This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Drizzle Bird
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump versus Surf: Hydro Pump significantly weakens opponents when rain-boosted, often picking up surprise KOs. Surf is the far more reliable option.

  • Hurricane versus Roost; The choice between Hurricane and Roost is a matter of coverage versus longevity. Hurricane gives Pelipper a powerful secondary STAB move, while Roost takes advantage of its decent physical bulk, increasing its staying power. This is particularly useful in weather wars against Torkoal

Tera Types

Ground: Tera Ground gives Pelipper an immunity to Volt Switch, which is often used against it early-game. This wastes a turn for the opponent and gives Pelipper the chance to safely U-turn or deal massive damage with a rain-boosted Hydro Pump.

Grass: Tera Grass is a viable option for Rotom-W, which primarily uses Hydro Pump on lead while providing a Volt Switch resistance.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA with Quiet: With 0 Speed IVs, this is used to underspeed uninvested Hippowdon, giving Pelipper the initial advantage in weather wars.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA with Relaxed: This spread gives Pelipper a better matchup against dominant, powerful physical attackers like Choice Band Dragpault and Extreme Speed Dragonite.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest: This offensive spread can be used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight and others in that Speed tier.

Items

  • Eject Button: This extra method of pivoting makes it much easier to switch Pelipper in just for getting rain up.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs can be used to take advantage of Pelipper's powerful STAB moves.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry provides longevity on defensive sets.

vgc2023.overview:
• Pelipper's role is primarily to set rain for its teammates, but functions it as an offensive support Pokemon with fully accurate Hurricanes and access to Tailwind and Wide Guard.

  • Rain boosts the power of Water-type teammates such as Palafin, Floatzel, and Drednaw, and it also weakens Fire-type moves for Fire-weak partners such as Amoonguss, Gholdengo, and Kingambit.

  • Pelipper's overall bulk is lacking, particularly specially, and super effective attacks like Thunderbolt from Gholdengo or Rotom-W are capable of OHKOing it.

sets.name: Pelipper
sets.description:
• Hurricane's full accuracy in Rain makes it mandatory on Pelipper. It provides consistent damage and threatens the Grass-type Pokemon that resist Water.

  • Hydro Pump is Pelipper's best Water-type attack but can be forgone if accuracy is a concern. Helping Hand paired with a fast Water-type Pokemon can compensate for the lack of reliable Water-type damage.

  • Wide Guard can be used over Protect to answer ubiquitous spread moves such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Sylveon's Hyper Voice.

  • Focus Sash ensures Pelipper survives attacks from Pokemon that might otherwise outspeed and OHKO it, such as Hydreigon and Annihilape. Damp Rock extends the uptime of Pelipper's rain-reliant teammates, allowing them to beat bulkier teams without requiring repeat switch-ins.

  • 252 Speed EVs with a Timid nature allow Pelipper to outspeed the entire metagame with Tailwind, as well as some notable Choice Scarf threats such as Annihilape.

  • A Ground Tera type grants Pelipper an immunity to Electric and a resistance to Rock, which are its main concerns. With a Grass Tera type, it instead resists Electric, but this grants an immunity to Spore and Rage Powder.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description: Pelipper is a staple pick on rain teams thanks to its ability, Drizzle. Its physical bulk combined with Scald lets it check and potentially cripple foes such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Scizor, and Great Tusk. Hurricane is an alternative to Defog on teams that use Tornadus-T for entry hazard control, which offers better neutral coverage and the ability to hit foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran. Pelipper also operates as a slow pivot with U-turn, which is greatly appreciated by the team's wallbreakers to ensure that they can enter the field safely. Tera Ground offers an Electric immunity for threats such as Tapu Koko, whereas Tera Steel offers a strong defensive typing, letting Pelipper check Pokemon like Extreme Speed Dragonite in a pinch. As the premier rain setter, Pokemon that rely on rain to boost their power or operate effectively within it, such as Mega Swampert, Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Urshifu-R, make for common teammates. Mega Swampert offers a valuable Electric immunity for Pelipper, checking foes such as Tapu Koko. Tornadus-T can provide entry hazard control with Defog, letting Pelipper enter the field and summon rain without having to fear taking hazard damage. Ferrothorn takes advantage of Pelipper's typing and ability to form a solid defensive core and provide a robust blanket check for opposing rain. In return, Pelipper alleviates Ferrothorn's massive Fire weakness by setting rain, and it can check threats that Ferrothorn fails to cover, such as Mega Lopunny.

sets.name: Sticky Web
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
A Focus Sash allows Breloom to make full use of Spore's utility and function as a solid lead or early-game wallbreaker. Spore generates free turns that Breloom or a teammate can capitalize on and is especially useful to halt a sweeper that Breloom cannot reliably OHKO, such as Iron Valiant or Volcarona. Bullet Seed hits various defensive Pokemon, such as Clodsire, Dondozo, and Garganacl, for significant damage. Mach Punch lets Breloom revenge kill threats such as Greninja and Roaring Moon and allows it to preserve its Focus Sash by bypassing Kingambit's Sucker Punch. With Tera Fire, Tera Blast lets Breloom lure in and dispatch Gholdengo and Amoonguss, the tier's predominant Spore absorbers. Alternatively, Swords Dance helps Breloom better pressure Pokemon such as Toxapex and Hatterene with Bullet Seed, while Close Combat is another option for faster-paced teams that gives Breloom a greater immediate offensive presence. If Breloom drops Tera Blast, Tera Fighting is ideal to power up Mach Punch and Close Combat, notably allowing +2 Mach Punch to OHKO Cinderace and deal huge damage to Pokemon that resist it such as Iron Valiant and Iron Moth.

Reliable forms of entry hazard control, such as Great Tusk and Hatterene, are vital teammates that help preserve Breloom's Focus Sash and give it the flexibility to stop a sweeper or wallbreaker later in the game. Rotom-W, Iron Valiant, and Garganacl all greatly appreciate Tera Fire Breloom's ability to weaken or eliminate Gholdengo and Amoonguss. Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Hydreigon can check the Ghost-types that are immune to Breloom's Mach Punch, such as Dragapult, and Skeledirge. Powerful sweepers such as Baxcalibur, Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Roaring Moon can take advantage of Spore granting them free opportunities to set up. Similarly, wallbreakers like Dragapult and Greninja can maximize the free turns generated by Spore to break through defensive threats that trouble Breloom, such as Skeledirge, and Corviknight.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Breloom is a powerful wallbreaker, capable of shredding through physically defensive walls such as Garganacl, Dondozo, and Corviknight. Technician-boosted Bullet Seed hits Water- and Ground-types such as Rotom-W and Great Tusk hard while providing a powerful neutral hit against walls such as Toxapex and Hatterene. Close Combat is Breloom's most consistent wallbreaking tool, OHKOing Garganacl after Stealth Rock and cleanly 2HKOing Corviknight. Mach Punch, in conjunction with Technician, allows Breloom to pick off faster threats such as Greninja, Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Baxcalibur. Lastly, Bulldoze OHKOes Gholdengo and 2HKOes Skeledirge, while Spore lets Breloom incapacitate a switch-in and generates opportunities to take down counters later in the battle, and Rock Tomb OHKOes Volcarona while reliably hitting Dragonite and still 2HKOing Skeledirge. Tera Fighting allows Breloom to 2HKO Amoonguss after Stealth Rock with Close Combat and revenge kill threats such as Cinderace from higher health with Mach Punch. Alternatively, Tera Grass turns Bullet Seed into a powerful nuke that can break down common switch-ins like Gholdengo and generally increase its damage output, turning Breloom into a very potent stallbreaker. Tera Fire, on the other hand, gives Breloom the option to use Tera Blast in the final slot, which destroys Gholdengo and Amoonguss and allows Breloom to take a hit from, and OHKO in return, offensive Volcarona.

Breloom fits well on bulky offense teams that can give it opportunities to come into play and capitalize on its wallbreaking prowess. Due to Breloom's low defenses and Speed, it appreciates being paired with pivots like Rotom-W and Dragapult that can help it enter battle safely. Ting-Lu and Great Tusk can set entry hazards to help Breloom break through pivots such as Toxapex and Amoonguss. Great Tusk in particular appreciates its tendency to force in Gholdengo and pop its Air Balloon, while teammates such as Garganacl, Toxapex, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo can deal with Breloom's faster offensive checks, such as Dragapult, Volcarona, and Iron Valiant. On more hyper offensive teams, Breloom is best paired with sweepers like Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Baxcalibur that appreciate its ability to wear down key defensive threats such as Garganacl, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo. On these teams, leads such as Glimmora can set hazards to aid Breloom's wallbreaking capabilities. Kingambit is a fantastic partner that handles Gholdengo and appreciates Breloom putting pressure on Great Tusk.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Since it can sleep foes without restriction, Breloom is a monstrous foe that every team needs to prepare for!

  • Bulldoze: This is Breloom's best option against Gholdengo and provides valuable speed control.

  • Spore: As good as Spore is, it's well prepared for enough by threats such as Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Lum Berry that going without it can make sense.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb provides speed control and ensures that Breloom is not walled by Flying-types such as Dragonite.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat lets Breloom muscle past bulkier threats more easily, such as Tera Steel Garganacl.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: Breloom doesn't Terastallize often, but Fighting Tera is a good choice for picking off foes more easily with Mach Punch.

  • Ground: Tera Ground-boosted Bulldoze has a 93.8% chance to OHKO 4 HP Gholdengo, making Breloom a situational lure. It also severely punishes Rotom-W that attempt to Volt Switch out, and Hippowdon that don't Terastallize.

  • Fire: With Tera Blast, Tera Fire provides an alternative way to get past Gholdengo, avoids getting burned by other foes, and gives bulkier Breloom a chance against Flutter Mane.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Since Breloom's bulk isn't very good, Focus Sash is the most reliable way to fire off Spore.

  • Loaded Dice: Guaranteeing 4 hits from Bullet Seed can be quite useful for bulkier Breloom sets, clinching a OHKO on Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle regardless of them running Substitute.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: If using Focus Sash, maximizing Speed is important to deal with slower foes that might invest in Speed, such as Corviknight and Skeledirge.

  • 252 HP / 180 Atk / 76 SpD: This bulkier spread makes sense if using Loaded Dice and Swords Dance, letting Breloom survive one hit from Iron Bundle or Choice Specs Flutter Mane with the correct Tera type.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Mega Medicham is a tremendously strong wallbreaker due to Pure Power, strong STAB moves, and coverage. Fake Out lets Mega Medicham chip down and revenge kill Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. It also can let Mega Medicham stall out rain, Toxic, and Terrain on foes, all while putting opponents into range for one of its stronger attacks safely. Ice Punch lets Mega Medicham get rid of Landorus-T and Dragonite, which can enable it to freely use its STAB moves. Bullet Punch can be used to snipe Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Weavile, and it also removes revenge killers like Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny after chip damage. Thunder Punch can be used to hit Slowbro, and in tandem with Electric Terrain, it can 2HKO Pokemon like Gholdengo and Victini. Alternatively, Thief can be used to immediately damage the aforementioned Pokemon, so it can use its STAB moves more. Due to Mega Medicham’s frailty and mediocre Speed tier, it is easily revenge killed. Defensive partners like Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn help check threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Knock Off and Pursuit users like Kingambit and Weavile also support Mega Medicham, as they break through Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon Mega Medicham struggle with, such as Slowbro, Victini, Gholdengo and Skeledirge, allowing it to consistently use its STAB attacks. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn benefit Mega Medicham, as it forces a lot of switches and entry hazards wear down checks quickly. Tapu Koko is a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it handles Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Slowbro reliably and powers up Mega Medicham's Thunder Punch. Tapu Lele can also be a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it powers up Zen Headbutt to insane levels, but blocking Fake Out and Bullet Punch from being used can be problematic. Pokemon like Volcarona and Kartana appreciate Torandus-T, Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Gholdengo being pressured constantly by Mega Medicham, enabling them to wreak havoc once the checks are removed or chipped.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Fire Spin and Grass Tera Blast can effectively lure otherwise undesirable matchups like Sandaconda and Vaporeon. 88 Speed allows Camerupt to outspeed the likes of Muk, Crocalor, and Perrserker

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Sun Support
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

vgc2023.overview:
• Torkoal has exclusive access to drought, making it the most consistent sun setter in the format. Its rock-bottom Speed and sun-boosted Eruption make it an absolutely terrifying Trick Room sweeper, capable of chunking or outright KOing a majority of the metagame.

  • Heavy support in the form of Trick Room and/or Chlorophyll + After You Lilligant is mandatory. Torkoal also welcomes priority protection from the likes of Farigiraf and Indeedee, both of which set Trick Room as well. While Torkoal has high enough bulk to shrug off most priority moves, it hates having the power of Eruption lowered, and Fake Out wastes its Trick Room turns.

  • Torkoal faces stiff competition from Armarouge due to Armarouge's superior support capabilities and better coverage options, in spite of its lower overall damage output. To make matters worse, Tera Grass, Pyschic, or Dark Armarouge and Ceruledge wall most Torkoal sets endlessly, using Flash Fire, Wide Guard, and Terastillization removing their weakness to Earth Power. However, Armarouge pairs well with Torkoal by giving it protection from Earthquake and enjoying sun itself.

  • Most Dragon-types such as Garchomp and Assault Vest Hydreigon can take everything Torkoal can dish out and threaten it in return. Guts Hariyama can protect against Garchomp's Earthquake with Wide Guard and threatens an OHKO on Garchomp. Lilligant can put them to sleep and threatens Garchomp with Leaf Storm. Hatterene is a more offensive Trick Room setter that threatens the Dragon-types with Dazzling Gleam.

sets.name: Trick Room Offense
sets.description:
• This set makes full use of Torkoal's nuclear power. Eruption vaporizes nearly anything without a resistance or immunity to Fire after Terrastilization. Heat Wave gives it a mostly-reliable spread option after taking damage. Earth Power hits opposing Fire-types and gives Torkoal a single-target option to get around Wide Guard.

  • Tera Fire is the go-to option to maximize Torkoal's damage. Tera Flying and Grass removes its weaknesses, which helps greatly against the ever-frequent Ground-type attacks, but are generally not worth it.

  • Solar Beam is an option to hit Water-types meaningfully and to hit Rock- and Ground-types a little harder than Earth Power. Tera Blast is a niche option if Torkoal is running Tera Flying, turning the tables on Tera Grass Armarouge and Ceruledge attempting to wall it. Choice Specs would push Torkoal's offensive capabilities onto another planet, but it makes Torkoal even easier to exploit with Wide Guard, Flash Fire, and attacks in general—it can't viably run Protect.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
Tera Fairy removes Salamence's weakness to Stealth Rock and Noivern's Draco Meteor while retaining its good matchup against Slither Wing.

Tera Ghost lets Salamence completely counter Lucario and Maushold while retaining its good matchup against Slither Wing.

Tera Steel lets it check Grafaiai, Maushold, and Staraptor, and revenge kill Lucario even when weakened.

Tera Dragon gives Draco Meteor a huge power boost, letting Salamence put more pressure onto checks like Gastrodon and Slowking in addition to making it resist Pawmot's Double Shock.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Tera Steel lets Salamence set up against Pokemon like Scream Tail, Grafaiai, and Staraptor.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Specsmence Returns
sets.description:
• Salamence finds a niche for itself among other special attacking Dragon-types due to an incredible ability in Intimidate and a useful typing that provides a handy Fissure immunity.

  • Hurricane versus Air Slash: Hurricane's accuracy may not be very reliable, but the sheer damage output makes it worth it. Air Slash is much weaker than Hurricane, but the more reliable accuracy and flinch chance make it a reasonable alternative. It becomes especially attractive if using Tera Flying.

  • Hydro Pump: If not using Tera Fairy, Hydro Pump is a reasonable choice that deals massive damage to Hippowdon and Fire-types without risking Draco Meteor.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Not only does Tera Fairy give Salamence an edge against many Dragon-types, but it also pairs extremely well with Intimidate, transforming Salamence into an effective hit-and-run threat.

  • Steel: Tera Steel comes in handy against Dragon- and Fairy-types alike, though the added weaknesses to Ground and Fighting make it less effective at taking physical hits with Intimidate.

  • Flying: Air Slash becomes much easier to justify with Tera Flying, and if you're willing to risk it, Hurricane can be used to become almost impossible to wall with Choice Specs.

  • Fire: Tera Fire doesn't offer as much defensive utility, but the powerful STAB attacks come in handy against Steel-types like Corviknight.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon trades defensive advantages for an extremely powerful Draco Meteor that catches defensive foes like Dondozo by surprise.

Items

  • Choice Specs: With Salamence already standing at a decent Speed tier, it can get away with Choice Specs, making it extremely difficult to wall outside of using Blissey.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf trades wallbreaking power for the ability to get the jump on major offensive threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Garchomp.

sets.name: Physically Offensive
sets.description:
• Salamence is somewhat overshadowed by other physical Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragapult, but it has a trick up its claws: Dual Wingbeat, which OHKOes Breloom and Meowscarada through their Focus Sash.

  • Earthquake versus Fire Blast: Earthquake is the best option for hitting Steel-types such as Gholdengo hard, but Fire Blast is Salamence's best shot at 2HKOing Corviknight.

  • Dragon Dance: After a boost, Dual Wingbeat's Focus Sash slaying powers go into overdrive, being able to bust through Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Great Tusk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, a boosted Dual Wingbeat has a 75% chance to OHKO offensive Mimikyu through its disguise! It also means Salamence no longer needs a boost to OHKO Great Tusk and Flutter Mane.

  • Electric: Tera Electric lets Tera Blast Salamence OHKO Azumarill and Iron Bundle, and potentially 2HKO Dondozo after Stealth Rock damage.

Abilities

  • Intimidate: While Salamence isn't particularly bulky, Intimidate makes setting up far easier when paired with a Flying Tera type that removes Salamence's common weaknesses.

  • Moxie: With Moxie, Salamence has the potential to seriously punish Breloom leads or snowball through teams even without Dragon Dance.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
• Salamence's great mixed offenses, Intimidate, and decent Speed give it a niche as a powerful wall breaker.

  • Dual Wingbeat: Dual Wingbeat lets Salamence OHKO Breloom regardless of its Focus Sash, something very few Pokemon can do.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor deals massive damage to Dondozo, usually doing more than 50% to physically defensive ones.

  • Substitute: Substitute makes the Dondozo match-up even better, making Yawn a non-issue. It's also a good way to scout Terastallization against slower threats.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type covers a lot of Salamence's weaknesses and makes dealing with Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane much easier.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Salamence a great match-up against most Dragon-types, and pairs especially well with Intimidate to turn Salamence into a good hit-and-run attacker.

  • Fire: With a Fire Tera type, Salamence gains a resistance to Fairy-type attacks and deals massive damage to Assault Vest Magnezone.

  • Electric: Tera Electric gives Salamence a great tool against Dondozo with Tera Blast.

  • Dragon: While this Tera type fails to help Salamence much defensively, it makes Draco Meteor 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Flying increases Staraptor's damage against targets such as Tinkaton, 2HKOing it. Tera Normal can be used to remove its Stealth Rock weakness. However, Double-Edge isn't as spammable as Brave Bird due to the presence of Ghost-types.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Tera Flying increases Staraptor's damage against targets such as Tinkaton and Quagsire, possibly OHKOing the latter. Tera Ground can be used to provide a resistance to Stealth Rock and mitigate chip damage while taking advantage of the fact Choice Band Staraptor already has very little defensive counterplay. It can also turn the tables against Electric-types like Sandy Shocks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swift Weasel
sets.description:
• Wave Crash: This is your main offensive option. When further boosted by rain, Tera Water, and Choice Band, it becomes one of the most powerful physical moves in the game, 2HKOing the likes of Bold Amoonguss and OHKOing maximum Defense Corviknight. Mystic Water is an option for flexibility but sacrifices the listed KOs.

  • Liquidation versus Waterfall: Liquidation is a secondary option, and it's preferred when facing frailer offensive teams due to the significant recoil drawback of Wave Crash. However, Waterfall is worth considering for its possible flinch chance.

  • Aqua Jet: Aqua Jet allows Floatzel to maintain offensive presence outside of rain, as well as being a great response to opposing priority moves, such as Kingambit's Sucker Punch.

  • Rain Setter: Pelipper's rain is mandatory for both Swift Swim and maximum damage output.

Tera Types

  • Water: Tera Water massively bolters Floatzel's damage output, and the weasel simply doesn't have the bulk needed for more defensive options.

EV Spreads

  • 60 HP / 252 Atk / 196 Spe:196 Speed EVs are used to outspeed the entire tier in rain, including Choice Scarf Dragpault.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: Maximum Speed investment outspeeds Hydreigon and Mimikyu outside of rain, in addition to tying with Salamence, at the cost of having less buffer HP for Wave Crash recoil.

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Floatzel is an incredible wallbreaker on rain teams, making use of its decent Attack stat powered by its Choice Band. Low Kick hits Ferrothorn and Ice Spinner hits Dragapult and Dragonite more reliably. However, because of Tera Water, its Water-type moves are all boosted considerably, so coverage is often unnecessary. Aqua Jet gives Floatzel priority outside of rain against weakened targets such as Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, and it bypasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tornadus-T and Zapdos all appreciate Floatzel's offensive capabilities, as it deals with wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Mega Diancie, Gholdengo, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Valiant. Zapdos can reliably check Water-types that counter Floatzel like Slowbro and Dodonzo. Tornadus-T can weaken and cripple Floatzel checks in Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Ferrothorn, as Knock Off removes Leftovers from them, making it easier for Floatzel to wallbreak. Offensive partners like Manaphy and Mega Swampert can overwhelm those same Water-resistant Pokemon as well as Dragonite. Ferrothorn can check priority users such as the aforementioned Dragonite and Kingambit, alleviating Floatzel's weakness to them.

sets.name: Mixed Wall
sets.description:
Tera Poison allows Gastrodon to resist Fighting-type attacks from Slither Wing and Hawlucha, as well as Power Whip from Tsareena. It also gains a Toxic immunity, which lets it beat foes like Grafaiai, and it resists other miscellaneous attacks such as Play Rough from Mimikyu and First Impression from Lokix.

Tera Ghost allows Gastrodon to stop Rapid Spin users such as Tsareena and Donphan from removing its entry hazards, although it should be wary of the latter's high Attack. It also resists Slither Wing's STAB moves and shuts down Swords Dance Lucario.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Gastrodon finds itself a valuable role in National Dex primarily off its invaluable Water and Electric immunities, allowing it to handle terrifying rain sweepers such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert and answer Rotom-W perfectly. Scald lets Gastrodon threaten a burn against otherwise safe switch-ins such as Ferrothorn and Dragonite. Toxic better threatens defensive Pokemon such as opposing Gastrodon, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. Earthquake threatens Pokemon like Heatran, Clodsire, and Gholdengo. Relaxed should be selected as Gastrodon's nature if using Earthquake to not lower its damage output; Bold should be used otherwise. Tera Fairy can be used in a pinch to grant Gastrodon a resistance to Fighting against Urshifu-R and Barraskweda and a Dark resistance against Kingambit. The given EV spread maximizes Gastrodon's physical bulk to better take on the likes of Floatzel, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R. Gastrodon fits best on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its defensive qualities while being able to supplement its passivity with offensive wallbreakers. Pokemon such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo can switch into Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Kartana and Ferrothorn; In return, Gastrodon provides entry hazard support to wear down answers such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Clodsire. Strong, fast wallbreakers like Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta love having Gastrodon as a fallback measure against the myriad of Water-type revenge killers on rain such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert. If Gastrodon opts to use Spikes, it likes having Stealth Rock setters such as Heatran and Mega Diancie as partners to form an effective entry hazard-stacking core.

sets.name: Tailwind Setter
sets.description:
• The given EVs and nature allow Drifblim to outspeed Choice Scarf Chi-Yu after Unburden or in Tailwind, and retain enough Attack to 2HKO Chi-Yu with Acrobatics, with the remaining EVs invested to improve overall bulk.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: TankChomp
sets.description:
Garchomp is a formidable tank that can reliably set multiple layers of entry hazards while still possessing an adequate offensive presence itself. Notably, it matches up well against common spinners like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Glimmora, especially as it can punish them from doing so with Rocky Helmet + Rough Skin. This combination is also valuable to spread chip damage onto physical attackers like Kingambit and Dragonite and punish pivots such as Cinderace and Corviknight. Dragon Tail forces out setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Tera Flying Kingambit, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Air Balloon Gholdengo, and it works extremely well to force entry hazard damage onto foes such as Tera Fairy Garganacl, Dondozo, and Iron Valiant. Tera Ghost is used to completely spinblock Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Alternatively, Tera Steel lets it emergency check Dragapult, Meowscarada, and non-Earthquake Baxcalibur and block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Tera Water allows it to deal with Gholdengo, Scizor, and Hatterene better.

Garchomp fits best on hazard stacking teams that range from bulky offense to offense. Gholdengo is a near-necessary teammate that can prevent most attempts of entry hazard removal, and it can make use of them itself to chip down checks like Tera Water Garganacl, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Knock Off users like Meowscarada and Great Tusk can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Amoonguss, Kingambit, and Dragonite to make them susceptible to Garchomp's entry hazards; Great Tusk in particular provides Rapid Spin as well, which removes entry hazards on your side of the field and subsequently maintains your own entry hazards up the opponent's side. Offensive Pokemon like Greninja, Dragapult, Volcarona, and Iron Valiant tend to force multiple switches and enjoy entry hazards chipping down their checks such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, Clodsire, and Garganacl. Substitute Skeledirge is a fantastic teammate that can take advantage of entry hazards itself, use its defensive profile to cover Fairy- and Ice-types like Iron Valiant and Baxcalibur, threaten Defog Corviknight from removing entry hazards, and pressure Hatterene, which would otherwise prevent Garchomp's antics and use it as setup fodder.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Garchomp serves as an excellent wallbreaker that possesses great defensive utility, having an Electric-type immunity and being a check to Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Outrage with Dragonium Z muscles through Pokemon like Great Tusk, Tangrowth, and Ting-Lu. Garchomp fits best on offensive teams; Pokemon like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Tapu Koko benefit from it breaking through Pokemon like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Dragonite. Tapu Koko makes a stellar partner because it can pivot on Garchomp targets in Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. In return, Tapu Koko threatens Corviknight and Slowbro, two major roadblocks for Garchomp. Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kingambit can pressure revenge killers such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Dragapult thanks to their strong priority while taking several attacks from them. Rotom-W switches into Pokemon that threaten Garchomp such as Great Tusk and Tornadus-T. Garchomp can take care of Pokemon Rotom-W pivots out on such as Gastrodon, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: TankChomp
sets.description: Garchomp possesses great role compression and is a good check to contact attackers like Mega Scizor, Dragonite, and Mega Lopunny. Toxic can cripple switch-ins such as Landorus-T, Tangrowth, and Rotom-W. Dragon Tail can stop any setup attempts from Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Dragonite lacking Ice Spinner and can wear down Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Flamethrower can rip through Pokemon like Kartana, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn. Tera Ghost lets Garchomp spinblock Great Tusk and switch into Fighting-type moves from Pokemon like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta, while Tera Water grants resistances to Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Ice- and Water-type moves from Weavile, Floatzel, and Urshifu-R as well as neutrality to Fairy-type attacks from Iron Valiant and Mega Diancie. Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and improves Garchomp's matchup against Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragapult. The given Speed EVs with a Jolly Nature allows Garchomp to outspeed Timid Gholdengo, while maximizing its physical bulk. Teammates like Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, and Volcarona can cover Garchomp's Ice and Fairy weaknesses and threaten out a majority of Garchomp checks such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Mega Diancie. In return, Garchomp can switch into Rock- and Fire-type Pokemon like Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Volcarona. Knock Off Kingambit and Weavile support Garchomp by crippling common Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
• The classic Swords Dance sweeper is still a big threat, thanks to its good bulk, unique Speed tier, and excellent use of Terastallization.

  • Outrage versus Dragon Claw: Outrage is by far Garchomp's strongest STAB move, but the lock-in effect makes it very vulnerable to Fairy-types such as Mimikyu.

  • Fire Fang versus Tera Blast: Despite its low base power, Fire Fang is Garchomp's best shot at breaking past Corviknight after a Swords Dance. If Garchomp is almost always Terastallized on your team, Tera Blast can be used instead.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has excellent synergy with Garchomp's typing, letting it more effectively tackle faster Dragon-types, Iron Bundle, Mimikyu, and Ice Shard from the likes of Baxcalibur and Cloyster.

  • Fairy: Fairy is an even stronger option against Dragon-types, and gives Garchomp a better matchup against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness is unfortunate against bulkier teams, a Fire Tera type lets Life Orb Garchomp OHKO Corviknight with a +2 Fire Fang 93.8% of the time.

  • Ground: While the defensive synergy with Garchomp's former typing isn't that strong, a Ground Tera type lets Garchomp become more of a hit-and-run attacker with Earthquake, dealing good damage to Dondozo before being forced out by Yawn.

Items

  • Life Orb: This is the best option for damage output.

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Garchomp deal with major status users more easily, such as Dragapult and Breloom.

  • Mirror Herb: Mirror Herb gives Garchomp the potential to severely punish set-up sweepers such as Dragapult and Dragonite, with the right Tera type.

  • Focus Sash: Surviving shocking attacks with Focus Sash gives Garchomp new sweeping and revenge killing potential.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description:
• While Garchomp is known for its offensive prowess, it can also support its teammates with entry hazards and phazing.

  • Earthquake versus Bulldoze: Bulldoze brings utility against Choice Scarf and naturally fast grounded opponents, but its lower Base Power makes Garchomp more passive against bulkier Pokemon.

  • Dragon Tail: Dragon Tail has marvelous synergy with setting up hazards, making it the prime choice for a Dragon-type STAB despite the lowered priority.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: If using Tera Fairy, this can help Garchomp muscle past Great Tusk, a foe that can threaten to Rapid Spin your hazards away.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Fairy Tera type provides Garchomp with an immunity to Dragon-type attacks, and is a big help against Great Tusk.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type makes Garchomp resist Dragon-, Ice- and Fairy-type attacks, making it a safer lead against opposing Dragon-type leads and Iron Bundle, at the cost of being vulnerable to Tera Fire Dragons and Fighting- and Ground-types.

EV spreads

  • 188 HP / 236 Def / 84 Spe with Impish: This EV spread lets Garchomp survive Adamant Dragonite's Outrage while also outspeeding it.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Jolly: While this spread doesn't take physical hits as well, it lets Garchomp outspeed Gholdengo, Baxcalibur, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: This prevents Choice Band Dragapult from OHKOing Garchomp, as it activates after the first hit, and the HP recovered doesn't allow the second one to get the KO, unless Dragapult is Terastallized into a Dragon-type.

  • Rocky Helmet: Combined with Rough Skin, Rocky Helmet severely punishes contact moves.

  • Red Card: With Red Card, Garchomp will be able to phaze foes Terastallizing into a Fairy type once.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Garchomp's fantastic Speed tier and power make it a fine Choice item user, especially when it can catch its softer checks off guard, such as Dragapult and Corviknight.

  • Stone Edge versus Rock Tomb: Stone Edge deals massive damage to common Tera Flying Pokemon such as Gholdengo, and it prevents it from being walled by Tera Fairy Rotom-W. Rock Tomb is fairly weak, but the speed control can be very useful on Choice Scarf variants if sacrificing Garchomp.

  • Iron Head: With Tera Steel, Iron Head lets Garchomp beat Tera Fairy Levitate foes such as Rotom-W.

Other Options

  • Crunch: Crunch lets Garchomp deal massive damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo, though it doesn't cover much else.

  • Fire Fang While weak, this is Garchomp's best option against Corviknight when not Tera Fire.

Tera Types

  • Fire: When combined with Tera Blast, Tera Fire lets even Choice Scarf Garchomp possibly 2HKO Corviknight. The Fairy and Ice resistance is also very helpful.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a good defensive alternative to Fire, retaining the useful Stealth Rock resistance and preforming better against Dragon- and Fairy-types.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy goes all in on the Dragon-type immunity, and deals with Great Tusk and Flutter Mane better than other Tera types.

  • Ground: The incredible power boost Earthquake gets from Tera Ground is worth considering, with Choice Band possibly 2HKOing physically defensive Dondozo with it.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band trades revenge killing for wallbreaking, letting Garchomp reliably 2HKO Skeledirge and deal massive damage to Corviknight with Fire-type Tera Blast.

  • Choice Scarf: With Choice Scarf, Garchomp is able to outspeed and revenge kill key threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Choice Specs Iron Moth, making it a potent late-game cleaner as well.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description: With good natural bulk, a great typing, phazing, and both Spikes and Stealth Rock, Garchomp is an effective entry hazard setter that also checks common threats like Ceruledge. Swords Dance is an option over either entry hazard to pressure bulkier teams. Dragon Tail forces switches and potentially create a favorable situation for Garchomp and helps rack up even more entry hazard damage. As Garchomp does not have any reliable recovery, Leftovers is the preferred option to give Garchomp longevity, but Heavy-Duty Boots is great for opposing hazard-stack matchups. Due to Garchomp mainly being an entry hazard setter, it greatly appreciates teammates such as Good as Gold Skeledirge to keep the entry hazards up in the face of Defog and Rapid Spin. Garchomp also works well with offensive threats such as Sheer Force Gengar, as the entry hazards can wear down its checks into KO range. Garchomp struggles to check common attackers like Greninja, so secondary checks like specially defensive Clodsire are appreciated.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Inner Focus prevents Lucario from having its Attack dropped by Salamence's Intimidate. Tera Normal lets Lucario gain a STAB bonus on its Extreme Speed to sweep teams after setting up.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!
Stone Edge can be used over Stealth Rock if the team has another Stealth Rock user such as Tinkaton.

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature retains enough Attack for Hippowdon to OHKO Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum before investing remaining EVs in HP and Special Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Few Pokemon are more reliable at setting up Stealth Rock and phazing than Hippowdon.

  • Whirlwind: This is a more direct phazing option than Yawn, and it is helpful against dangerous setup sweepers that may run Lum Berry, such as Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Slack Off: Slack Off may seem like an obvious choice to make a defensive Pokemon last longer, but Hippowdon is often more focused on support than walling, so Slack Off doesn't fit every team.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb not only provides helpful speed control, but also pops Air Balloon on foes Hippowdon would otherwise struggle with, such as Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Fissure: Hippowdon isn't quite as good at using Fissure as Dondozo and Garganacl, and it can be difficult to fit in, but it does severely punish passive play.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Hippowdon doesn't Terastallize often, but a Grass Tera type does help it against Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Water-types such as Rotom-W.

  • Steel: Tera Steel allows specially defensive Hippowdon to avoid a 2HKO from Iron Bundle that lack Choice Specs.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Careful: Patching up Hippowdon's weaker Special Defense is quite useful against special attackers, such as having a 6.3% chance of surviving Gholdengo's +2 Make It Rain, and Choice Specs Hydreigon no longer being able to 2HKO Sitrus Berry Hippowdon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Impish: A physically defensive spread means not even Choice Band Tera Dragon Dragapult will be able to 2HKO Sitrus Berry Hippowdon.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fluffy Hippowdon is a remarkable physical wall thanks to its defensive stats, reliable recovery in Slack Off, and pure Ground typing, letting it check non-Mold Breaker offensive threats like Dragonite, Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing. Whirlwind prevents foes like the aforementioned Dragonite from setting up. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it checks and lets it pseudo-spinblock Cyclizar and Iron Treads; alternatively, Leftovers gives it extra recovery without having to waste Slack Off PP. 25 Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight, allowing it to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Specially defensive walls like Corviknight, Florges, and Blissey can compensate for Hippowdon's poor Special Defense and check foes like Chi-Yu and Greninja. In return, they appreciate Hippowdon dealing with Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2023.overview:
• Snow lets Abomasnow carve itself a niche in the current metagame.

  • Abomasnow is a decent offensive support Pokemon with Aurora Veil, which partners well with various Ice-types such as Baxcalibur, Cetitan, and Glaceon, as they gain a Defense boost in snow.

  • Abomasnow's offensive typing is well-suited in a metagame filled with Ground-, Dragon-, and Water-types such as Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Rotom-W.

  • Despite the Defense boost in snow, Abomasnow is still fairly specially frail with a poor set of weaknesses that leave it vulnerable to some of the most common special attackers in the format like Gholdengo and Armarouge.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Giga Drain gives Abomasnow some longevity when behind Aurora Veil and lets it beat the likes of Rotom-W and Palafin which resist Blizzard. Earth Power is an alternative that hits Fire- and Steel-types like Torkoal and Gholdengo, notably OHKOing the former when Terastallized.

  • Abomansow runs items that help it overcome its crucial weaknesses. Focus Sash allows it to take any one hit, such as Rotom-H's Overheat, letting it set up Aurora Veil. Babiri Berry serves a similar purpose, allowing it to survive Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Tera Steel Hydreigon's Flash Cannon.

  • The Speed investment allows Abomsnow to outspeed Garchomp while in Tailwind.

  • Water is the primary Tera type used by Abomasnow, turning its Fire and Steel weaknesses into resistances. Ground is an alternative Tera type that allows it to fire off STAB-boosted Earth Powers, catching its common checks by surprise.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Thanks to its high Speed, great Attack stat, and good STAB combination, Weavile is able to tear apart offensive teams and set itself apart from other Pursuit trappers in Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar. It can easily trap Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Choice Specs Dragapult with Pursuit. Triple Axel has good neutral coverage and threatens a KO on foes like Kartana, Mega Charizard Y, and Iron Valiant, while Knock Off removes items from the likes of Toxapex and Ferrothorn and provides good utility. Ice Shard helps revenge kill Dragapult and faster foes that have been weakened like Mega Lopunny and Tapu Koko. Tera Dark propels Weavile's Knock Off to stellar levels of damage, possibly 2HKOing defensive Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn after Stealth Rock while also removing its own weakness to Stealth Rock. Alternatively, Tera Ice allows Weavile to more easily revenge kill Dragapult, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Koko while also boosting its Triple Axel to insane levels. Although it can safely take unresisted hits from full, Weavile is really frail, so it appreciates being brought onto the field by pivots like Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Slowbro. The latter also provides Future Sight support, which allows Weavile to beat its most common checks, being Toxapex, Corviknight, and Urshifu-R. It also works well with Pokemon that like having Psychic- and Ghost-types like Gholdengho, Dragapult, and Tapu Lele being removed, like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta. Weavile also appreciates Spikes support from setters like Ting-Lu and Ferrothorn to weaken opposing Ferrothorn and Toxapex, as well as Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W to prevent it from being worn down by entry hazards.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Weavile's great Speed and Attack paired with Swords Dance makes it one of the most versatile Pokemon in the metagame, being able to wallbreak, revenge kill, and clean late-game. Most of Weavile's checks, such as Urshifu-R, Kingambit, and Heatran, aren't long-term checks and don't like losing their item. It also requires a minimal amount of chip damage on Pokemon like Buzzwole, Iron Hands, and Toxapex to effectively break them. Triple Axel is used for the larger damage output, but Ice Spinner can be used for a consistent and accurate STAB move. Icicle Crash avoids residual damage from contact abilities like Iron Barbs while also avoiding Static, Flame Body, and Rocky Helmet. Knock Off is usually preferred, as it can remove items from Toxapex and Ferrothorn and support Weavile's team, but Darkinium Z paired with Throat Chop allows Weavile to nuke its checks, mainly Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn. Tera Dark removes Weavile's weakness to Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor while also propelling Knock Off's damage to nearly unstoppable levels. Pivot support from the likes of Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Koko helps Weavile by bringing it safely onto the field while also allowing it to set up, making it more consistent. Magnezone works well with Weavile, as it can trap and remove Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight for it. In return, Weavile pressures Ground-types like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Weavile also appreciates being paired with strong wallbreakers that share checks with it such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Mega Mawile, as they can overwhelm them throughout the game. Weavile enjoys Spikes support from Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp, as it forces chip damage on its checks, such as Mega Scizor, Toxapex, and Iron Hands.

We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• In a metagame with very few special attackers, Magnezone carves a strong niche as an Electric-type attacker that can take out the common physical walls, such as Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Magnezone’s STAB combination is difficult to switch into, especially with Choice Specs. Clodsire, the most noteworthy special wall in the format, can fall to an Analytic-boosted Flash Cannon or Steel Beam when carrying Choice Specs.

Tera Types

  • Water: Offensively, Water Tera Blast nails Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Clodsire, although the risk it runs when considering Water Absorb should be noted. It also gives Magnezone a much-appreciated Fire resistance for Pokemon like Skeledirge, Iron Moth, and Volcarona, and lets Magnezone take on Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump.

  • Flying: Flying has wonderful defensive synergy with Magnezone, reversing its Ground and Fighting weaknesses, and lets Tera Blast hit Grass-types harder.

  • Fairy: A Fairy-type Tera Blast is very useful against common Dragon-types, most notably Garchomp and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Gaining a resistance to Dark allows Magnezone to surprise and defeat Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon.

  • Grass: Grass has excellent defensive and offense synergy with Magnezone, especially through its utility against Ground-type attackers and Spore immunity. Most notably, Tera Blast Grass can OHKO max SpD Hippowdon with Choice Specs.

  • Steel: The boost from Tera Steel makes Steel Beam absurdly powerful, with Analytic letting Choice Specs Magnezone OHKO even offensive Multiscale Dragonite!

EV Spreads

  • 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Modest: Running at least some Speed investment lets Magnezone outspeed critical Pokemon like Azumarill, Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Kingambit. 252 EVs give Magnezone a chance at outspeeding slow Mimikyu, Dragonite, Gholdengo, and Annihilape.

  • 188 HP / 252 SpA / 60 Spe with Modest: Magnezone's excellent typing means you often switch it into attacks, especially if you aren’t using Sturdy as an ability. This spread sacrifices some of Magnezone's Speed to raise its capabilities as a pivot. However, reducing the Speed EVs below 60 is not recommended, as it is the minimum required line to outspeed an uninvested Corviknight.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs gives Magnezone a devastating amount of power, with even Clodsire having trouble handling it.

  • Assault Vest: The increase in special bulk helps Magnezone against the myriad of choice item special attacking Dragon-types, like Hydreigon and Dragapult.

  • Air Balloon: The temporary Ground-type immunity helps Magnezone against foes like Garchomp and Dragonite without Terastallizing.

Abilities

  • Analytic: A Magnezone boosted by both Choice Specs and Analytic is incredibly hard to switch into, making it easier for Magnezone to generate momentum.

  • Sturdy: With Sturdy's guaranteed survivability and Magnezone's high damage output, Magnezone will very likely take down at least one Pokemon per game. Sturdy also helps Magnezone play around Dondozo, as it can safely come in on Fissure and use Volt Switch against it, which renders Yawn moot. However, if Magnezone switches into a Yawn and not Fissure, it should be noted that Dondozo often runs Protect to block Volt Switch and ensure Magnezone falls asleep.

  • Magnet Pull: Magnet Pull ensures Magnezone can eliminate Corviknight. In the case Magnezone uses Fighting as its Tera Type, Magnet Pull also allows it to beat both Kingambit and Tera Steel Hydreigon with more reliability.

With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Rotom-W's defensive set might be the more known one, but Rotom-H's key resistances to Fairy-type attacks and U-turn, plus its ability to put serious pressure on Gholdengo, make it a good alternative as a bulky pivot.

  • Foul Play: Foul Play is a must-have, as otherwise, Rotom-H is extremely passive against Baxcalibur, which is likely to switch in for an Attack boost from Overheat.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Thunder Wave: Will-O-Wisp is the preferred status move, potentially shutting down major physical threats such as Dragonite, Mimikyu, and Iron Hands. Thunder Wave is still a reasonable choice, though, stopping special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Iron Moth in their tracks.

  • Trick and Flame Orb: This one-use method of burning may seem silly, but taking away important items can be devastating against certain Pokemon, and Rotom-H can use this to get rid of troublesome Choice items it's taken a Trick as well. Note that Rotom-H will burn itself if it Terastallizes while holding Flame Orb, which is generally not good outside of blocking sleep or Toxic poison.

  • Using a Neutral Nature with a Bold Mint: If using Trick, it's best to run a neutral nature such as Serious and change the stat boosts with a Bold Mint. This way, Rotom-H won't get confused by any Berry it receives.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel with Levitate is a sublime defensive typing, letting Rotom-H better handle huge threats like Dragonite, Garchomp, and Baxcalibur.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is an alternative option to soak up Dragon-type attacks that also gives Rotom-H a better matchup against Great Tusk and Iron Hands.

  • Ghost: While this unfortunately makes Gholdengo a much bigger issue, Tera Ghost is still worth considering for making Rotom-H immune to Dragonite's Extreme Speed and dealing with Iron Valiant more smoothly. It also lets Rotom-H switch out of trapping moves without using Volt Switch.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is Rotom-H's ticket to staying around the longest, usually avoiding 2HKOs from powerful unboosted attacks such as Dragonite's Outrage and Iron Valiant's Close Combat.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rotom-H's typing makes it a good user of Rocky Helmet, passively punishing physical Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Iron Valiant and making it a good response to expected uses of U-turn.

sets.name: Choice Attacker
sets.description:
• Rotom-H sets itself apart from other Fire-types, with its Ground immunity and Volt Switch pivoting.

  • Trick: Trick gives Rotom-H an excellent tool against defensive foes, such as Dondozo and Skeledirge.

  • Using a neutral nature with a Timid mint: Make sure to get a Rotom-H with a neutral nature and then use a Timid Mint on it. This way, it can't be confused by any Berries given with Trick.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera typing with Tera Blast makes Rotom-H much better equipped to handle normally problematic Dragon-types, such as Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Dragapult.

  • Electric: Electric is an easy Tera type to recommend, as it increases damage output and removes all of Rotom-H's weaknesses.

  • Fire: When paired with Tera Blast, Rotom-H now has a much more reliable Fire-type STAB move than Overheat, at the cost of retaining several problematic weaknesses.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-H outspeed normally problematic threats such as Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Specs: The extra power makes Rotom-H far more difficult to wall, with defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Thunderbolt.

sets.name: Trick
sets.description:
Equipped with a Choice Scarf, Rotom-W provides excellent utility as a fast pivot thanks to its Volt Switch, devastating status moves, and high-Base Power STAB move in Hydro Pump. Volt Switch keeps up momentum during the game, and it can super effectively hit Corviknight, Dondozo, Toxapex, and Greninja, which Rotom-W now outspeeds thanks to its Choice Scarf. Hydro Pump is the strongest move it has, meaningfully hurting a wide range of Pokemon, and it punishes Ground-types such as Greak Tusk, Clodsire, and Garchomp that attempt to block Volt Switch. Rotom-W can outspeed the entire unboosted metagame with its Choice Scarf, allowing it to reliably hit Cinderace, Iron Moth, and Garganacl. Trick is essential to cripple walls that can recover from Rotom-W's attacks, like Toxapex and Tera Fairy Garganacl. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple threats such as Dragapult, Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Baxcalibur, especially since Choice Scarf Rotom-W outspeeds them. Will-O-Wisp is just as useful as Thunder Wave, disarming physical threats like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, Breloom, and Meowscarada. Tera Steel gives Rotom-W an immunity to Toxic from Clodsire and Toxapex, as well as a resistance to Meowscarada's Flower Trick, Breloom's Bullet Seed, Iron Valiant's Moonblast, and Dragonite's Extreme Speed. On top of this, Levitate makes Steel's Ground weakness into an immunity; notably, EdgeQuake can't hit Tera Steel Rotom-W neutrally. Alternatively, Tera Water takes a more offensive approach, boosting the power of Hydro Pump to 2HKO Gholdengo, and it can potentially OHKO physically defensive Garganacl and Clodsire.

Rotom-W sits comfortably on balance and bulky offense teams. It pairs well with defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Toxapex, and Amoonguss, which use their Grass resistances and/or recovery to sponge hits like Breloom's Bullet Seed, Meowscarada's Flower Trick, and Ting-Lu's Ruination. Rotom-W pressures entry hazard removers like Great Tusk, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Cinderace, which helps hazard setters. Great Tusk is a great example, since it also removes hazards to ease Rotom-W's pivoting. More offensive partners like Iron Valiant, Cinderace, and Dragapult love Rotom-W crippling bothersome walls like Ting-Lu and Amoonguss with Trick. In turn, they can effectively check Breloom, Meowscarada, Choice Specs Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Choice Specs Dragapult, which can all cause trouble for Rotom-W. When Rotom-W pivots against Corviknight, Dondozo, Toxapex, and Greninja as they switch out, frail attackers such as Meowscarada, Cinderace, and Iron Valiant can safely come in to pressure the incoming Amoonguss, opposing Rotom-W, and Gholdengo.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Rotom-W's Speed, which notably allows it to outpace Gholdengo, access to Volt Switch, and great typing make it an excellent pivot and revenge killer.

  • Trick: If using a Choice Item, Trick is seriously worth considering for its ability to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo. Make sure Rotom-W is a neutral nature that has had a Timid Mint used on it. This way, Rotom-W can eat any Berry without getting confused.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: When combined with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type lets Rotom-W take on Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon far more effectively.

  • Electric: Not only does the damage boost from Tera Electric come in handy, but it also removes any weaknesses Rotom-W has.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing back to its Ghost-type roots gives Rotom-W a vast array of immunities, helping against Dragonite and Great Tusk in particular. It also makes Shadow Ball viable for picking off Ghost-types with Choice Scarf.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-W outspeed major threats such as Dragapult and Meowscarada.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs tends to be safer to Trick than Choice Scarf, and it gives a big power boost.

  • Assault Vest: Increasing Rotom-W's special bulk gives it a far better matchup against foes like Flutter Mane and Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Rotom-W's Special Attack is part of what makes it an effective revenge killer if using a Choice Item.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: This spread sacrifices Rotom-W's revenge killing potential, but, in exchange, it makes it a better pivot, and the better bulk makes Rotom-W more suited to finding the right time to cripple a wall with Trick. It's also is the best spread to use on Assault Vest sets.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• With a great typing, ability, and good bulk, Rotom-W makes for an effective user of Nasty Plot.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: This move is essential for getting past Dragon-types like Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Even when not Terastallized, it's a decent coverage move.

  • Hydro Pump versus Substitute: Hydro Pump is by far Rotom-W's strongest STAB, but it can be worth sacrificing for Substitute, which lets Rotom-W effectively defeat most Garganacl and defensive Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Rotom-W can turn the tables on its Dragon-type adversaries.

Items

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Rotom-W easily set up on Hippowdon, and avoid getting put to sleep by Dondozo.

  • Sitrus Berry: If Sleep isn't a big issue, Rotom-W appreciates the burst recovery Sitrus Berry provides.

  • Covert Cloak: If using Hydro Pump, this is Rotom-W's best way around Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: Maximizing Speed with a Timid nature gives Rotom-W the jump on Gholdengo. If Gholdengo isn't an issue, a Modest nature will still outspeed Jolly Breloom.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: Rotom-W's good bulk can be maximized instead of outspeeding Breloom; this spread avoids the 2HKO from Timid Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Levitate and excellent status moves make Rotom-W a clean choice for a bulky pivot!

  • Foul Play: Foul Play is essential for hitting Baxcalibur hard, since it's immunity to burns would otherwise let it set up on Rotom-W.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Thunder Wave: Will-O-Wisp's ability to cripple top-tier physically offensive threats such as Dragonite, Garchomp, and Scizor as well as punish the otherwise problematic Iron Hands makes it the best support option. However, Thunder Wave does provide additional insurance against Baxcalibur and punishes special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Iron Moth.

  • Hydro Pump: Hydro Pump gives Rotom-W offensive presence against foes that don't care about the rest of the moveset, like Garganacl, Volcarona, and Skeledirge.

Other Options

  • Discharge: Giving Rotom-W an Electric STAB attack to better deal with Flying-types like Corviknight and Tera Flying Roaring Moon is useful, but it can be tricky to fit into the set.

  • Hex: If using Tera Ghost, Hex gives Rotom-W a much fiercer offensive kick than usual after inflicting status.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Rotom-W an incredible defensive typing, vastly improving its matchups against Pokemon that rely on Ground-type coverage such as Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Garchomp. It also provides a useful Freeze-Dry resistance against Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy guards against fearsome powerful Dragon-type and Fighting-type attacks that Rotom-W can have trouble handling (RC) and lets it use Tera Blast to hit special attacking Dragon-types like Dragapult and Hydreigon hard.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost offers Rotom-W a vast array of immunities with Levitate, enabling it to defeat certain Dragonite sets and do much better against Iron Hands and Iron Valiant when Rotom-W lacks Will-O-Wisp. Being a Ghost-type also prevents Rotom-W from getting trapped, letting it escape faster trappers without Volt Switch.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry will turn many powerful, unboosted attacks such as Dragonite's Outrage and Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush into 3HKOs.

  • Leftovers: If Sitrus Berry is already in use, Leftovers is a reasonable alternative.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Rotom-W is an excellent defensive pivot that can take on dangerous attackers such as Palafin, Scizor, and Iron Treads and generate momentum with Volt Switch. While Scald offers more PP and reliability, Steam Eruption OHKOes Great Tusk after Stealth Rock and improves Rotom-W's overall offensive presence. Will-O-Wisp hinders physical attackers more reliably than Scald. Alternatively, Apple Acid breaks down defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl, while Haze neutralizes slow setup sweepers such as Scizor and Freeze-Dry hits Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp super effectively. Roost provides consistent recovery, while Strength Sap makes Rotom-W more effective against physical attackers such as Great Tusk and Chien-Pao, but leaves it unable to recover against Gholdengo. The given Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed Jolly Azumarill and uninvested Great Tusk, but more Speed can be run to handle certain threats; 224 Speed outspeeds Palafin, while 240 Speed with a Timid nature outpaces Gholdengo. Tera Steel allows Rotom-W to more easily pivot into Toxapex and take on Dragon-types such as Garchomp. Alternatively, Tera Electric strengthens Volt Switch and makes Rotom-W less vulnerable to Salt Cure. Rotom-W appreciates partners that can pivot such as Ting-Lu, Slither Wing, and Corviknight. Physical walls like Garganacl and Skeledirge after Terastallizing can take on many of the physical attackers that Rotom-W cannot handle, such as Roaring Moon. Powerful offensive Pokemon such as Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant, and Iron Treads appreciate Rotom-W's ability to pivot them into battle.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Rotom-W is a stupendously effective pivot on teams because its great defensive profile allows it to check a laundry list of threats like Mega Swampert, Tornadus-T, and Mega Scizor. Volt Switch lets Rotom-W start the spin cycle, pivoting out on opposing threats that it lures in like Ferrothorn and Dragapult, helping to position teammates favorably. Hydro Pump is a fantastic complement to Volt Switch, leaving Ground-types like Great Tusk and Landorus-T out to dry. Will-O-Wisp neutralizes physical sweepers like Mega Scizor, Kingambit, and Dragonite, hampering their hopes to use Rotom-W as setup fodder. Pain Split provides Rotom-W longevity in conjunction with Leftovers, but Defog can be used for entry hazard control, as Rotom-W easily folds common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Despite this, Rotom-W struggles to remove entry hazards against offensive setters like Garchomp and often misses the recovery that Pain Split offers. Tera Ghost improves Rotom-W’s matchup against the likes of Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham while letting it spinblock against Great Tusk. Tera Steel gives Rotom-W a Toxic immunity and valuable resistances, improving its prospects against the likes of Kartana, Clodsire, and Toxapex. Strong wallberakers like Dragapult, Heatran, and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T all appreciate Rotom-W positioning them against walls like Ferrothorn, Gholdengo, and Dragonite. Iron Valiant likes Rotom-W luring out Dragon-types like Dragapult and Dragonite. Teammates such as Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor can check Grass-types for Rotom-W as well. Notably, Mega Scizor forms a great VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as Mega Scizor irons out threats that Rotom-W has trouble with like Kartana, Weavile, and Tapu Lele, while Rotom-W can deal with common Mega Scizor checks such as Zapdos and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Rotom-W functions as a shockingly potent pivot, as a lightning-quick Volt Switch allows it to reliably create big surges of momentum for teammates. Will-O-Wisp reliably chips down bulkier threats like Mega Scizor and Garchomp while also surprising faster physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny. Thunder Wave is an option that can pour a cold water onto a sea of speedy sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Kartana, slowing them down. Trick stifles walls like Ferrothorn and Gastrodon who could otherwise stem the tide of Rotom-W’s momentum. Choice Scarf Rotom-W should not be Terastalizing in most cases, but a Steel or Ghost typing can be situationally useful against prominent metagame forces such as Great Tusk and Tapu Lele. Other pivots such as Mega Scizor, Tornadus-T, and Victini can create formidable VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W. Victini in particular deals with Grass-types like Ferrothorn and Kartana, while Rotom-W can threaten physically defensive walls such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Strong wallbreakers like Heatran, Iron Valiant, and Mega Medicham pair swimmingly with Rotom-W, as they plow through common defensive staples such as Gastrodon and Ferrothorn and benefit from Rotom-W pivoting them into advantageous positions.

sets.name: Physically Defensive Pivot (Electric)
