battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Pivot Knight
sets.description:
• Corviknight's fantastic typing makes it one of the best pivots in the metagame; it easily gets dangerous teammates such as Hydreigon, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult in.

  • Brave Bird: Brave Bird's damage output generally justifies the recoil.

  • Body Press: Body Press deals much more damage to Kingambit and Electric-types such as Rotom-W but makes Dragapult and Flutter Mane a problem.

  • Rocky Helmet: This lets Corviknight wear down physical threats more quickly while pivoting.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight's defensive typing is fantastic, so don't Terastallize too hastily and lose to more threats.

  • Dragon: Dragon and Fairy weaknesses are devastating, but in the late-game, resisting Electric and Fire can give Corviknight new win conditions against old foes such as Rotom-W.

  • Flying: Boosting Brave Bird's damage output is nice, but the secret to the Flying Tera type is that Corviknight will no longer be vulnerable to Fissure while it uses Roost.

  • Grass: Grass improves matchups against Rotom-W and Breloom significantly.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor's ability to punish Flutter Mane for using Mystic Fire makes it the best ability choice on Corviknight.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's excellent bulk makes Pressure a good alternative for stalling out foes such as Dondozo.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Corviknight stands out as one of the best choices around for a defensive Steel-type, thanks to recovery and Body Press.

  • Taunt: This lets Corviknight effectively shut down slower defensive Pokemon, such as Dondozo.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head helps Corviknight check Mimikyu more easily, especially if not running Rocky Helmet. It also prevents Corviknight from being walled by Flutter Mane and Dragapult.

Tera Types

  • Corviknight has a fantastic defensive typing, so only Terastallize if you need to win certain matchups, especially since it becomes vulnerable to Toxic.

  • Flying: A Flying Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing even when using Roost, making it a more reliable check to Fissure users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Body Press is easier to sweep with, as long as troublesome Fairy-types such as Mimikyu are removed.

  • Grass: Tera Grass Corviknight not only handles Rotom-W better, but can set up on Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

  • Dragon: A Dragon Tera type lets Corviknight resist common attacks aimed at it, such as Electric- and Fire-type attacks. However, the new weaknesses to Fairy and Dragon make this a reactive Terastallization.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: The passive damage from Rocky Helmet against Mimikyu gives Corviknight a much easier time using Taunt over Iron Head.

  • Leftovers: Corviknight tends to stick around, so Leftovers recovery makes sense over a Berry.

Abilities

  • Mirror Armor: Mirror Armor means Flutter Mane can't use Msytic Fire without getting its Special Attack dropped.

  • Pressure: Corviknight's ability to take powerful, low PP moves such as Close Combat after Iron Defense makes Pressure a viable alternative.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• With Bulk Up giving an Attack boost, Corviknight is free from having to use Body Press for good damage output.

  • Taunt: This is highly recommended for shutting down Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is chosen for both reliable damage output and hitting Fairy-types hard.

  • Power Trip: Power Trip takes several boosts to get powerful, but it's Corviknight's best shot at dealing decent damage to Gholdengo, being able to break its Substitute after Bulk Up. It also makes Corviknight a powerful Baton Pass recipient when using Espathra.

  • Covert Cloak: This makes Corviknight immune to Salt Cure's residual damage, making Corviknight a good check to Garganacl.

  • Mirror Armor: In addition to punishing Flutter Mane for using Mystic Fire, Mirror Armor also protects Corviknight from rare uses of Intimidate and Charm.

Tera Types

  • Remember that most of Corviknight's good Tera types leave it vulnerable to Toxic, so Terastallize carefully.

  • Dark: While it doesn't help Corviknight much defensively, a Dark Tera type lets it 2HKO 4 HP Gholdengo with Power Trip after one use of Bulk Up.

  • Flying: This Tera type lets Corviknight retain its Flying typing while using Roost, meaning Fissure users such as Dondozo are much easier to handle.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type boosts Iron Head and removes Corviknight's Electric weakness, at the cost of making it vulnerable to Earthquake.

  • Dragon: Once Fairy- and Dragon-types are out of the way, the Dragon Tera type allows Corviknight to get around Electric- and Fire-type attacks.

  • Grass-type: A Grass Tera type is Corviknight's best way of setting up on Breloom and handling Rotom-W.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: With high Defense and a good defensive typing, Corviknight is a reliable physical wall that can switch into offensive threats like Kingambit and Dragonite, as well as remove entry hazards without being threatened by entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Well-Baked Body allows Corviknight to fearlessly switch into Fire-type attacks from Pokemon like Cinderace and Volcarona, while Intimidate and Fluffy make Corviknight a good switch-in to physical attackers like Quaquaval and Roaring Moon. Brave Bird lets Corviknight threaten Pokemon like Meowscarada, Body Press beats Kingambit, and Iron Head can be used to threaten Hatterene and Chien-Pao while still hitting Ghost-types. Corviknight also acts as a slow pivot with U-turn, allowing it to bring in offensive teammates like Dragonite and Polteageist safely. Corviknight struggles to hurt Steel-type Pokemon like Iron Treads and opposing Corviknight, so it appreciates teammates like Chi-Yu and Iron Moth that can take them out. Due to its middling Special Defense, Corviknight also appreciates teammates like Garganacl and Florges that can take special attacks.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Corviknight makes use of its good defensive typing and decent special bulk to serve as both a special pivot and a Defogger that doesn't fear common entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Well-Baked Body is great for checking Volcarona and Iron Moth, and Volt Absorb allows Corviknight to block Volt Switch from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Sandy Shocks. Brave Bird provides a solid STAB option, while Iron Head threatens Ice-types like Chien-Pao. U-turn and minimum Speed turn Corviknight into a slow pivot, allowing it to safely bring in frail Pokemon like Gengar and Ceruledge. Corviknight has difficulty against physical walls like Dondozo and Kingambit, so teammates like Sandy Shocks and Iron Moth that can handle them are necessary. Because Corviknight can't run multiple immunity abilities, a second specially defensive partner like Garganacl or Clodsire should be used to help cover its defensive weaknesses.

sets.name: Shell Smash (Rock)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Barraskewda is a devastating wallbreaker with a naturally high Speed tier to outpace the whole unboosted metagame, including fast threats like Chien-Pao and Kilowattrel. Close Combat pressures Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Desolate Land Chi-Yu and provides strong neutral coverage for Dondozo and Desolate Land Cinderace. Psychic Fangs and Drill Run cover foes such as Toxapex, Water Absorb Gengar, and Iron Moth; the latter's lesser power and accuracy is compensated for by hitting Desolate Land Ceruledge and OHKOing Cinderace. Aqua Jet revenge kills faster foes like boosted Volcarona and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks. Specially offensive pivots such as Iron Moth and Greninja can bring Barraskewda in safely on their switch-ins like Garganacl, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu for more wallbreaking opportunities. Late-game cleaners like Dragonite and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks love Barraskewda pressuring the opposition early on; Sandy Shocks threatens problematic bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex in return.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Thanks to its high offensive stats alongside Swift Swim, Choice Band Barraskewda is a premier wallbreaker, offensive pivot, late-game cleaner, and revenge killer on rain teams. Its blistering Speed tier allows it to nearly outpace the entire metagame under rain, including boosted foes like Dragon Dance Dragapult and Mega Swampert. Liquidation's Defense drop lets it potentially 2HKO Pokemon such as Dragapult and Pelipper, while Waterfall's flinches gives Barraskewda slightly better odds to muscle past the likes of Slowbro and Toxapex. Flip Turn keeps up momentum by providing free entry for its teammates while chipping down switch-ins like Dondozo and Tangrowth. Close Combat hits Water-resistant foes such as Ferrothorn, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados, and it provides strong neutral coverage against the likes of Tera Water Great Tusk, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Gastrodon. Aqua Jet prevents Barraskewda from being revenge killed by priority attacks like Kingambit and Mega Mawile's Sucker Punch and—if rain is not active—lets it pick off faster threats such as Sand Rush Excadrill and boosted Volcarona and Iron Valiant. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs pressures Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Water Absorb Clodsire better. Tera Water skyrockets Barraskewda's rain-boosted STAB moves further, potentially 2HKOing even Water-resistant Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Pelipper is a necessary teammate that spearheads rain teams by reliably summoning rain with Drizzle. Mega Swampert is a fantastic offensive partner that can overwhelm shared checks like Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Slowbro and appreciates Barraskewda's Flip Turn to bring it in safely on foes such as Toxapex, Dragapult, and Dragonite. Tornadus-T and Ferrothorn are rain team staples that support Barraskewda with Knock Off, crippling walls such as Rotom-W and opposing Ferrothorn; Ferrothorn in particular helps threaten Gastrodon with Power Whip and sets entry hazards to soften up foes. The aforementioned Pelipper and Tornadus-T also provide Defog support for Barraskewda to pivot throughout the game unperturbed, bring it in safely via U-turn, and threatens problematic Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to insane levels, being able to outright OHKO specially defensive Hippowdon and Gastrodon after only one layer of Spikes.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to insane levels, OHKOing Hippowdon and doing massive damage to Gastrodon and Scream Tail.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Normal boosts the power of Boomburst to make up for the decreased power, being able to still have great odds to OHKO Hippowdon after 1 layer of Spikes and 2HKO Gastrodon with no entry hazards on the field.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: Tera Blast in conjunction with Tera Fighting gives Polteageist the necessary coverage to break past Dark-types like Tyranitar, Bisharp, and Iron Jugulis that wall it otherwise. Tera Fighting also allows Polteageist to resist Sucker Punch from Bisharp and Accelrock from Lycanroc-D as well as take neutral damage from Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Cinderace that can break through opposing walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind Hatterene is an excellent option on balance teams to deny entry hazards from being set up. With Magic Bounce, it can switch into and reflect entry hazards from Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Blissey. From there, it can begin setting up Calm Mind to pose a greater threat itself and overwhelm the opponent's defensive answers to it. Draining Kiss acts as pseudo-recovery and can help Hatterene heal off damage it's taken from Pokemon such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk. Psyshock allows Hatterene to deal high damage to special walls such as Blissey and Clodsire and win potential setup wars against other Hatterene and Volcarona. Stored Power fulfills a similar role to Psyshock in enabling Hatterene to break through special walls and other Calm Mind users and can also help Hatterene defeat various Unaware Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Dondozo, but it requires Hatterene to set up multiple Calm Minds before it becomes truly potent. Mystical Fire deals high damage to many of Hatterene's common switch-ins such as Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Kingambit and has the nice bonus of lowering the target's Special Attack, which is particularly useful against Gholdengo that aren't running Covert Cloak. Nuzzle is another option to cripple switch-ins with paralysis, which can act as useful speed control for Hatterene's teammates. Tera Water nullifies all of Hatterene's weaknesses, which can grant it more opportunities to use Calm Mind against its checks such as Gholdengo, while Tera Fire can similarly neutralize all of Hatterene's weaknesses and comes with additional benefits such as boosting the damage of its Mystical Fire and letting it check Iron Valiant and Volcarona better. However, Tera Fire also comes with notable downsides, namely giving Hatterene a weakness to Ground-type moves and Stealth Rock, which can hinder its matchups against common entry hazard setters. The EV spread allows Hatterene to move reliably switch into physical attacks from common entry hazard setters while also outspeeding Toxapex and Garganacl.

Hatterene's ability to discourage the use of entry hazards will be appreciated by almost any team. Pokemon vulnerable to entry hazards and those that frequently pivot in and out of battle such as Meowscarada, Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Dragapult enjoy Hatterene's support. Entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk and Corviknight are also good partners, as Hatterene's presence can ease the burden placed on them to remove entry hazards and grants the team greater flexibility in dealing with entry hazard setters. Furthermore, while Hatterene can switch into entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk, it can be worn down quickly from their repeated Ground-type attacks. Great Tusk and Corviknight can reduce Hatterene's need to switch in as often by acting as alternative switch-ins. Due to relying on Leftovers and Draining Kiss for recovery, Hatterene can struggle to stay healthy, particularly if it loses its Leftovers to Knock Off or is hit by Salt Cure, so it is recommended to have teammates that can switch into these moves. Corviknight can switch into Knock Off from hazard setters such as Meowscarada and Great Tusk, while Covert Cloak Gholdengo can neutralize Salt Cure. Pokemon holding Rocky Helmet such as Corviknight can be troublesome for Hatterene, as they will wear Hatterene down when it uses Nuzzle or Draining Kiss. Covert Cloak users, especially Gholdengo, are similarly irritating for Hatterene due to nullifying the secondary effect of its Nuzzle or Mystical Fire. Knock Off support from Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and Iron Valiant is thus appreciated to remove these items from the opponent's Pokemon. Hatterene's weakness to Steel- and Ghost-type attacks can be exploited by strong attackers such as Gholdengo, Dragapult, and Kingambit. Kingambit and Tera Water Garganacl can reliably switch into Gholdengo and Dragapult, while Great Tusk and Dondozo can counter Kingambit.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Calm Mind (Psychic)
sets.description:
With its good bulk, Calm Mind, Magic Bounce, and secondary Fairy typing, Hatterene serves as a strong wincon versus types such as Dark and Dragon that otherwise threaten Psychic-type teams. Psyshock is Hatterene’s hardest-hitting move against special walls such as Dragalge and Clodsire. Draining Kiss provides useful coverage against Dark- and Dragon-types and meaningful recovery. Mystical Fire hits Steel-types that otherwise stonewall Hatterene, while Nuzzle supports its teammates by spreading paralysis. The EV spread outspeeds Toxapex which could otherwise clear Calm Mind boosts Hatterene with Haze.

Hatterene struggles with breaking through Pokemon that can handle its STAB attacks and coverage, with Steel-types being a notable example. Because of this, Armarouge is a wonderful partner for Hatterene, as it can pressure the aforementioned Steel-types while also not having to worry about entry hazards due to Hatterene's Magic Bounce. Espathra forms a strong offensive core with Hatterene that can threaten a wide range of types such as Water, Dragon, and Ground once Hatterene breaks down Espathra’s checks. This core can be enabled further by setting up dual screens with Scream Tail. Indeedee and Gallade ease pressure from Ghost- and Dark-types, respectively, while the former's Psychic Surge can power up Hatterene's Psyshock, and the latter can check Steel-types for Hatterene thanks to its strong Fighting STAB attacks.

sets.name: Calm Mind (Fairy)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2023.overview:
• Hatterene is an offensive Trick Room setter that loves to take advantage of all the Dark- and Dragon-type Pokemon running around the metagame, such as Murkrow, Hydreigon, and Garchomp.

  • Hatterene needs assistance to get started. Fake Out support from Hariyama or Mold Breaker Tinkaton can stop faster Pokemon who would otherwise threaten a KO before Trick Room. Redirectors such as Amoonguss all but ensure that Trick Room gets set up. Indeedee-F in particular facilitates Hatterene very well, as it can use Trick Room, set up Psychic Terrain to protect against priority, and redirect attacks with Follow Me.

  • Additional spread damage from the likes of Torkoal, Armarouge, and Sylveon can overwhelm entire teams alongside Hatterene and close out a game. Armarouge additionally helps dissuade opposing Torkoal from utilizing Trick Room turns itself, as it can block spread moves with Wide Guard.

  • Magic Bounce renders Hatterene immune to most forms of disruption such as Taunt from Murkrow or Talonflame and Spore from Amoonguss.

  • Its low HP and middling physical bulk makes Hatterene vulnerable to most strong or super effective physical attacks. Strong priority moves, such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Kingambit's Sucker Punch, are problematic unless Hatterene has Psychic Terrain or Quick Guard support. Hatterene also struggles to get started against many common Ghost-types due to its low Speed and relative frailty. Gengar can threaten to either OHKO it with a STAB move or take away Hatterene's speed control with Imprison.

sets.name: Trick Room Sweeper
sets.description:
• Mystical Fire lets Hatterene deal decent damage to Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit, which it would otherwise fail to hit effectively.

  • Covert Cloak renders Hatterene immune to the secondary effects of moves like Snarl and Fake Out, which, combined with Magic Bounce, greatly limits the ways the opponent can deal with it. Life Orb makes Hatterene a far more threatening sweeper but noticeably hinders its longevity, leaving it more vulnerable to revenge killing from powerful priority moves.

  • Tera Fire lets Hatterene turn the tables on Steel-types, such as Gholdengo looking for a quick KO before it sets up Trick Room. Tera Fairy removes Hatterene's weakness to Ghost and makes Dazzling Gleam hit harder. Tera Steel gives Hatterene a slew of resistances and allows it to surprise Fairy-types like Sylveon with a super effective Tera Blast. Steel-type Tera Blast also OHKOes Garganacl, which would otherwise wall it endlessly. Tera Psychic gives Hatterene a boosted STAB option that isn't resisted by Fire-types.

  • Shadow Ball is a niche option to cover common Ghost- and Psychic-types. After You allows Hatterene to support Pokemon with higher Speed during Trick Room, such as Meowscarada and Gengar. Focus Sash is an option if Hatterene doesn't run a defensive Tera type.

sets.name: Triage
sets.description: Hatterene is a decent Triage user that can successfully check dangerous attackers like Aerilate Dragonite, Greninja, and most Chien-Pao. Calm Mind and its good bulk allow it to set up and beat bulkier foes as well. Psyshock provides effectively mixed coverage, most notably beating Blissey. For the last moveslot, Mystical Fire beats non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight, Nuzzle cripples switch-ins like Kingambit, and Giga Drain hits Garganacl hard while providing more recovery and priority. Other sweepers benefit greatly from the dents placed by Hatterene, such as Shell Smash Polteageist and Dragonite. Hatterene is weak to mainly priority-immune Chien-Pao and Shell Smash Polteageist. Kingambit, with or without RegenVest, is a reliable check to Polteageist. Corviknight is a solid partner, as it provides entry hazard removal and pivoting to safely bring Hatterene in. Hatterene also struggles with Fire-type Pokemon, making teammates like Garchomp and Well-Baked Body Kingambit naturally good partners.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Grimmsnarl is a prominent part of Ubers hyper offense teams as the most reliable dual screens setter in the tier.
  • Taunt stops would-be setup sweepers, prevents entry hazards from Pokemon like Froslass and Glimmora, and stops Corviknight from using Defog.
  • Play Rough is mandatory to deal decent damage to one of the most common Pokemon in the tier in Ting-Lu, which is immune to Taunt and can use Grimmsnarl as setup bait for Spikes, damage it greatly with Ruination, and phaze any incoming Pokemon with Whirlwind. In a pinch, Play Rough also does good damage to Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Tera Ghost is chosen to prevent Great Tusk and Iron Treads from using Rapid Spin, while Tera Steel provides useful resistances, most notably to Fairy-type attacks.
  • Grimmsnarl works well when paired with a suicide lead such as Froslass or Glimmora, as they can set up Spikes and Toxic Spikes, thereby giving any setup sweepers a much easier time sweeping.
  • Dual screens support gives Pokemon such as Calm Mind Miraidon, Swords Dance Koraidon, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao an easier time setting up and makes revenge killing them significantly harder.
  • Iron Moth is a notable teammate for being a strong setup sweeper that can also absorb Toxic Spikes.

sets.name: Dual Screens (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Grimmsnarl to survive a Swords of Ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite, then invests the remaining EVs into Special Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• With Prankster and the movepool to use it, Grimmsnarl is one of the best dual screens setters, as it is useful for setting up dangerous sweepers such as Dragonite or Iron Valiant.

  • Parting Shot: Parting Shot is not only useful for dropping stats, but the pivoting action can let Grimmsnarl come in later to set up screens if it's in a bad matchup.

  • Thunder Wave: This is a reasonable alternative for crippling fast foes that may be problematic for sweeps.

  • Taunt: Taunt shuts down phazers and opposing Taunts that could stop the dual screens from being set up.

  • Spirit Break versus Foul Play: Hitting foes like Great Tusk and Roaring Moon makes Spirit Break a good offensive move. Alternatively, Foul Play is notable for breaking Gholdengo's Substitute and punishing physical setup sweepers.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Grimmsnarl should almost never Terastallize, since it's trying to support sweepers rather than deal serious damage on its own. Still, a Grass Tera type is a reasonable choice for blocking Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Normal)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Possessing OU's highest unboosted Speed tier makes Choice Specs Dragapult a very remarkable special wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. It outspeeds and threatens common offensive threats like Cinderace, Iron Moth, and even boosted foes like Adamant Dragonite after a Dragon Dance. Moreover, it's immune or resistant to common priority attacks like the aforementioned Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Breloom's Mach Punch, and Slither Wing's First Impression, which makes it much harder to revenge kill. It is also able to switch into and check Rotom-W. A coverage move in either Flamethrower or Thunder lets Dragapult nail Corviknight, with the former also hitting other Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads, while the latter pressures Toxapex and Tera Water Garganacl. Infiltrator allows Dragapult to bypass Grimmsnarl's dual screens, Orthworm's Shed Tail, and Substitute users like Gholdengo, which gives it an edge against hyper offense teams. Tera Ghost maintains an immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed and strengthens Shadow Ball—its most spammable attack—notably guaranteeing the 2HKO on Corviknight and Assault Vest Iron Treads after Terastallizing. Tera Fairy prevents Dragapult from being picked off by opposing Dragapult and Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Meowscarada. Finally, Tera Dragon turns Draco Meteor into an even more powerful nuke. This takes advantage of the lack of prominent bulky Steel- and Fairy-types in the metagame, notably chunking answers to Ghost-types like Purifying Salt Garganacl and Ting-Lu and 2HKOing Unaware Clodsire.

Choice Specs Dragapult fits perfectly on bulky offense and VoltTurn teams. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Great Tusk appreciate Dragapult's U-turn bringing them in safely, and they are able to pressure its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Blissey, and Garganacl. Entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Great Tusk allow Dragapult to pivot throughout the game unperturbed; the former can also pivot it in safely via U-turn, letting it threaten Gholdengo, which tends to switch into Corviknight to block its Defog. Furthermore, Corviknight and Great Tusk provide the necessary defensive backbone to switch into boosted threats such as Roaring Moon, as well as revenge kill attempts from Sucker Punch users like Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Gholdengo forms a Ghost spam core with Dragapult, as it can overwhelm a shared check in Ting-Lu, use non-Calm Mind Blissey as setup fodder, and either cripple Tera Water Garganacl with Trick or straight up dent Tera Fairy variants. Entry hazards from Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Garganacl can quickly put foes into Dragapult's KO range, especially as it tends to force a lot of switches; in return, Dragapult spinblocks foes like Great Tusk and Iron Treads in a pinch. Setup sweepers like Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao appreciate Dragapult wallbreaking early-game for them to clean up late-game easily.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Dragapult utilizes its near-unresisted STAB moves, its blistering Speed stat, and its excellent Attack stat to function as a strong physical wallbreaker. The choice for the second move depends on what Tera type Dragapult chooses. Tera Dragon Dragapult uses Phantom Force for a Ghost-type STAB move, but Tera Ghost uses Tera Blast, since, unlike Phantom Force, it is not a two-turn move. Sucker Punch allows Dragapult to revenge kill weakened sweepers such as opposing Dragapult, as well as Iron Moth and Tera Flying Roaring Moon after some chip damage. However, be careful when using Sucker Punch, since opponents can predict it and set up. An Adamant nature gives Dragapult extra wallbreaking power, at the cost of being outsped by threats like Chien-Pao. Alternatively, a Jolly nature allows Dragapult to outspeed the entirety of the unboosted metagame. With Tera Dragon, Dragapult's Dragon Darts becomes harder to switch into; it 2HKOes walls Dragapult normally struggles with such as Ting-Lu. Tera Dragon Dragapult is also less susceptible to Sucker Punch, albeit at the cost of losing its immunity to Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

Iron Valiant is a fantastic partner, since it's able to check Dark-types such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu. Hazard removal from Pokemon like Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Corviknight make for good partners, since Dragapult's lack of longevity makes it difficult to switch in when hazards are up. Great Tusk and Corviknight are able to beat both Scizor and opposing Great Tusk, while Cinderace can threaten bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight. Dragapult benefits from entry hazards from the likes of Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl, since it can more effectively wallbreak with entry hazards up. Other pivots such as Scizor and Rotom-W appreciate that Dragapult's U-turn can bring them in. In return, Scizor can revenge kill Ice-types such as Chien-Pao, while Rotom-W can check both Corviknight and defensive Great Tusk. Paralysis support from Rotom-W can shutdown offensive Pokemon like opposing Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Lastly, Gholdengo makes for a good teammate, since it can spinblock and deny Defog and can help Dragapult overwhelm shared checks like Kingambit and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Unlike its more offensively oriented Choice item sets, this Dragapult set goes for a more multifunctional approach. Dragapult's unmatched Speed tier, in conjunction with STAB Dragon Darts, allows it to snipe key offensive threats such as Roaring Moon, Iron Moth, and Cinderace with some prior chip damage. This often means that Dragapult will force a lot of switches which can be capitalized on with Will-O-Wisp to spread status and power up Hex. Will-O-Wisp also allows Dragapult to avoid Sucker Punch, which can come in handy against Cinderace, Kingambit, and Meowscarada. With a burn and Stealth Rock up, Hex 2HKOs Defensive Corviknight, Amoonguss, and Dondozo, allowing Dragapult to pick apart balanced cores. Finally, U-Turn rounds out the set, letting Dragapult keep momentum up even against hard counters like Ting-Lu and Garganacl. 252 Speed EVs with a Hasty nature ensure that Dragapult outspeeds the entire unboosted tier. 76 Attack EVs ensure an OHKO on Roaring Moon with Dragon Darts, while the rest of the EVs are put into Special Attack. Although Dragapult does not typically find itself needing to Terastallize very often, Ghost is most commonly used to power up Hex even further. For example, Tera Ghost Hex does a minimum of 84% to a burnt Defensive Great Tusk. In a pinch however, Terastallization can be used defensively to avoid OHKOs like from Chien-Pao's Ice Shard.

Because of the amount of utility it provides, Dragapult appreciates plentiful chip damage from its teammates, as it lacks immediate power. All forms of entry hazards are greatly appreciated due to Dragapult's ability to force out the opponent, so entry hazard setters like Garganacl, Great Tusk, Glimmora and Ting-Lu form good teammates. Stealth Rock is particularly important since it secures important 2HKOs with Hex. Among the entry hazard setters, Garganacl has fantastic synergy with Dragapult, as it is able to set up Stealth Rock while also chipping down foes with Salt Cure. Partners that can spread status such as Rotom-W and Skeledirge are also excellent teammates. Since Ting-Lu and Garganacl stonewall this set, teammates that scare them out such as Offensive Great Tusk and Banded Meowscarada are great partners. Tera Flying Covert Cloak Gholdengo forms a particularly potent Ghost spam core with Dragapult, as it can turn common counters to Dragapult such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Garganacl into setup fodder. Physical sweepers like Chien-Pao and Kingambit appreciate having their counters like Corviknight and Great Tusk crippled with burns and have solid type synergy with Dragapult. Due to this set being most potent in the mid- to late-game, it's more at home in teams with solid defensive backbones that can sponge hits. Defensive pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Hatterene, Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Amoonguss can all soak damage for Dragapult from common checks like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit while setting up entry hazards, spreading status, or dealing chip damage, allowing Dragapult to clean up later in the game.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs (Dragon)
sets.description:
As the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the Monotype metagame, Choice Specs Dragapult is an excellent offensive threat that deals with Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Greninja for Dragon teams. Draco Meteor and Shadow Ball are helpful against a variety of types lacking the necessary immunities and can be used to decimate types such as Dark, Flying, Fairy, and Ghost. Flamethrower roasts Steel-types such as Corviknight and Scizor without the risk of getting stalled by Pressure, and Thunderbolt nails Toxapex and Dondozo and cleans Water teams late-game. Alternatively, U-turn brings in team mates like Baxcalibur, Garchomp, and Hydreigon, which take advantage of common switch-ins such as Ting Lu, Clodsire, and Kingambit. Infiltrator lets Dragapult bypass dual screens, which is sorely needed to properly deal with Flutter Mane.

Since Dragapult excels at cleaning teams with its natural speed, wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Hydreigon, Baxcalibur, and Choice Band Haxorus, as well as entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Dragalge are excellent teammates. Dragonite loves Dragapult's ability to wear down or outright remove Steel-, Water-, and Ghost-types such as Klefki, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, allowing it to clean up types such as Fairy, Water, and Fire with a Dragon Dance or Choice Band set. Choice Scarf users like Baxcalibur, Hydreigon, and Roaring Moon are appreciated, as these deal with opposing Choice Scarf users such as Gallade and Gholdengo, which revenge kill Dragapult with ease. Cyclizar provides entry hazard removal and can pass a Shed Tail to Dragapult, allowing it to get in the field safely.

sets.name: Dragon Dance (Ghost)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Dragapult's incredible Speed makes it a very effective hit-and-run attacker.

  • Phantom Force: This is risky due to the two turns making Dragapult vulnerable to Normal-types and surprise Terastallization, but lack of many strong Ghost-resistant foes makes Phantom Force an effective late-game cleaning move.

  • Shadow Ball: With a Naive nature, Shadow Ball is an easy way to 2HKO Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, and incoming Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Dragon and Ghost: Terastallizing into either of Dragapult's STAB types makes it even more difficult to wall, with Ghost being notable for letting Dragapult use a less risky STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives a valuable Fairy-type resistance and is a more powerful tool against Steel-types at the cost of a Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's Dragon-type immunity can help win Tera wars against foes like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting vastly improves Dragapult's match-up against Kingambit and Choice Scarf Meowscarada.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band guarantees that Breloom is OHKOed through its Focus Sash with Dragon Darts.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Sucker Punch a less risky option.

  • Choice Scarf: This may seem like overkill, but Choice Scarf gives Dragapult the edge over Booster Energy users such as Iron Bundle, Roaring Moon, and Flutter Mane, and other Choice Scarf foes such Gholdengo.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• Despite Dragapult's insane Speed stat, Dragon Dance insulates it from popular revenge killers such as Booster Energy Iron Bundle and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, making it a great sweeper.

  • Phantom Force: Phantom Force's drawback can be an issue when Normal-types are potentially around, but its great coverage still makes it good way to clean teams.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: Not only does this make Dragon Darts difficult to wall, but it clinches a OHKO on Breloom regardless of the item.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy makes setting up against Great Tusk and Dragon-types much more feasible.

  • Fire: Not only does this make Fairy-types easier to deal with, but it can help Dragapult sweep through defensive Steel-types such as Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Steel: Steel covers a lot of Dragapult's former weaknesses, letting it set up on new foes such as Mimikyu.

  • Ghost: Terastallizing into a Ghost-type gives Dragapult the option for a much more reliable STAB move in Tera Blast, at the cost of not helping it set up against new threats.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is far less likely to stop Dragapult's sweep.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• Despite the lower offensive stat, the higher base power of Dragapult's special attacks makes it a serious threat.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is the recommended coverage move for hitting Corviknight and Dondozo hard.

  • U-turn: Even though it's weak, U-turn is a reasonable consideration for pivoting and breaking Mimikyu's Disguise.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: The stronger Shadow Ball makes this Dragapult difficult to wall outside of Normal-types and Ghost resistant foes such as Garganacl.

  • Fire: The Fairy-type resistance and powerful Flamethrower can make the Stealth Rock weakness worth it.

  • Fighting: The resistance to Sucker Punch Tera Fighting provides can be key in stopping Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Dragapult's match-up against other Dragon-types and Great Tusk.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon makes Draco Meteor nearly impossible to wall without a resistance.

sets.name: Bulky Status
sets.description:
• With usable bulk bolstered by Will-O-Wisp, this Dragapult can severely punish its weaker offensive checks.

  • Disable and Substitute: Disable makes Dragapult rely on Will-O-Wisp for Normal-types, but when combined with Substitute, it defeats Choice-locked foes and those that rely on one specific move to beat Dragapult.

  • Draco Meteor: Draco Meteor improves Dragapult against other Dragon-types, particularly Hydreigon and itself.

  • Flamethrower: This lets Dragapult deal decent unconditional damage to Steel-types, with Kingambit being the biggest target.

  • Dragon Darts: With a Naive nature, Dragon Darts gives Dragapult a consequence-free Dragon-type attack and decent mixed attacking potential.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Dragapult preforms better against most Dragon-types and Knock Off users such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant.

  • Steel: Steel Tera type is great for general defense and Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Mimikyu.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Dragapult's high Speed combined with Reflect and Light Screen make it an effective dual screens lead.

  • Curse: Curse reduces Dragapult's HP to get it off the field quickly once it has set up screens. It also forces opponents to use recovery moves or switch out, allowing Dragapult's teammates to get in and set up safely. Curse is Dragapult’s best option to bypass Substitute, Protect, and Mimikyu.

  • Shadow Ball: This breaks Focus Sash, hits Ghosts like Gholdengo and opposing Dragapult that normally threaten it, and breaks Mimikyu's Disguise. Notably Gholdengo stops Curse with Good as Gold, making Dragapult totally helpless against it if it does not carry Shadow Ball.

  • Dragon Darts: Dragon Darts can be used for more power to make Dragapult more self-sufficient when it has to stay on the field, and breaks Focus Sash as well. Its dual-hit nature makes it bypass most Substitutes.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Will-O-Wisp can be used to cripple physical attackers. In tandem with Reflect, this can be a potent strategy to allow the next Pokemon to set up nearly risk-free.

Tera Types

  • Ghost / Dragon: Dragapult, as a screens supporter, should not normally Terastallize, but if you are in a bad spot, Ghost and Dragon power up its STAB move of choice.

  • Steel: A defensive typing like Steel can allow Dragapult to survive certain moves like Iron Bundle's Ice Beam, boosted Cloyster's Icicle Spear, and boosted Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and retaliate.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type is useful for enemy Infiltrator Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

Items

  • Focus Sash: While Light Clay is standard, Focus Sash nearly guarantees setting at least one screen without having to Terastallize, in the event Dragapult leads off against Choice Scarf users like Gholdengo, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance Dragapult is one of the most dangerous setup sweepers in the tier due to its blazing Speed and immense power. After a Dragon Dance, Dragapult outspeeds all Choice Scarf and Booster Energy users, such as Kartana, Greninja, and Iron Valiant, making it extremely hard to stop if it sets up successfully. Ghostium Z-powered Phantom Force enables a boosted Dragapult to blast through bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Heatran after slight chip damage. Dragapult's typing gives it opportunities to switch in and set up against certain Pokemon such as Volcarona, non-Ice Spinner Dragonite, and Urshifu-R locked into a Fighting-type move. Substitute is the preferred option in the last moveslot to ease prediction and facilitate setup while also avoiding priority. Substitute also allows Dragapult to play mind games with Kingambit. Fire Blast is another option that allows Dragapult to deal massive damage to physically defensive Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor, both of which can survive a boosted Never-Ending Nightmare at full health. Clear Body is the preferred ability to avoid stat drops from Intimidate, but Infiltrator can also be used to improve the matchup against dual screens and Shed Tail teams. A Jolly nature lets Dragapult outspeed Mega Lopunny and Tapu Koko prior to setting up. Dragon Dance Dragapult fits best on offensive teams, where it can function as a potent late-game cleaner with its Z-Move. Entry hazard support from Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Glimmora can help chip bulky foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit into range of Dragapult's attacks. Gholdengo can block attempts to remove entry hazards, as well as pressure certain physical walls that give Dragapult a hard time, such as Ferrothorn. Dragapult can struggle with bulky physical walls such as Dondozo, Garganacl, and post-Tera Skeledirge, so powerful special wallbreakers that can take advantage of these Pokemon, such as Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y, are greatly appreciated. Tapu Lele also provides Psychic Terrain, which thwarts revenge killing attempts from priority moves. A late-game cleaner such as Dragonite or Booster Energy Iron Valiant can take advantage of the holes Dragapult left behind in the enemy defensive core.

sets.name: Hex
sets.description: Despite Hex Dragapult's lack of immediate offensive presence, it can be a very annoying threat; it excels in getting around many of Dragapult's normal checks and counters, pivoting to dangerous teammates, and spreading status. Against common checks like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Toxapex, it can bring in Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, and Tapu Koko, respectively, to punish the opponent. Will-O-Wisp boosts Hex to monstrous levels and threatens to pacify physical attackers like Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Kingambit. Dragon Darts is a strong physical move to better hit special walls like Clodsire, forcing it to recover lest Dragapult's teammates like Iron Valiant break through. With Tera Ghost, it can muscle through specially defensive Toxapex after burn and entry hazard damage with Hex, though Tera Fairy helps it tank hits from opposing Dragapult and Dark-type moves like Pursuit, and it can still check Zamazenta. Infiltrator allows it to check threats behind Substitutes, most notably Iron Defense Zamazenta and Shed Tail receivers like Dragonite. Dragapult struggles to break through Heatran, so Pokemon that can pressure it such as Garchomp and Rotom-W are great partners. It also must be careful around Pursuit trappers like Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, as even after a burn they heavily chip it; teammates like Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Great Tusk are thus mandatory to threaten said trappers. Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y very much appreciate Dragapult crippling and weakening Kingambit and Tyranitar, respectively, as this aids in the process of removing them. In return, Dragapult can clean up the opposing team after its checks are gone. Pivots like Rotom-W and Corviknight bring Dragapult in, with the former checking Heatran and forming a nice VoltTurn core with it, and the latter tanking Dragon- and Fairy-type moves for it. Entry hazards and Knock Off from the likes of Ferrothorn and Great Tusk weaken the opposition for Dragapult to clean, notably its checks like Toxapex and Clodsire.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Dragapult is a menacing wallbreaker, being able to threaten many teams with its STAB Shadow Ball and Draco Meteor. The former in particular is very spammable, as only a limited pool of Pokemon can switch into it. U-turn takes advantage of this limited pool, pressuring Shadow Ball switch-ins like Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar while bringing in teammates such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Flamethrower hits Kingambit for massive damage, while Hydro Pump helps against Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu. Finally, Thunder pressures would-be checks, such as Toxapex. Ghost is the best Tera type for Dragapult, as it propels its Shadow Ball to a near-unstoppable level, making it even more spammable. Dragon boosts Draco Meteor's damage while making Dragapult less susceptible to Pursuit, while Tera Fairy purely helps it defensively: not only does it not fear Pursuit, but it's also not weak to Ice Shard or Sucker Punch from Weavile and Kingambit, respectively. Finally, it gives Dragapult a Dragon immunity, which allows you to beat Dragon Dance Dragapult after it burns the Z-Move. Dragapult must be wary of Pursuit from Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit, as they can both shrug off multiple Shadow Balls and remove it from the game. However, it can pivot around its checks, so Pokemon that can take advantage of and remove them make great partners, such as Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant. The latter two also share checks with Dragapult, like Clodsire and Toxapex, meaning they can overwhelm these checks. Dragapult also greatly appreciates Knock Off support from Tornadus-T, Weavile, or Ferrothorn, as its checks such as Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Garganacl all rely a lot on their items. Finally, since checks such as the aforementioned Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit are very susceptible to Spikes, Dragapult appreciates its setters such as Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Meowscarada is the fastest Spiker in the metagame that also provides further utility, making it a very potent dedicated lead. Moreover, its immunity to Prankster Taunt from Grimmsnarl, another common lead, lets Meowscarada get the leg up against opposing offensive teams. Taunt in conjunction with its insane Speed tier allows Meowscarada to shut down opposing entry hazard setters and removers like Garchomp, Glimmora, Iron Moth, and Corviknight, annoy defensive Pokemon like Clodsire and Toxapex, and prevent foes such as Volcarona, Kingambit, and Dragonite from using it as setup fodder. Aside from threatening Grass-resistant Pokemon like Dragapult, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo, Knock Off's utility allows Meowscarada to soften up and cripple defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and Toxapex, and it works well with Spikes by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Amoonguss, Clodsire, and Scizor. Even with Meowscarada's middling Special Attack, Leaf Storm boosted by Overgrow can cleanly OHKO defensive Great Tusk, one of the metagame's most common entry hazard removers. Focus Sash guarantees that Meowscarada can set at least one layer of Spikes and safely puts Meowscarada into Overgrow range. Tera Ghost can be used in a pinch to spinblock Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Torkoal.

Meowscarada excels at setting up the tempo for hyper offense teams. Offensive Stealth Rock setters like Garchomp and Great Tusk can stack entry hazards to put even more pressure on the opposing team, with mixed Garchomp threatening Corviknight from using Defog; in return, Meowscarada's Knock Off removes Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Dragonite and Volcarona to make them susceptible to Stealth Rock. By stacking entry hazards, Gholdengo becomes a near-mandatory teammate to prevent every attempt of hazard removal; Gholdengo also takes advantage of entry hazards itself to pressure checks like Toxapex and Clodsire, which makes Nasty Plot variants particularly difficult to deal with. Setup sweepers commonly found on hyper offense teams such as Dragonite, Kingambit, Baxcalibur, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth appreciate Spikes chipping down Pokemon like Dondozo, Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Clodsire. Furthermore, they enjoy Meowscarada crippling defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Amoonguss with Knock Off, with Dragonite and Kingambit in particular also appreciating Meowscarada luring in and dealing with Great Tusk.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Grass)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: CRITTY CAT
sets.description:
• With its good Attack, Speed, and access to Flower Trick and Knock Off, Meowscarada is a potent cleaner that is also hard to switch into.

  • Flower Trick: With its guaranteed critical hit, Flower Trick is a dangerous cleaning move once resistances to it have been sufficiently chipped.

  • Trick: Trick can help Choice-locked sets incapacitate an annoying wall, such as Dondozo or Amoonguss, by locking them into a single move. Make sure to use a neutral nature and use a Jolly Mint on Meowscarada, so it won't get confused by eating any Berry after Trick.

  • Low Kick: Low Kick OHKOs Hydreigon, Roaring Moon, and Kingambit if using Protean.

Abilities

  • Protean: Protean’s type-shifting allows Meowscarada to make the most of its colorful movepool, particularly on Choice-locked sets, where the limitation to only changing types once is effectively nullified.

  • Overgrow: If you intend to make use of a Tera type other than Grass or switch moves often, Overgrow is worth considering, as it allows Meowscarada more flexibility with its moves by not changing type and removing STAB from Flower Trick or Knock Off.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band boosted Meowscarada hits incredibly hard, and with its naturally high Speed it can serve as a cleaner and a potential wallbreaker.

  • Choice Scarf: With the Speed offered via Choice Scarf, Meowscarada can threaten otherwise faster foes, such as Dragapult, potentially putting more pressure on offensive teams.

Tera Types

  • Grass: While Terastallizing does override Protean, Tera Grass Meowscarada can be used to power through teams ill-prepared for it. Dual screens teams in particular are especially vulnerable to the sheer power of Choice Band-boosted Tera Grass Flower Trick.

sets.name: Focus Sash
sets.description:
• With its good Speed and wide movepool, Meowscarada makes for a potent lead.

  • Sucker Punch: Sucker Punch allows Meowscarada to better handle foes such as Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Toxic Spikes: Toxic Spikes’s forced passive damage is a great asset for the fast-paced teams Meowscarada generally finds itself on.

  • Taunt: Thanks to its good Speed, Meowscarada makes particularly excellent use of Taunt, shutting down other entry hazard leads such as Garchomp and Hippowdon.

  • Play Rough: This provides good coverage for Fighting- and Dragon-types that might otherwise pose issues, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Low Kick: Low Kick is worth considering if your team struggles with Kingambit.

  • Overgrow: Since this Meowscarada set aims to be more of a supportive Pokemon, Overgrow is preferred to keep STAB on its attacks after it uses its support moves.

Tera Types

  • Grass: When paired with an Overgrow boost, Tera Grass lets Flower Trick deal a huge amount of damage.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy eases Meowscarada's matchup against Choice Band Dragapult, who can threaten to KO through Focus Sash via Dragon Darts.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Meowscarada with Sword of Ruin is an adept offensive pivot and revenge killer against boosted foes like Polteageist and Volcarona and other Choice Scarf users such as Sandy Shocks and Greninja. Moreover, Meowscarada can potentially clean up in the late-game after using Knock Off + U-turn to sufficiently weaken checks like Corviknight, Scream Tail, and Kingambit; U-turn also hits Roaring Moon and opposing Meowscarada. Trick immediately shuts down Meowscarada's checks, while Knock Off + Spikes chips the grounded ones into KO range. Early-game wallbreakers like Dragonite, Chi-Yu, and Greninja can punch huge holes into the opposition so that Meowscarada can take over the game; in return, Meowscarada cripples Dondozo and Corviknight with its STAB moves for the former two and offers pivot support for the latter two. Corviknight is a solid Defogger and pivot that also switches into priority attacks like First Impression, -ate Speed, and Ice Shard, which frees up Meowscarada to pivot more freely throughout the game.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Meowscarada utilizes its amazing Speed, great Attack stat, Protean, and Choice Band to cement itself as a great Pokemon within the tier.
  • Flower Trick allows Meowscarada to handle Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types like Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl.
  • Knock Off is a great option for hitting Ghost- and Psychic-types such as non-Choice Scarf Gholdengo and Espathra. It is also useful for dealing with Magnezone, preventing Meowscarada from being OHKOed by a Choice Specs-boosted Hyper Beam.
  • Sucker Punch can be used to OHKO Choice item Dragapult and Flutter Mane; however this requires prediction in regards to the latter and is generally an inferior option to Knock Off.
  • Giga Impact is Meowscarada's strongest move at its disposal, letting it take on threats such as Sylveon and Clodsire.
  • Play Rough hits Dragon- and Fighting-types like Goodra, Garchomp, and Gallade.
  • Other options include moves like Thunder Punch and Shadow Claw, which beats stall Azumarill and Counter Annihilape, respectively.
  • Alternatively, Meowscarada can opt to run a Leech Seed set with Substitute, Protect, Leech Seed, and Flower Trick with an EV spread of 240 HP / 16 Def / 252 Spe and Mental Herb to have a more reliable matchup against Annihilape, Iron Hands, and non-Timid Flutter Mane.
  • Against Pokemon that can tank a hit from Meowscarada, like Iron Hands and Great Tusk, it is best to use moves that won't make Meowscarada vulnerable to the opposing Pokemon's attacks. Using Flower Trick on Iron Hands can let you win the one-on-one against it, as your opponent may predict Meowscarada turning into a Fairy-type and use Heavy Slam; this also applies to non-Speed Booster Energy and Choice Scarf Great Tusk, where Meowscarada may need to use Play Rough on a predicted Close Combat or Flower Trick on a Headlong Rush.
  • Be wary against Donphan, Meowscarada fails to deal with its Sturdy and Counter.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Grass)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
Skeledirge is a fantastic defensive Pokemon thanks to its great bulk and Unaware letting it check dangerous Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Volcarona, and Hatterene. Unlike other walls, however, Skeledirge can also be a foreboding wincon with Torch Song and its great offensive typing, which gives it nearly unresisted coverage. Will-O-Wisp gives it value against switch-ins such as Ting-Lu, Rotom-W, and Clodsire and cripples physical attackers like Great Tusk and Garchomp. Hex benefits from Skeledirge spreading burns, 2HKOing Pokemon such as Dragonite, Iron Hands, and physically defensive Dondozo unboosted, and Toxapex after a single boost from Torch Song. Tera Fairy bolsters Skeledirge against Dragon-types that would otherwise overwhelm it like Dragapult, Dragonite, Garchomp, and Baxcalibur. It also lets Skeledirge beat Quaquaval and lose its Ground weakness, letting it more easily spread burns against Ground-types like Great Tusk and Garchomp. In a pinch, it can bait Dark-type moves from Pokemon like Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Meowscarada, Terastallize the same turn, and punish them with Will-O-Wisp. Tera Fairy also maintains Skeledirge's ability to beat Iron Valiant, Volcarona, and Hatterene.

Skeledirge fits on many bulky offense, balance, and stall teams as a much-appreciated answer to common wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant and Hatterene. Skeledirge often ends up entry hazard fodder for Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Thus, secure hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are excellent partners. Additionally, Great Tusk can 2HKO the aforementioned Pokemon, helping set Skeledirge up for a potential sweep, while Corviknight walls the aforementioned Ground-types, can bring Skeledirge in later with U-turn, and can absorb Knock Off from the likes of Great Tusk, Meowscarada, and Iron Treads. Pokemon such as Meowscarada and Iron Valiant can overwhelm Skeledirge answers like Gholdengo, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu. In addition to this, they appreciate Skeledirge's ability to beat Hatterene and, after Terastallizing, Dragapult. Covert Cloak Gholdengo can beat any Garganacl using Skeledirge as setup fodder. Bulky Water-types like Rotom-W and Toxapex help deal with offensive Water-types like Greninja and Quaquaval. Additionally, they can both spread status, facilitating Skeledirge's Hex. Rotom-W in particular can offensively check Ground-types like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu too, although it cannot directly switch into them. Offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, Kingambit, and Dragonite appreciate Skeledirge halting scary Pokemon, like Volcarona and Iron Valiant, and they help it overwhelm checks like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire.

sets.name: Substitute
sets.description:
With Substitute, Skeledirge can use its typing and bulk to consistently check Garganacl and more easily snowball with Torch Song. Substitute also allows Skeledirge to scout Choice item Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Dragonite, as well as protecting it from revenge killers like Kingambit and Roaring Moon more reliably. Substitute also lets Skeledirge set up against the likes of Garganacl and Cinderace, and it blocks from status from the likes of Toxapex, Clodsire, and Thunder Wave Rotom-W. Maximum HP investment means that Garganacl cannot break Substitute with Salt Cure. 40 Defense EVs let Skeledirge survive two Bulldozes from Focus Sash Breloom, meaning it can consistently outheal Bulldoze, barring a critical hit. 188 Special Defense EVs ensures it survives a Shadow Ball from non-Tera Ghost Choice Specs Dragapult, while 28 Speed EVs let it outspeed Kingambit. Tera Fairy helps stop the likes of Dragapult and Great Tusk from overwhelming Skeledirge, especially the former, which bypasses Substitute with Infiltrator but cannot 2HKO Skeledirge after it Terastallizes. Tera Fairy also prevents Garganacl's Earthquake from breaking Substitute.

Substitute Skeledirge fits best on bulky offense and balance teams as a good check to Garganacl. Pokemon Garganacl can overwhelm such as Dragonite, Hex Dragapult, Dragon Dance Roaring Moon, Calm Mind Hatterene, Corviknight, Toxapex, and Dondozo can lure it in for Skeledirge to set up Substitute on and snowball. Additionally, the former can break through Pokemon that wall Skeledirge, namely Toxapex and Clodsire, and Dragapult and Corviknight also boast U-turn, letting them pivot into Skeledirge on a Garganacl switch-in. The setup sweepers enjoy Skeledirge's potent wallbreaking, too. Toxapex and Dondozo also check Pokemon that overwhelm Skeledirge, such as Dragapult and Greninja. Pokemon that do not mind Knock Off like Great Tusk and Corviknight greatly help this set, as Skeledirge is both weak to Knock Off and reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots due to its Stealth Rock weakness. These Pokemon also double as entry hazard removers, with the former preventing Gholdengo from entering safely and the latter checking Ground-types like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Meowscarada can chip down Pokemon that wall Skeledirge like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. In return, Skeledirge can threaten common entry hazard answers like Hatterene and Corviknight, as well as spinblocking in a pinch.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Skeledirge is a decent Koraidon check, reliably beating Choice Scarf and Swords Dance + Flame Charge sets while pivoting into and scouting Choice Band Koraidon. Skeledirge is notably immune to trapping by Dugtrio and Gothitelle, which ensures its viability as an alternative to the more passive Toxapex. Torch Song is Skeledirge's most reliable STAB move and gives it the potential to snowball late-game into a sweeper. Will-O-Wisp prevents physical attackers like Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao from setting up on it and also annoys passive Pokemon like Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Alomomola. Earth Power punishes Miraidon and Chi-Yu as they switch in while also letting it beat Garganacl and Tera Fire Koraidon. Alternatively, Hex complements Will-O-Wisp, doing heavy damage to neutral targets such as Toxapex and Pelipper. Fairy is Skeledirge's preferred Tera Type, granting it a valuable immunity to Koraidon's Outrage and allowing it to absorb otherwise supereffective attacks like Crunch from Chien-Pao and Earthquake or Headlong Rush from Great Tusk. Skeledirge fits best on balance teams that appreciate its ability to neuter Koraidon and can effectively handle the numerous Pokemon that can threaten Skeledirge, such as Great Tusk, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle. As a result, ideal teammates include revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Miraidon and Choice Band Chien-Pao and defensive staples like Corviknight, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
• Will-O-Wisp cripples common Skeledirge switch-ins such as Toxapex and Ting-Lu, and it also forces out Koraidon. Hex, in conjuction with Will-O-Wisp, helps Skeledirge beat foes that otherwise wouldn't take much damage from its attacks, such as Toxapex and Alomomola.
  • Earth Power hits Pokemon that would wall Skeledirge completely, such as Garganacl, while still hitting Toxapex hard. Earth Power also hits Tera Fire Koraidon, which can potentially beat Skeledirge one-on-one if Torch Song is its only attacking move, as Hex without a status condition does not always break Koraidon's Substitute with a Torch Song boost.
  • Skeledirge is best suited for bulky offense and stall teams alike, as those styles of teams specifically appreciate its walling capabilities. For example, it can wall non-Stomping Tantrum Koraidon, Choice Specs Iron Valiant, and non-Earthquake Slither Wing.
  • Tera Fairy helps Skeledirge check Pokemon that would otherwise overwhelm it, such as Koraidon locked into Outrage and Chien-Pao locked into Crunch. Tera Water is also an option to check Palafin and rain teams, and it retains Skeledirge's Fire resistance.
  • Pokemon that appreciate walls like Ting-Lu and Toxapex being burned make for great partners, like Miraidon and Kingambit. Other Koraidon and Chien-Pao checks such as Toxapex and Great Tusk make for great partners too, as Skeledirge appreciates not being the only check to them. Lastly, Blissey walls Iron Bundle and Miraidon for Skeledirge, and in return Skeledirge checks Koraidon.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Fire)
sets.description:
Skeledirge is a great choice for Fire teams as a non-passive physically defensive wall. With Will-O-Wisp and Unaware, it can check physical set-up sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite or Belly Drum Azumarill that threaten Fire. Additionally, Torch Song lets Skeledirge fire back against these threats while raising its Special Attack and reducing passitivity. Hex pairs incredibly well with Will-O-Wisp, as it threatens large amounts of damage on burned foes, while Shadow Ball is a more consistent STAB option that hits opposing Skeledirge for more immediate damage. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Skeledirge avoid entry hazards chipping away at it whenever it switches in.

Volcarona is a great teammate for Skeledirge, as it can threaten Dark-types that annoy Skeledirge such as Ting-Lu and Kingambit. In return, Skeledirge can burn physical attackers, like Dragonite, giving Volcarona more setup opportunities. Paldean Tauros-F is also a good teammate, since it can threaten the aforementioned Dark-types with its Fighting STAB while also having Intimidate to help neutralize physical attackers that Skeledirge cannot handle on its own, such as Roaring Moon. Additionally, its Choice Scarf set can outspeed and KO Greninja. Torkoal pairs well with Skeledirge due to its ability to both remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin and set them up, all while also powering up Skeledirge's Torch Song. Cinderace is a fairly good partner as well due to High Jump Kick, letting it remove Dark-types aiming to threaten Skeledirge, while also being able to remove entry hazards with Court Change and hit Poison-types such as Clodsire and Toxapex with Zen Headbutt. Scovillain is a good partner, since it can remove Water-types such as Dondozo and Rotom-W with its Grass STAB. Both Talonflame and Air Balloon Iron Moth alleviate Skeledirge's weakness to threats such as Great Tusk and Ting-Lu.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Defensive Gator
sets.description:
• Thanks to instant recovery, Unaware, and the snowballing potential of Torch Song, Skeledirge distinguishes itself as one of the premier physical walls.

  • Will-O-Wisp versus Yawn: Will-O-Wisp vastly improves Skeledirge's match-up against fearsome physical foes such as Kingambit, while Yawn works exceptionally well with Stealth Rock support.

  • Substitute: Substitute is a good way around status, especially Garganacl's Salt Cure. It also becomes effective when used on Toxic Spikes teams.

Other Options

  • Encore: When paired with Substitute, Skeledirge can seriously punish passive Pokemon, though at a serious cost in coverage.

  • Flame Charge: Despite Skeledirge's low Speed, stacking Flame Charge boosts can make it difficult to check, though it'll often need multiple boosts to outspeed threats without compromising its bulk.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Terastallizing into the Fairy typing removes Skeledirges glaring weakness to Dark and provides an overall superior defensive typing. It also provides a neutral typing for the inevitable Shadow Balls that will be thrown at Skeledirge. With proper timing, Skeledirge can defeat counters meant to deal with it, most notably Gholdengo and Dragapult.

  • Normal: While Tera Normal isn't fantastic defensively, it lets Skeledirge severely punish attempts from special attacking Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult to check it.

  • Water: A Water Tera type lets Skeledirge take on formerly super effective attacks such as Liquidation, providing a valuable turn to burn the offender. It should be noted that Tera Water tends to be a safer option versus the ubiquitous Gholdengo, as it does not often run Thunderbolt.

Items

  • Leftovers or Sitrus Berry: The residual recovery helps Skeledirge use Torch Song more freely.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak ignores the secondary effects of Salt Cure and Acid Spray, improving Skeledirge's match-up against Garganacl and Bellibolt.

  • Safety Goggles: The immunity to Spore Skeledirge gains lets it check Breloom and Brute Bonnet far more effectively.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: This makes Skeledirge less pressured to Terastallize to rid itself of its Stealth Rock weakness.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 244 Def / 12 Spe with Bold: The EVs are set to maximize physical bulk with just enough Speed to outpace uninvested Corviknight.

  • 220 HP / 164 Def / 4 SpA / 108 SpD / 12 Spe with Calm: This EV spread allows both Tera Fairy and Water Skeledirge to avoid a 2HKO from a plethora of offensive threats, such as Modest Gholdengo, Adamant Azumarill, and Choice Specs Dragapult, while still boasting significant physical bulk.

sets.name: Blunder Song
sets.description:
• With Blunder Policy, this Skeledirge provides a unique approach to offense: it'll either put important foes to sleep (RC) or threaten to snowball into a sweep with Speed and Special Attack boosts!

  • Shadow Ball: Even with Skeledirge's wide variety of viable Tera types, Shadow Ball is still an excellent secondary STAB attack for hitting Dragapult and opposing Skeledirge.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power is Skeledirge's best option against Garganacl, and it makes checking Iron Moth feasible.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: With this Skeledirge's more offensive nature, Tera Fairy's immunity to powerful Dragon-type attacks is a big help, and it makes Tera Blast an effective tool against bulky foes such as Baxcalibur and Garchomp.

  • Normal: Tera Normal gives Skeledirge a key Ghost-type immunity, taking advantage of common Choiced Ghost-types such as Gholdengo.

  • Fire: In addition to removing the troublesome Ghost-type weakness, Tera Fire makes sweeping with Torch Song require less setup.

  • Water: Besides being a fantastic defensive typing, Tera Water gives Skeledirge the chance to pick off weakened Iron Bundle as they use Hydro Pump and gives it a good attack against Garganacl and Iron Moth.

  • Grass: Tera Grass vastly improves Skeledirge's matchup against Breloom, Rotom-W, and Brute Bonnet.

EV Spreads

  • All EV spreads for this set should outspeed Dragapult after missing Sing.

  • 204 HP / 140 SpA / 164 Spe with Modest: The HP investment in this spread lets Skeledirge survive one Earthquake from Garchomp when staying a Fire-type and one Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle when Tera Fairy or Tera Normal.

  • 92 HP / 252 SpA / 164 Spe with Modest: This spread sacrifices bulk for being able to OHKO Iron Bundle with Torch Song after Stealth Rock damage and doing the same to Kingambit with Tera Fire.

  • 164 HP / 180 Def / 164 Spe with Bold: This defensive spread allows Tera Skeledirge to always avoid a 2HKO from Jolly Choice Band Dragonite's Extreme Speed and avoids getting 2HKOed by Baxcalibur's 4-hit Icicle Spear when Tera Normal or Fairy.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Modest or Timid: A huge sacrifice in bulk makes it harder for Skeledirge to set up, but the Speed investment does allow it to outspeed several major Choice Scarf threats after missing Sing. Modest variants will outspeed up to Choice Scarf Annihilape, while Timid sets will Speed tie with +1 Espathra.

sets.name: Offensive Gator
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

sets.name: Good as Gold
sets.description: Good as Gold Skeledirge's great bulk, typing, and movepool make it a decent deterrent to entry hazard removal and excellent status spreader. Will-O-Wisp + Hex spreads chip damage, neuters physical attackers, and gives Skeledirge the most firepower; Roar + Shadow Ball is a more consistent alternative that deters setup and racks up entry hazard chip. Teammates that can reliably set entry hazards long-term such as Regenerator Garchomp and Ting-Lu are great partners, as they greatly appreciate Skeledirge's ability to deter hazard-removing attempts. Pokemon that check the likes of Greninja such as specially defensive Desolate Land Volcarona make for great defensive partners alongside Skeledirge. Strong wallbreakers such as Gengar and Cinderace appreciate Skeledirge’s ability to keep entry hazards up by preventing Corviknight's Defog and potentially risk a spinblock against Iron Treads, allowing them to further pressure the opposing team. 12 Speed EVs let Skeledirge outspeed and either damage or burn Corviknight.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: When it comes to Unaware Pokemon, Skeledirge is one of the best available; it has great physical bulk and a solid move in Torch Song, which boosts its already good Special Attack. These traits make it a hard-to-break physical wall and a potential wincon as well. Will-O-Wisp lets it cripple physical attackers such as Mega Tyranitar, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T while also punishing Water-types such as Rotom-W. Combined with Will-O-Wisp, Hex helps it overwhelm passive checks in Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Clodsire while also allowing Skeledirge to sweep statused teams. While not as strong as Hex, Shadow Ball is a decent option as it's more consistent. Tera Water allows Skeledirge to beat rain teams by spreading burns against rain sweepers such as Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Floatzel. On the other hand, Tera Fairy allows it to counter Dragon Dance Dragapult and avoid Pursuit from Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile while also keeping a Fighting resistance, meaning it can still check Zamazenta. It also removes Skeledirge's Ground weakness, allowing it to comfortably burn Pokemon like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T. Skeledirge struggles against Heatran and Garganacl, as it can't burn them nor deal significant damage to them. Therefore, Pokemon that pressure them like Garchomp and Rotom-W for the former and Cover Cloak Gholdengo for the latter make good partners. Skeledirge also hates losing its item, so Knock Off absorbers like Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor make for good teammates. The former can also weaken Heatran for it while Skeledirge can burn Mega Tyranitar. Special sponges like Gastrodon, Clodsire, and Toxapex all appreciate Skeledirge's ability to cripple physical attackers such as Kartana, Mega Lopunny, and Kingambit, alleviating the pressure these Pokemon exert on them. In return, they can all handle special attackers like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Mega Charizard Y.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Rapid Spin (Water)
sets.description: These are the sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!
