  • Play Rough versus Knock Off: Play Rough is Tinkaton's best option against Roaring Moon, and thanks to Mold Breaker, Tinkaton can hit Unaware Dondozo with boosted Play Rough. Meanwhile, Knock Off is Tinkaton's best attack against Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Tera turns Tinkaton's Ground-type weakness into an immunity, allowing it to use Encore on moves like Earthquake and Fissure from foes such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Dondozo.

  • Steel: Steel Tera capitalizes on Gigaton Hammer to make it deal as much damage as possible.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 236 Atk / 36 Def / 4 SpD / 228 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds Annihilape and allows Tinkaton to survive a +1 Dragon Claw + Normal Tera Extreme Speed from Dragonite after Terastallizing.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers has great synergy with Encore, allowing it to set up while healing off some of the damage from weak moves.

  • Focus Sash: Holding a Focus Sash guarantees that Tinkaton can get at least one move off even against super effective attacks aimed at it.

  • Air Balloon: With Air Balloon, Tinkaton can give Ground-type foes like Great Tusk and Hippowdon issues before even Terastallizing.

vgc2023.overview:
• Tinkaton is primarily a bulky attacker, but it also has an amazing defensive typing and Fake Out, giving it good defensive utility.

  • Tinkaton does extremely well against Murkrow teams, including Pokemon common on them like Annihilape, Hydreigon, Meowscarada, Maushold, and Murkrow itself. This makes it a very good partner for Dondozo + Tatsugiri teams, which feel pressured by Murkrow's Haze. Many of the aforementioned Pokemon are also very common on teams without Murkrow, so Tinkaton checking them well is broadly useful.

  • Mold Breaker + Fake Out Tinkaton does well against dedicated Trick Room teams because its Fake Out bypasses Oranguru's Inner Focus and Farigiraf's Armor Tail, and it can OHKO Mimikyu through Disguise.

  • Tinkaton struggles with the extremely common Fire-types, as well as Garchomp and Steel-types like Corviknight and Scizor, which wall it entirely. Water-types help deal with the majority of its counters, especially Rotom-W.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Knock Off hits Pokemon that resist both its STAB moves like Gholdengo, Armarouge, and Ceruledge and can cripple Pokemon with the item removal, especially Dondozo.

  • Tinkaton has many opportunities to use Swords Dance, especially because opponents will often use Protect consecutively in front of it, expecting a Fake Out or Gigaton Hammer. It's also a good move to use on the Gigaton Hammer recharge turns.

  • Assault Vest turns Tinkaton into a sponge against special attackers, which helps against common Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Gholdengo.

  • Sitrus Berry lets Tinkaton run Protect, which helps it stall out Gigaton Hammer recharge turns. This also pairs well with Swords Dance, which is similarly convenient to have on the recharge turns.

  • Mold Breaker is mainly good when used with Fake Out, as the ability lets Tinkaton flinch Dragonite, Farigiraf, and Oranguru. Mold Breaker also bypasses Mimikyu's Disguise.

  • Own Tempo is valuable because there are multiple good Intimidate users: Arcanine and Gyarados, as well as Paldean Tauros-A, Paldean Tauros-B, and Salamence. If you're not very worried about dedicated Trick Room teams or Dragonite, this is a good way to improve your matchup against bulkier teams.

  • Tera Steel is by far the best Tera type for Tinkaton, as it makes Gigaton Hammer very powerful, even doing good damage to targets that resist it. For example, it 2HKOes maximum HP Talonflame.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Tinkaton's decent bulk with Assault Vest and incredible defensive typing allow it to pivot into and check special attackers such as Hatterene and Gengar. Knock Off is Tinkaton's most important move, as it provides utility by removing crucial items from common switch-ins such as Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Iron Treads. Skitter Smack lowers the Special Attack of bulky Calm Mind users such as Florges and powerful wallbreakers such as Chi-Yu, allowing Tinkaton and its teammates to more easily handle these threats. Play Rough and Ice Hammer both hit Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon hard; Play Rough also dents Fighting-types such as Slither Wing while Ice Hammer deals huge damage to Garchomp, Dragonite, and Clodsire. Physically defensive walls such as Hippowdon can deal with the physical wallbreakers that threaten Tinkaton, like Ceruledge, and appreciate it relieving pressure against Greninja. Slower attackers such as Chi-Yu and Quaquaval benefit from Tinkaton handling fast revenge killers such as Gengar for them.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Wave Crash is a very strong STAB move. With Stealth Rock support and Tera Water's power boost, it crushes walls Palafin normally might struggle to break, like Toxapex and Corviknight, and always OHKOes Miraidon.
  • Close Combat is a strong, reliable coverage move that hits many of Palafin's checks like Corviknight and Koraidon for solid damage, while also hitting Water-types barring Toxapex for neutral damage.
  • Ice Punch allows Palafin to hit Dragon-types like the very common Koraidon and Miraidon while also hitting Water Absorb Clodsire. However, it cannot OHKO Koraidon and is not guaranteed to OHKO Miraidon.
  • Zen Headbutt allows Palafin to hit Toxapex super effectively, as well as potentially OHKOing Koraidon and having fantastic odds to 2HKO Miraidon.
  • Tera Water powers up Palafin's Water-type moves and allows Palafin to achieve feats like 2HKOing Miraidon with Jet Punch from full HP if rain is up.
  • Choice Band Palafin functions best on offensive teams to revenge kill threats like Flutter Mane or to break walls for its teammates mid-game. Remember, base Palafin needs to be used very early in a game to transform into its Hero Form.
  • Pelipper is a great partner for Palafin, as it checks Koraidon decently and replaces its sun with rain, strengthening Palafin's powerful Water-type attacks.
  • Koraidon sets up sun and resists Water-type attacks Palafin throws at it, so Palafin appreciates teammates that threaten Koraidon, like Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Also, Palafin is weakened by the sun Koraidon sets up, so it is best not to pair Palafin and Koraidon together.
  • Miraidon is a good partner, as it destroys Alomomola, a great counter to Palafin, and can safely bring Palafin onto the field with either U-turn or Volt Switch. Miraidon also appreciates Palafin threatening Ground-type Pokemon that can take Miraidon's Electric-type attacks, like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Jet Punch's strong priority allows this Palafin set to still be threatening to offensive builds, while Drain Punch keeps Palafin healthy against bulkier teams.
  • Taunt allows Palafin to prevent common responses to setup sweepers from working, such as Whirlwind from Ting-Lu and Haze from Toxapex, while also preventing Pokemon like Annihilape from setting up alongside it.
  • Fairy is the Tera type of choice to allow Palafin to resist both of Koraidon's STAB attacks and potentially set up on Choice Scarf variants of it. Fairy also removes Palafin's weakness to Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry and Miraidon's Electric moves.
  • Palafin struggles to deal with Koraidon or Miraidon, which can come in on this set easily, especially given that Zero to Hero forces Palafin to switch at least once before it can be offensively threatening. As a result, this Palafin needs teammates that can defensively handle these threats. Ting-Lu and Iron Treads both help with Miraidon, and Pokemon like Great Tusk, Scream Tail, and Skeledirge can provide defensive solidity against Koraidon.
  • This Palafin set functions best with a sturdy defensive backbone alongside it, to mitigate the impact of Zero to Hero. As a result, it does not work as well on more hyper offensive playstyles.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: This looks like a job for Palafin
sets.description:
• Palafin's stats are middling, but after switching out once it will forme change into Palafin-H, which boasts the highest base Attack in the format, making it an effective wall breaker and revenge killer.

  • Jet Punch: With Jet Punch, Palafin-H becomes an excellent revenge killer, being able to take down important threats such as Flutter Mane, Iron Moth, and Great Tusk.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat is good coverage, hitting Rotom-W for neutral damage and covering Roaring Moon and Meowscarada.

  • Adamant versus Jolly: An Adamant nature increases the damage Wave Crash and Jet Punch inflict, making Palafin-H a more effective wall breaker and revenge killer. A Jolly nature enables Palafin-H to outspeed Mimikyu and Hydreigon.

Tera Types

  • Water: A Water Tera type boosts Jet Punch and Wave Crash, making Palafin-H a potent late-game cleaner.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type turns all of Palafin-H's weaknesses into resistances, giving it a favorable matchup against Rotom-W, and making it immune to Spore from Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Overcoat is an option over Filter so Venomoth can't try to muscle past a weakened Revavroom with Sleep Powder and enough sleep turns.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description: Tera Ground covers Steel- and Fire-types such as Klefki, Coalossal, and Paldean Tauros-F, but Tera Fire can be used for Bronzong.

sets.name: Shed Tail
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Shed Tail (Dragon)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Shed Tail
sets.description: Shed Tail, Regenerator, and good Speed give Cyclizar a unique role on offensive teams: safely bringing in powerful attackers like Cinderace and Dragonite multiple times per battle. Draco Meteor KOes opposing Cyclizar and picks off weakened foes. U-turn lets Cyclizar pivot out without self-damage, healing from Regenerator to potentially use Shed Tail again later. Rapid Spin and/or Knock Off provide further utility. Choice Scarf + Shed Tail is preferred against Chien-Pao and other fast threats, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to avoid entry hazard damage and the Choice lock. Cyclizar benefits greatly from a strong physical wall or Dazzling user to deal with priority attackers like Dragonite; strong attackers like Cinderace and Greninja are valuable for dealing with phazers like Hippowdon, or a Good as Gold user like Skeledirge or Garganacl can block phazing moves outright.

sets.name: Support
sets.description: Cyclizar provides invaluable utility on hyper offense with Rapid Spin, Knock Off, and Shed Tail. Rapid Spin removes entry hazards, which are detrimental to allies like Dragonite lacking Heavy-Duty Boots and Mega Gyarados. Taunt can be used over Draco Meteor to stifle passive foes like Gastrodon and Ferrothorn, preventing them from laying entry hazards or using recovery. Knock Off removes items from the likes of Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire, crippling them. Shed Tail gives allies a free switch-in, allowing them to avoid status conditions and boost safely if the Substitute stays intact. Sitrus Berry allows Cyclizar to reliably pass Shed Tail against priority moves from the likes of Mega Scizor and Dragonite, and it helps ensure it can pass multiple Substitutes during a game. Cyclizar typically doesn’t use Tera, as its more offensive teammates such as Dragonite and Annihilape take advantage of Tera much more effectively. However, Tera Fairy gives Cyclizar crucial resistances, allowing it to survive hits from Zamazenta and Dragapult and turn the tables on them. Sweepers like Dragonite, Mega Gyarados, and Dragapult utilize dual screens and Shed Tail support to set up safely and survive potential revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Either Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl is a mandatory partner for Cyclizar; they help enable sweepers by setting up dual screens for them and make the Substitutes that Cyclizar passes harder to break. Tapu Koko notably provides Electric Terrain for Iron Valiant, increasing its effectiveness. Faster threats like Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant can force Cyclizar out; thus, Pokemon like Kingambit and Volcarona make great partners that cover for Cyclizar and exploit its checks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Cyclizar provides utility and Speed control to ones team, able to pass fast Substitute to teammates and to revenge kill weakened opponents. Overheat, Thunderbolt, and Power Whip provide excellent coverage to hit many Pokemon like Gholdengo, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Swampert, respectively. Knock Off and Rapid Spin can be utilized for a more supportive role, though it will increase Cyclizar’s passivity. A Naive nature should be used with Power Whip to have a high chance of OKHOing Mega Swampert after Stealth Rocks. Cyclizar can pack Tera Fairy to check Dragapult while Tera Steel can give it many resistances, helping it check the likes of Mega Scizor and Weavile. Strong wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Mega Gyarados greatly appreciate Cyclizar’s Shed Tail granting them free switch ins. Teammates like Zamazenta appreciate avoiding crippling status and getting more opportunities to set up with Howl. Gholdengo and Iron Valiant love the opportunities to switch in safely and help exploit Cyclizar’s checks in Iron Valiant and Zamazenta. Mega Gyarados and Volcarona benefit from Shed Tail while also threatening Great Tusk and Mega Lopunny, who seek to take advantage of Cyclizar. Tapu Koko also is a great ally that provides support with dual screens, making the Substitutes Cyclizar passes harder to break.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description:
• Thanks to Earth Eater, Orthworm can wall sets of many physical Dragon-types like Garchomp and Baxcalibur.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: Heavy Slam can 2HKO offensive Dragapult, OHKOs Flutter Mane, and deals much more damage to Iron Valiant, while Iron Head is superior for Dragonite.

  • Rest and Chesto Berry: Rest is an option with Chesto Berry to heal Orthworm in a pinch, giving it better longevity.

  • Shed Tail: Shed Tail gives Orthworm use when IronPress isn't as effective. The surprise factor comes at the price of the reduced effectiveness of IronPress.

  • Substitute: Substitute stops Salt Cure damage from Garganacl and phazing from Garchomp's Dragon Tail.

Other Options

  • Earthquake is an option to hit Gholdengo, but it won't 2HKO, so Recover is still a problem.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry allows two uses of Shed Tail.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers is a consistent option, especially in conjunction with Substitute.

Tera Types

  • Poison: Tera Poison provides a key Fighting resistance and single weakness and maintains a key resistance to Flower Trick, letting Orthworm preform better against Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy provides a Fighting resistance and Dragon immunity, turning Dragon Tail Garchomp into setup bait, and dealing with Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Roaring Moon.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: This EV spread makes Orthworm much less likely to be 2HKOd by Life Orb Dragapult.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread can be used to outspeed Adamant Kingambit, most Corviknight, and Skeledirge. This can be very useful if using Shed Tail.

sets.name: Shed Tail Support
sets.description:
• Orthworm's good physical bulk and ability make it a great user of Shed Tail, and a reliable Stealth Rock user.

  • Body Press: Body Press has a good chance to OHKO offensive Meowscarada, and threatens Kingambit and Roaring Moon.

  • Heavy Slam versus Iron Head: A Steel-type STAB move helps hit some Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Flutter Mane, who are OHKOed by Heavy Slam, and deals massive damage to Iron Valiant. Iron Head is an alternative for heavy foes like Dragonite.

  • Spikes: Orthworm can also set Spikes, but this compromises its ability to pass Shed Tail.

  • A Special Teammate: Many Pokemon can benefit from Orthworm's Shed Tail. One example is Air Balloon Gholdengo, which puts a lot of pressure on defensive foes when behind a Substitute.

Tera Types

  • This Orthworm isn't usually meant to Terastalize, since that's better served by the teammates its passing a Substitute to.

  • Poison: Tera Poison leaves Orthworm with only one fairly rare weakness, and aiding it against former threats like Great Tusk and Iron Valiant.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Orthworm a Fighting resistance, as well as a way to absorb Garchomp's Dragon Tail while still staying in.

EV spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD: This spread maximizes Orthworm's physical bulk. Running a Speed IV of 0 may be tempting, but being outsped by bulky Brute Bonnet is risky.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Impish: This spread outspeeds Kingambit, and most Skeledirge and Corviknight. Outspeeding Kingambit and Corviknight prevents Taunt from stopping Shed Tail, and let's Orthworm bring in a teammate against Torch Song.

  • 252 HP / 44 Def / 212 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and Jolly Brute Bonnet. Mach Punch still does a lot, but thanks to Sitrus Berry, Orthworm will have enough HP left to Shed Tail to a check or counter.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description: Glimmet is one of the best entry hazard setters in LC because it can set up all of Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Toxic Spikes. Mud Shot threatens Steel-types like Pawniard and Tinkatink, albeit activating the former's Defiant, hits opposing Glimmet, and can help win matchups against faster threats with its Speed drop, especially on Focus Sash sets. Alternatively, Power Gem can be used to hit Ghost-types such as Hisuian Zorua and Drifloon. Eviolite allows Glimmet to set up entry hazards multiple times in a game and check Larvesta and Drifloon, while Focus Sash can be used to guarantee hazards, even in unfavorable lead matchups such as Diglett. Tera Ghost lets Glimmet spinblock and allows it to escape Diglett and Gothita, while Tera Grass gives it a better matchup against Quaxly and Toedscool, the two most common spinners, as well as Ground-types like Diglett and Mudbray. Ghost-types such as Hisuian Zorua, Drifloon, and Greavard should be used with Glimmet to maintain Glimmet’s hazards by spinblocking. U-turn and Volt Switch users like Magnemite, Mankey, and Voltorb are great partners, as their ability to force switches amplifies the damage Glimmet's hazards can deal to the opposing team. Offensive attackers such as Crabrawler, Pawniard, and Mankey appreciate Glimmet's hazards to secure KOs and wear down their checks.

sets.name: Focus Sash Glimmora
sets.description:
With Stealth Rock and its ability Toxic Debris, Focus Sash Glimmora functions as a lead able to set up hazards when hit by a physical attack. Mortal Spin lets Glimmora provide entry hazard removal for its team and potentionally poison an opposing Pokemon. Earth Power hits Steel-types like Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Iron Treads, which all block Mortal Spin. Energy Ball is mainly used to hit Great Tusk while also dealing super effective damage against Garganacl, Rotom-W, and Greninja. Alternatively, Sludge Wave allows Glimmora to threaten Hatterene, which would otherwise be troublesome thanks to its Magic Bounce ability and STAB Psychic-type moves like Psyshock. Spikes is another option that gives Glimmora the potential to set up as many entry hazards as possible, rather than the singular Stealth Rock. Tera Grass turns Glimmora's weakness to Ground-type attacks into a resistance and increases the damage output of Energy Ball, both of which are particularly useful against Great Tusk. Alternatively, Tera Ghost blocks Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk and Iron Treads, ensuring all of Glimmora's hazards stay up.

Hyper offense teams appreciate Focus Sash Glimmora's entry hazards to provide chip damage support for setup sweepers like Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Kingambit. Gholdengo is a great partner for Glimmora, as its ability Good As Gold lets it block Defog attempts from Corviknight, while its Ghost typing prevents Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk and Iron Treads, which in turn allows the hazards Glimmora set up to stay up throughout the game. Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Dragapult can use Great Tusk as an opportunity to fire off powerful attacks, which can hit Glimmora for super effective damage with Earthquake and remove its entry hazards with Rapid Spin.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description:
• Glimmora stands out as one of the best suicide leads in the metagame thanks to its signature ability in Toxic Debris and great utility movepool consisting of Stealth Rock, Spikes, and Memento. Its high Special Attack alongside STAB and coverage options in Power Gem and Earth Power let it threaten most foes including Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and Iron Treads.
  • Tera Ghost Glimmora prevents common spinners like Iron Treads and Great Tusk from removing the entry hazards that Glimmora sets. Glimmora also benefits from Tera Ghost removing its 4x weakness to Ground-type attacks, letting it threaten these spinners with its coverage more reliably. However, given the nature of Glimmora as a dedicated lead, Terastallizing is not generally recommended.
  • Dazzling Gleam threatens Fighting-types like Koraidon and Great Tusk, as well as Miraidon. Its signature move, Mortal Spin, lets Glimmora act as an entry hazard remover and also cripples Stealth Rock setters like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk with poison.
  • Mortal Spin is a good option when facing setup sweepers that Glimmora cannot threaten if it doesn't have the right coverage like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon, Double Dance Miraidon, and Bulk Up Annihilape.
  • Memento allows a teammate to come in easily while also preventing entry hazard removal attempts.
  • Glimmora likes offensive staples like Miraidon and Koraidon that can take advantage of the entry hazards it sets up. They both threaten to OHKO Defog Corviknight.
  • Glimmora also appreciates Ghost-types such as Annihilape, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo, while they appreciate the entry hazards that Glimmora sets.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Poison)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Debris Lead
sets.description:
• With a solid early-game Speed tier, utility, high Special Attack, and decent coverage options, Glimmora can set the tone of a battle, sometimes scoring KOs before fulfilling its main role of setting entry hazards.

  • Mud Shot: This will fail to KO many foes—most notably other Glimmora—but it is a valuable form of speed control that can immediately turn the game in your favor.

  • Mortal Spin: If using Stealth Rock weak teammates like Dragonite or Baxcalibur, clearing the hazards with Mortal Spin can be quite useful.

  • Memento: Memento immediately makes way for a devastating sweeper to set up against foes with halved offensive stats and potentially lowered Speed.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying vastly improves Glimmora's matchup against Great Tusk and Garchomp.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type is an option to absorb Spore from Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

Items

  • Focus Sash: This is the most reliable item for setting up Stealth Rock.

  • Air Balloon: With Air Balloon, Glimmora vastly improves its match-up against Ground-type leads such as Garchomp.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Glimmora is a valuable dedicated lead on hyper offense teams that can reliably set up multiple entry hazards in Stealth Rock, Toxic Spikes, and potentially Spikes, as well as remove opposing ones with Mortal Spin. It can make use of its solid coverage options and remarkable Special Attack to pose a noticeable offensive threat itself, especially against common entry hazard setters, removers, and other dedicated leads. Power Gem threatens the metagame's best Defogger in Tornadus-T, while Sludge Bomb dents screens setters such as Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko and—if Focus Sash is still intact—Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well, which can be problematic against offensive teams. Earth Power pressures Steel-types like Heatran, Gholdengo, and Kingambit that would otherwise block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Energy Ball deals with other entry hazard setters and removers such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W. Focus Sash guarantees that Glimmora can set at least one layer of entry hazards, potentially letting Toxic Debris trigger twice as well. Tera Ghost is used in a pinch to spinblock foes such as Great Tusk, Cyclizar, and Excadrill and remove its Ground weakness to set up multiple entry hazards in the face of other setters like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gastrodon. Gholdengo is a near-mandatory teammate to keep up entry hazards by blocking every attempts to remove them, such as Defog and Rapid Spin. Setup sweepers like Kingambit, Volcarona, Dragapult, Annihilape, and Iron Valiant appreciate entry hazards wearing down foes such as Dondozo and Clodsire and not being chipped down by opposing ones themselves; particularly, Kingambit's Knock Off can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Volcarona to make them vulnerable to Glimmora's entry hazards.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Houndstone carves a niche in the metagame as a bulky spinblocker that can comfortably switch into Great Tusk and Iron Treads.
  • Will-O-Wisp prevents physical attackers from setting up on Houndstone and spreads status on passive Pokemon like Corviknight, Toxapex, and Ting-Lu.
  • Rest gets rid of status and helps Houndstone remain healthy throughout the game.
  • Houndstone's EVs and ability make it surprisingly bulky, allowing it to survive even a Tera Dark Crunch from Choice Band Chien-Pao and OHKO back with Body Press.
  • Tera Water grants Houndstone a resistance to Fire-type moves, which are otherwise super effective because of its ability. Additionally, it gives Houndstone a neutral typing against threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Annihilape.
  • Houndstone's primary role is to act as a spinblocker with some defensive utility, so it is essential to pair it with Pokemon that set entry hazards such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads, as well as strong wallbreakers like Chien-Pao, Koraidon, Annihilape, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle that make the most out of the chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Scrappy Choice Item
sets.description:
• Scrappy gives Flamigo a unique niche, letting it throw out powerful Close Combats that are unsafe for Gholdengo and Dragapult to take!

  • Throat Chop is a decent filler move, letting Flamigo shut down Sylveon's Hyper Voice and Skeledirge's Torch Song. Note that Close Combat still does more damage to most Ghost-types.

  • Tailwind is a filler move that gives Flamigo's team some extreme speed control before it goes down.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting lets Flamigo fully take advantage of Scrappy, giving Choice Scarf sets a 81.3% chance to OHKO offensive Dragapult.

  • Fire: Tera Fire makes Flamigo immune to Will-O-Wisp, letting Choice Band sets more easily break through Skeledirge, and gives Flamigo the option to 2HKO Corviknight with Tera Blast.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With Choice Scarf, Flamigo outspeeds major threats such as Dragapult and Hydreigon, making it a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band lets Flamigo deal massive damage, giving it a shot at 2HKOing Skeledirge with Close Combat.

sets.name: Slush Rush Sweeper
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Slush Rush Sweeper
sets.description: The Speed EVs are to outrun +2 neutral natured Toxtricity. With 60 Defense EVs, Cetitan under snow survives Paldean Tauros-F's Close Combat even after Belly Drum.

sets.name: Wall
sets.description:
Dondozo is one of OU's premier walls, capable of shutting down dangerous setup sweepers like Roaring Moon. Liquidation is Dondozo's STAB move of choice due to its lack of recoil, but Wave Crash's power has some merit against foes like Ting-Lu, Skeledirge, and Clodsire. While weaker, Waterfall is another option that has more PP than Liquidation, allowing Dondozo to perform better against stall; however, its use case is rare. Body Press makes use of Dondozo's massive Defense stat and punishes Pokemon like Tera Normal Dragonite and Kingambit. Rest + Sleep Talk provides Dondozo with good sustainability without making it too passive, while Yawn is an option that forces out sweepers Dondozo cannot consistently deal with, like mixed Iron Valiant. On Yawn sets, Leftovers over Heavy-Duty Boots can be beneficial, as Dondozo is vulnerable when it is asleep without Sleep Talk. Grass is the preferred Tera type for eliminating Dondozo's original weaknesses; this is particularly helpful against Meowscarada and Iron Hands. Dragon, however, is an option that keeps Dondozo's resistance to Fire intact, albeit making it weak to Fairy-types like Azumarill and Iron Valiant.

Entry hazard setters like Clodsire and Ting-Lu pair perfectly with Dondozo, playing into its desire to outlast foes long-term with chip damage in the form of entry hazards, status, or Ruination. Both also check special attackers like Iron Valiant and Gholdengo, which Dondozo tends to struggle with. Garganacl deserves a special mention as a teammate due to its ability to wear down foes with Salt Cure; it, in turn, appreciates Dondozo taking on Great Tusk and Kingambit. Hatterene provides Dondozo teams with an excellent sweeper and appreciates Dondozo taking care of physical wallbreakers like Dragapult, and Kingambit. It also can help by blocking opposing entry hazards with Magic Bounce, letting Dondozo more comfortably tank a Knock Off from Great Tusk or Iron Treads. Similarly, entry hazard removal from Corviknight or Great Tusk is also helpful; Corviknight also deals with Meowscarada, which can force Dondozo to Terastallize early. Choice Scarf Gholdengo can help pressure opposing Dondozo while dealing with Dragapult and Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description:
Curse Dondozo is a deceptively strong sweeper that provides good defensive utility before it attempts a sweep. Liquidation is preferred over Wave Crash due to its lack of recoil; however, Wave Crash is an option if a stronger STAB move is desired. Waterfall has higher PP than Liquidation, but it is usually a weaker option. Body Press makes use of Dondozo's naturally high Defense stat and Curse's boosts, while Protect lets Dondozo accumulate Leftovers recovery. However, these two moves can be dropped for the combination of Rest and Sleep Talk, which affords Dondozo greater longevity at the cost of relying on Sleep Talk to call the right move. Leftovers is preferred over Heavy-Duty Boots, as Dondozo will be on the field for many turns in a row to adequately set up with Curse; however, if a team requires it to play more defensively, Heavy-Duty Boots is fine choice. Grass is Dondozo's Tera type of choice, removing its original weaknesses while giving it an important resistance to Ground. Maximum investment in special bulk allows Dondozo to become nigh-unbreakable once it sets up.

Entry hazard removal is key for Dondozo if it does not run Heavy-Duty Boots; good options include Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Corviknight. Though Dondozo can have quite the offensive presence once it sets up, it is best to run it alongside consistent wallbreakers like Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Iron Valiant, which can help break open holes for it to sweep late-game. Similarly, entry hazards from teammates like Garchomp and Glimmora can facilitate Dondozo's sweep. Trick users like Meowscarada and Gholdengo can cripple Dondozo checks like Clodsire and Skeledirge, causing them to lose to Dondozo over the course of the game. While Dondozo is a great sweeper, it is far from consistent at generating setup opportunities; accordingly, it is best to pair it with another bulky sweeper like Iron Defense Garganacl or Hatterene, which can weaken or bait out answers to bulky sweepers like Trick users and Unaware Clodsire.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Dondozo is a solid physical wall due to its incredible physical bulk and Unaware. Dondozo fits well on bulky teams where it can switch into physical attackers such as Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao.
  • Liquidation hits Ground- and Fire-types such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Skeledirge. Earthquake lets Dondozo lure in and deal huge damage to Miraidon.
  • Curse makes Dondozo less passive and gives it sweeping potential. Protect lets Dondozo scout for Choice item users such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle while also recovering health.
  • Rest is the only recovery option for Dondozo and can be used with Sleep Talk to deal with physical attackers such as Koraidon and Chien-Pao better. However, Miraidon's extensive presence in the metagame makes Rest unreliable.
  • Tera Steel lets Dondozo resist Moonblast from Flutter Mane and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle. Alternatively, Tera Fairy allows Dondozo to resist Fighting- and Dark-type moves from Koraidon and Chien-Pao while it also gains an immunity to Dragon-type moves.
  • Tera Ground gives Dondozo an immunity to Electric-type moves and can allow it to catch Miraidon by surprise and KO it using a boosted Earthquake.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk are great teammates, as foes can take advantage of Dondozo being worn down due to hazards. Dugtrio is a good teammate, as it can trap and KO Miraidon, making Dondozo incredibly tough to stop.
  • Dondozo appreciates special walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Blissey that can switch into threats such as Miraidon and Flutter Mane. In return, Dondozo checks their threats in Koraidon, Chien-Pao and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Curse + Resttalk
sets.description:
Dondozo is a staple on rainless Water teams due to its phenomenal bulk and ability to check setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Chien-Pao, thanks to Unaware. Dondozo faces competition from Quagsire as the team's Unaware user, as Quagsire has an immunity to Electric-type attacks and can stack entry hazards; however, it drops to Grass-type attacks. Curse allows Dondozo to apply offensive pressure, boosting its attack and allowing it to better hit targets such as Baxcalibur and Kingambit while also allowing it to better tank hits in return. Rest allows Dondozo to shrug off status and gives it longevity, allowing it to constantly absorb powerful attacks for Water teams, such as Great Tusk's Headlong Rush. Sleep Talk enables Dondozo to further take advantage of Rest, allowing it to continue to setup or attack its target while asleep. Dondozo takes advantage of its STAB through the use of Waterfall, doing more damage, but Avalanche allows Dondozo to OHKO Meowscarada, as well as pressure Water-immune Pokemon such as Clodsire and Gastrodon. Its EV spread allows Dondozo to tank attacks from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, due to its already high physical defense, which may be further boosted by Curse.

Choice Specs Greninja is an insane wallbreaker, with coverage allowing it to take on a variety of Pokemon such as an opposing Dondozo or Ting-Lu with Grass Knot, Garchomp with Ice Beam, Amoonguss and Clodsire with Extrasensory, and Espathra with Dark Pulse. Toxapex absorbs Toxic Spikes for Dondozo, spreads Toxic, and shrugs off Grass-type attacks such as Flower Trick from Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Grass Knot from Greninja. Gastrodon provides an Electric immunity and it can tank attacks from special attackers such as Flutter Mane; however, it needs to be wary of Energy Ball. Gastrodon can also stack Spikes or set Stealth Rock, wearing down foes for Dondozo. The defensive core of Dondozo, Toxapex, and Gastrodon also gives Water teams opportunities to scout powerful attacks by allowing for each to switch-in for another, such as Dondozo switching in for Gastrodon or Toxapex to tank Chien-Pao's Crunch. Earthquake also allows it to take on Poison- and Electric-type Pokemon such as Clodsire and Sandy Shocks. Quaquaval can remove hazards with Rapid Spin for Dondozo and offensive Quaquaval sets can take on common threats to Water teams such as Greninja after one Aqua Step or Meowscarada after two.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: OHKO Fisher
sets.description:
• With immense bulk, Yawn, and Unaware, Dondozo is not only an impressive defensive Pokemon, but one of the most dangerous OHKO fishers in the game.

  • Wave Crash: Despite the recoil, Wave Crash is the prefered option over Liquidation in most cases, purely for the damage output.

  • Protect: Protect is not only useful for scouting for unexpected Tera types, but pairs well with Yawn and Leftovers to give Dondozo more longevity.

  • Avalanche: It can be tricky to fit in, but Avalanche can be used to deal more consistent damage against Dragon-types.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Dondozo take on powerful Dragon-type attacks much more easily, and is just a good defensive typing in general.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type is useful enough for covering Dondozo's weaknesses, and the Spore immunity makes it capable of beating Breloom too.

  • Flying: Flying may seem like an odd Tera type, but it can lead to your Dondozo winning mirror matches thanks to the Fissure immunity.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Def / 252 SpD / 4 Spe: With Dondozo's massive HP stat, it's still able to take physical hits fairly well with this spread, while making it feasible to Yawn against special attacking threats such as Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe: This more extreme spread helps against powerful Tera users, with the ability to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Tera Dragon Dragapult's Dragon Darts with Leftovers. This comes at the cost of being much more vulnerable to weaker special attackers.

sets.name: BIG FLOPPA (Assault Vest)
sets.description:
• Dondozo’s good power and bulk lend it nicely to an Assault Vest set, and is particularly good at punishing otherwise troublesome special attackers such as Flutter Mane.

  • Avalanche: Avalanche punishes Flying- and Dragon-types with super effective coverage.

  • Body Press: This is valuable Fighting-type coverage for most foes that would otherwise be a good switch in to Dondozo, such as Meowscarada, Magnezone, and Kingambit.

  • Fissure: Fissure allows Dondozo to potentially cheese its way through something that might otherwise wall it.

  • Heavy Slam: Dondozo is heavy enough to deal serious damage to Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Flutter Mane.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake offers more reliable Ground-type coverage at the cost of not being an instant KO like Fissure.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Tera Grass removes Dondozo’s usual set of weaknesses and allows it to absorb spore from the likes of Amoonguss, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy grants Dondozo a new set of resistances to take advantage of with its phenomenal bulk and also grants it a powerful STAB to hit Dragon- and Fighting-types with if it runs Tera Blast.

  • Steel: When paired with Heavy Slam, Dondozo can now 2HKO Iron Bundle without Stealth Rock support, in addition to gaining a fantastic defensive typing.

  • Ground: Terastallizing into a Ground-type allows Dondozo to block the Electric-type attacks commonly aimed at it while also giving it STAB on Earthquake.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon gives Dondozo a resistance to both Electric- and Water-type attacks, allowing it to stand up to Rotom-W much better.

  • Dark: Tera Dark allows Dondozo to better check Espathra by becoming immune to Lumina Crash and Stored Power.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description:
• With Unaware, Dondozo becomes an effective and difficult to break Curse user.

  • Fissure: Even with Curse being the point of this set, Dondozo can still effectively fish for OHKOs with Fissure when it's not in a favorable set-up position.

  • Avalanche: Many foes will Terrastallize into a Flying-type to avoid an expected Fissure, which makes Avalanche a particularly useful coverage move.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: The Dragon immunity that Tera Fairy provides makes setting up on powerful foes like Choice Band Dragapult and Roaring Moon much easier.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera Type, Dondozo can effectively set up on Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

  • Flying: If using Fissure, Tera Flying is a good choice for potentially beating other Dondozo.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Dondozo is a great defensive Pokemon with its high physical bulk and typing, which allows it to wall physical attackers such as Zacian-C and Groudon. Spikes supports offensive teammates, while Haze stops foes like Swords Dance Zacian-C and Tidy Up Groudon from setting up. Knock Off removes items such as Covert Cloak and Leftovers, and Scald burns provide chip damage on foes. Flip Turn makes it easier to pivot into offensive teammates such as Miraidon, since Taunt, Dark-types, and Magic Bounce don't block it; alternatively, Parting Shot makes the foe easier to handle for Dondozo's teammates, but it's stopped by Taunt and Good as Gold. Heavy-Duty Boots, notably eases Dondozo's pivoting, while Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves such as U-turn and V-create. Covert Cloak protects against secondary effects like confusion from Zacian-C's Magical Torque and burns from Scald. Tera Fire allows Dondozo to resist Magical Torque and Grass-type moves from Zacian-C, and it maintains Dondozo's resistance to Fire-type moves such as V-create. Dondozo appreciates defensive teammates with typing synergy such as RegenVest Ting-Lu, which helps protect Dondozo from threatening Pokemon such as Miraidon.

sets.name: Prankster
sets.description: Prankster Dondozo with Haze can reliably check physical setup sweepers such as Zacian-C and Groudon thanks to its huge physical bulk. Entrainment forces out Pokemon dependent on their abilities, Encore can lock foes into unfavorable moves such as setup moves or V-create, and Glare debilitates fast attackers such as Zacian-C and Palkia-O. Parting Shot allows Dondozo to maintain momentum against opposing threats such as Miraidon with its priority pivoting and attack stat reduction, making it easier for teammates such as Ting-Lu to take hits from them; alternatively, Flip Turn provides a pivoting option unaffected by Taunt, Dark-types, and Magic Bounce. Heavy-Duty Boots, notably eases Dondozo's pivoting, while Covert Cloak protects it from status conditions from moves such as Nuzzle, Mortal Spin, and Magical Torque. Tera Fire improves Dondozo's matchup against Zacian-C with Grass-type coverage and lets it resist V-create and Magical Torque, whereas Tera Dark makes Dondozo immune to status moves from other Prankster users and improves its matchup against Ghost- and Dark-types. RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, Ting-Lu, and Fur Coat users synergize with Dondozo, covering threats such as Zacian-C, Groudon, and Palkia-O.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: A pure Water typing, titanic physical bulk, and Tablets of Ruin make Dondozo a nearly impenetrable physical wall that can blanket check common physical attackers including Cinderace, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao. Other options like Unaware can be used to ignore setup sweepers and wallbreakers that attempts to boost past Dondozo, while Magic Guard prevents it from being overwhelmed by entry hazards, Toxic, and Wave Crash recoil. Aside from turning it into a bulky setup sweeper, Curse also lets Dondozo contest with opposing setup from the likes of Dragonite and Kingambit, especially on non-Unaware variants. Earthquake is a necessary coverage move to hit Toxapex and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ceruledge. Rest + Leftovers provide much needed longevity, with Rest preventing Dondozo from being permanently crippled by Clodsire's Toxic, Iron Moth's Toxic Spikes, and Volcarona and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp. Special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Corviknight are necessary to deal with special attackers like Gengar, Sandy Shocks, Chi-Yu respectively; the former three spread further passive damage onto foes between entry hazards, Toxic, Ruination, and Salt Cure, slowly whittling down foes for Dondozo to sweep easier. In return, Dondozo covers the likes of Quaquaval and Cinderace for them.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: Thanks to its massive physical bulk and ability, Unaware, Dondozo serves as a wall for physical setup sweepers, such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Dondozo also annoys rain teams, shutting down wallbreakers such as Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Mega Swampert. With Curse, Dondozo can also function as a late-game sweeper. Liquidation is preferred to Wave Crash given that it has more PP and does not incur recoil. However, Wave Crash can also be considered for its greater power. Leftovers is preferred to maximize longevity; however, Heavy-Duty Boots is worth consideration to fortify switches into entry hazards. Tera Grass transforms Dondozo's Electric and Grass weaknesses into resistances, turning common threats in Tapu Koko and Kartana into fodder and avoiding Leech Seed from Ferrothorn. Dondozo fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as they greatly appreciate its ability to wall physical setup sweepers. Given its mediocre special bulk, special walls such as Clodsire and Ting-Lu make for good teammates, as they can switch into special attackers such as Tapu Koko, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Choice Specs Dragapult. Gholdengo is another good teammate since it checks dangerous special wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant that can play around Dondozo's commonly paired special walls. Other Pokemon that can beat these threats include Mega Scizor and Clodsire.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Offensive Spinner
sets.description: Despite having no effect in singles, Commander is used so Gardevoir can't Trace Storm Drain and wall Tatsugiri. Tera Steel turns the tide on Fairy-types such as Gardevoir and Sylveon. It also helps against Cryogonal's Freeze Dry.

sets.name: Spinning Sushi
sets.description: Commander is chosen to let Tatsugiri have an effective way to hit Gardevoir as it would otherwise copy Storm Drain via Trace and be immune to both Surf and Draco Meteor. Storm Drain can be used in conjunction with Tera Fairy to completely wall opposing Tatsugiri.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Annihilape is a solid setup sweeper due to its good Attack stat, decent bulk, and unresisted STAB combination. It can take advantage of Pokemon such as Corviknight, Blissey, and Clodsire.
  • Bulk Up gives Annihilape the potential to sweep while also making it progressively harder to KO.
  • Taunt allows Annihilape to stay healthy and also stops bulkier Pokemon such as Corviknight, Clodsire, and Toxapex from recovering their health. Rest can alternatively be used with Chesto Berry to get rid of status and recover health, but it fails when Electric Terrain is up.
  • Drain Punch allows Annihilape to recover health and damage foes such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads.
  • Rage Fist, along with Taunt, makes Annihilape incredibly threatening for slow walls such as Dondozo and Ting-Lu, as their attacks do little damage to Annilhilape while also boosting Rage Fist's power.
  • Tera Water allows Annihilape to take hits from special attackers such as Iron Bundle, Chi-Yu, and Flutter Mane while also letting it resist Flare Blitz from Koraidon.
  • Tera Fairy gives Annihilape an immunity against Dragon-type moves from Koraidon and Miraidon while also letting Annihilape take neutral damage from Ghost-type moves from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, OHKOing them in return with boosted Rage Fist.
  • Annihilape reaches its full potential on dual screens hyper offense teams, where it can easily take hits while setting up.
  • Special walls such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight are good teammates on balance teams, as Pokemon such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle threaten Annihilape. Corviknight is also able to remove entry hazards for Annihilape. Kingambit as a teammate overwhelms Alomomola and Skeledirge, which are common checks to it and Annihilape.
  • Entry hazard setters such as Glimmora, Froslass, Toxapex, and Clodsire can lure in Corviknight, presenting Annhilape with a great setup opportunity by forcing Corviknight to either use Defog and activate Annihilape's Defiant or give Rage Fist a boost by attacking.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big new changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulky Taunt
sets.description:
• Thanks to great bulk and the dangerous Rage Fist, Annihilape is one of the premier bulky set-up sweepers of Battle Stadium Singles.

  • Taunt: Taunt helps you deal with annoying Pokemon like Dondozo, Will-O-Wisp Skeledirge, and Hippowdon, to mention a few, forcing them to attack and boost Rage Fist.

  • Vital Spirit: With Vital Spirit, Annihilape can absorb Spore from foes like Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Amoonguss.

Tera Types

  • Fire: In addition to giving a useful resistance to Fairy attacks, Tera Fire also prevents Will-O-Wisp from hitting.

  • Steel: Steel turns Annihilape's Psychic and Fairy weakness into resistances, as well as being an excellent defensive type overall. It lets Annihilape set up freely on Amoonguss, gives it a better chance of defeating Flutter Mane, and resisting Flower Trick means Meowscarada has a much harder time revenge killing it.

  • Poison: While not as sturdy of a defensive typing as Tera Steel, Tera Poison offers a better matchup against Flutter Mane, does well against Meowscarada, and lets Annihilape freely switch into Toxic and Toxic Spikes later in the match.

  • Flying: Flying helps a lot to avoid Dondozo's Fissure, forcing it to attack with moves that boost Rage Fist. It also improves Annihilape's match-up against Great Tusk.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's residual recovery eases the long-game of setting up.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak makes Annihilape immune to being Salt Cured, making it a great check against Garganacl. It also gives peace of mind, removing potential flinches from Hydreigon's Dark Pulse or Special Defense drops from Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball.

  • Punching Glove: Removing contact damage from Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin is helpful against defensive Pokemon such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximum Speed mainly helps Annihilape outspeed Gholdengo, Great Tusk, and Breloom. With Bulk Up and Rage Fist improving its offense, Annihilape can invest in HP over Attack.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: More special bulk can make it much more difficult for special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult to revenge kill Annihilape.

  • 252 HP / 156 SpD / 100 Spe with Careful: This EV spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and Cloyster while still giving Annihilape good special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Setter
sets.description:
• Annihilape's good bulk and significant offensive presence makes it an easy to use Stealth Rock setter.

  • Rage Fist: Rage Fist is Annihilape’s strongest move; its power and coverage often lets Annihilape either defeat or significantly chip one of the opponent’s Pokemon on top of getting Stealth Rock up.

  • Taunt: Taunt gives Annihilape a strong matchup into bulky walls such as Hippowdon and opposing setup foes like Volcarona, while also making it easier to boost Rage Fist’s power.

  • Encore: Encore is an incredibly powerful move that can lock the opponent into an attacking move to boost Rage Fist's power. Alternatively, it can lock the opponent into a status move.

  • Final Gambit: Final Gambit has excellent synergy with Rage Fist; not only do they cover for each other's immunities, Final Gambit punishes foes that refuse to attack Annihilape to avoid boosting Rage Fist, allowing Annihilape to still take out a foe.

  • Curse: This is an excellent way for Annihilape to retire itself from the battle while putting significant pressure on the opponent to switch out and shutting down gimmicks such as Baton Pass.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is an excellent Speed reducing move for its ability to hit Dragonite, and threaten Volcarona and Iron Bundle. Its low accuracy should be noted as a risk, however.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze cannot hit Flying and Levitate Pokemon. In exchange, it is much more effective against Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Tinkaton.

  • Fling and Light Ball: This gives Annihilape a chance to paralyze a foe, including Gholdengo that lack Covert Cloak, and break potential Focus Sashes too.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Ghost-type attacks are incredibly common. Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and opposing Annihilape all struggle against an unexpected Tera Normal.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has excellent defensive synergy with Annihilape. It's noteworthy for halving the damage from common Dragon and Fairy-type moves.

  • Poison: Tera Poison has a good matchup against Flutter Mane, and lets Annihilape deal with Toxic and Toxic Spikes without needing to Taunt.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 4 Def / 108 SpD / 140 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds critical Pokemon such as Dragonite, Adamant Baxcalibur, and Modest Gholdengo. The Special Defense investment lets Annihilape live Choice Specs Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo’s Shadow Ball with ease.

  • 172 HP / 4 Atk / 180 Def / 76 SpD / 76 Spe with Careful: This spread compromises some of Annihilape’s Speed to invest into more bulk. It still outspeeds Garchomp at -1 and certain sets of Dragonite, and lives Dragapult’s Choice Band Fairy Tera Blast on a roll.

Abilities

  • Vital Spirit: Vital Spirit adds to Annihilape’s reliability as a lead. Immunity to sleep moves from common Pokemon such as Breloom, Brute Bonnet, Dondozo, Hippowdon, and Skeledirge lets Annihilape thrive.

  • Defiant: Defiant is a strong option. While Intimidate Pokemon are far from common from the format, Defiant can take advantage of an opposing Annihilape’s speed control moves.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Annihilape has enough Speed to surprise important threats with Choice Scarf, such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Meowscarada.

  • Shadow Claw versus Rage Fist: Shadow Claw is weak, but it's a reliable Ghost-type STAB move that can reliably OHKO Flutter Mane even when using minimum Attack investment. If you can manage to get Annihilape into a weak attack, though, Rage Fist has much more reward associated with it.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch deals massive damage to Garchomp and Dragonite, making them easier to pick off or pressuring them to Terastallize.

  • Final Gambit: If using maximum HP, Final Gambit can potentially OHKO major defensive threats if Annihilape is healthy, such as Garganacl and Corviknight.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Close Combat does outrageous damage, with Rotom-W in particular taking over 90% from it.

  • Ghost: A Ghost Tera type makes Shadow Claw OHKO Dragapult, as well as giving it a 56.3% chance of OHKOing 4 HP Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: This simple EV spread is best when not using Final Gambit to maximize offensive power.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe: While maximizing HP makes Annihilape a less reliable revenge killer, it can effectively sacrifice itself with Final Gambit to get surprise KOs on certain defensive foes, like Corviknight and Garganacl.

Abilities

  • Vital Spirit: The immunity to Spore gives Annihilape a good opportunity to switch into Breloom, and it need not worry about Yawn.

  • Defiant: While Intimidate is not particularly common, punishing that and Speed drops can lead to devastating surprise sweeps.

vgc2023.overview:
• Annihilape is a great Bulk Up user in Series 1 thanks to its unresisted STAB combination, good bulk, Rage Fist, and Defiant, which stops Attack drops from slowing down its clean up.

  • It can also utilize Choice Scarf to good effect, using Final Gambit as an immediate one-on-one trade option.

  • Rage Fist increases in power every time Annihilape is hit, making it a deadly move during longer games thanks to its good natural bulk.

  • Annihilape sports positive matchups versus much of the metagame, including, but not limited to, Maushold, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada. Additionally, its Defiant can be used to deter Intimidate Pokemon such as Arcanine and Gyarados, allowing strong ally physical attackers such as Garchomp and Gyarados to thrive.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• To set up with Bulk Up safely, Annihilape enjoys dual screens and redirection support from Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl and Amoonguss.

  • Tera Blast is used to KO Steel-types Drain Punch does not hit super effectively, such as Gholdengo, without relying on Rage Fist being boosted.

  • The Fire Tera type gives Annihilape an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Talonflame and a key resistance to Fairy and neutrality to Ghost and Psychic, useful against opposing Annihilape, Meowscarada, and Armarouge. Furthermore, it lets Annihilape effectively combat Trick Room because, when played under dual screens, Annihilape can counter major Trick Room threats like Hatterene and Tera Fire Torkoal. Alternatively, picking Tera Water focuses on defensive advantages, primarily resistances to Steel- and Fire-type moves such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Torkoal's STAB moves.

  • Vital Spirit can be used instead of Defiant for mainly Amoonguss, but also other sleep move users like Yawn Sylveon and Hypnosis Gothitelle.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• This set is used commonly on Trick Room teams. Annihilape outspeeding most Pokemon, OHKOing them with Final Gambit, and being immune to Fake Out helps teammates like Hatterene and Armarouge set Trick Room, and fainting gives a free switch-in to a slow Trick Room beneficiary such as Tera Fire Torkoal. U-turn provides a switch-in without sacrificing Annihilape, and, while it doesn't OHKO, it hits common Pokemon such as Oranguru and Indeedee-F for large amounts of damage.

  • Shadow Claw is a consistent damage-dealing option that doesn't rely on foes to power it up. However, Rage Fist can still be utilized effectively thanks to Annihilape's bulk. Phantom Force avoids attacks and ignores protecting moves, giving Annihilape opportunities to deal unavoidable damage.

  • While not normally Terastallized, Annihilape can use Tera Ghost to remove its Fairy weakness and give a huge boost to its Ghost-type move, which becomes able to heavily dent much of the metagame.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Annihilape's amazing bulk and the fantastic Rage Fist make it an amazing late-game wincon and wallbreaker. Bulk Up makes it harder for foes such as Great Tusk and Dragonite to break through it, as well as allowing it to break through defensive Pokemon like Buzzwole and Mega Scizor. Taunt prevents status, recovery, and set up from Pokemon like Skeledirge, Mega Scizor, and Landorus-T while also forcing foes to damage Annihilape, boosting the power of Rage Fist. Rage Fist lacks no switch-in once boosted up and allows Annihilape to demolish Pokemon that wouldn't mind it unboosted, such as Gholdengo and Mega Scizor. It also notably invalidates Unaware, enabling it to break through Pokemon like Clodsire and Skeledirge. Drain Punch provides Annihilape with some additional recovery, preventing it from being worn down quickly. Rest combined with Chesto Berry can be used over Taunt, as it provides Annihilape with a one-time way to recover HP and status, as well as being the premier way to heal from strong incoming hits, but it can be easily exploited if the foe is able to chip down Annihilape enough. Tera Water is the premier option, as it boosts Annihilape's defensive profile, giving it resists to moves like Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes and Gholdengo's Make It Rain. Fairy is another option that gives Annihilape nice resistances to moves like Mega Lopunny's Close Combat and an immunity to Draco Meteor or Dragon Darts from Dragapult. Tera Fire gives Annihilape an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Skeledirge and Rotom-W while giving it a Fairy resistance as well, preventing the likes of Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant from revenge killing it. Notably, all of these types give Annihilape a Flying- and Ghost-type neutrality, preventing Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Gholdengo from revenge killing it as easily. 28 Speed EVs help Annihilape outspeed Pokemon such as Mega Tyranitar, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W. The other EVs maximize its special bulk, letting it take hits comfortably from Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Dual screens setters like Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl let Annihilape tank hits more easily. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Heatran to wear down Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele is appreciated. Allies like Heatran and Tyranitar handle Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Tornadus-T, with Annihilape cleaning up once the aformentioned threats are removed.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Lead
sets.description: Annihilape carves a niche in being a Stealth Rock user that is immune to Rapid Spin from foes like Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Annihilape being a Defog deterrent due to Defiant, as well as its bulk and Final Gambit picking up easy KOs also strengthens this niche. Final Gambit lets Annihilape safely bring in a teammate while dealing massive damage due to its large HP stat. Taunt denies other entry hazards from being set up by Pokemon like Ting-Lu and preventing the use of Defog from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T on the switch. Defog can also activate Defiant, giving Annihilape way more offensive output for Rage Fist and making it easier to pick up a KO. Annihilape won't be Terastallizing often, but Tera Ghost can be used to boost the power of Rage Fist in scenarios where it is boosted, and it gives Annihilape neutralities to moves like Mega Diancie's Moonblast and Tornadus-T's Hurricane or Bleakwind Storm. Annihilape fits on hyper offense exclusively, so Pokemon that benefit from entry hazards being simultaneously denied and set up, such as Iron Valiant and Dragonite, are good partners. Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Mega Diancie are very big problems for Annihilape, so partners like Gholdengo and Mega Scizor are very valuable. Final Gambit removing Pokemon like Great Tusk and Tornadus-T can also be a big help to teammates like Kingambit and Dragonite.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Clodsire's special bulk combined with its Ground typing makes it one of the best answers to Miraidon, notably thanks to its ability to absorb Toxic Spikes, which would otherwise trouble other defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu.
  • Toxic prevents Clodsire from being overly passive and allows it to outlast Iron Bundle.
  • Clodsire is a decent setter of both Spikes and Stealth Rock, freeing up moveslots on teammates like Great Tusk. However, opposing spinners as well as Corviknight have very little issue removing entry hazards against Clodsire.
  • Water Absorb is the preferred ability, as it deters Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump and more comfortably tanks Draco Meteor from Miraidon, since Unaware would otherwise ignore the Draco Meteor special attack drop. It also checks Tera Water Miraidon, which is an important trait it possesses over Ting-Lu. Unaware checks non-Life Orb Calm Mind Miraidon while beating Calm Mind + Taunt Flutter Mane, as well as making Iron Moth's Fiery Dance boosts less of a threat.
  • Clodsire can use Tera Steel to take Miraidon's Draco Meteor far more easily while being able to take on Iron Bundle's STAB moves in conjunction with Water Absorb.
  • Both defensive and balanced teams enjoy Clodsire answering most Miraidon sets, helping fend off Flutter Mane, freeing up moveslots on other entry hazard setters, and pressuring opposing defensive Pokemon with Toxic.
  • Dondozo pairs with Clodsire nicely, as it appreciates Clodsire's ability to switch in on Miraidon's Electro Drift, while Dondozo can take on Chien-Pao and Great Tusk for it.

sets.name: Toxic Spikes (Ground)
sets.description:
Due to its remarkable bulk, unique dual-typing, and two great abilities, Clodsire is a mainstay on Ground teams. Water Absorb stops common Water-type threats like Quaquaval, Dondozo, and Pelipper in their tracks, while Unaware walls setup sweepers such as Gholdengo, Mimikyu, and Volcarona. Poison Jab hits threats like Meowscarada, Rotom-C, and Iron Valiant, while Gunk Shot provides more power against bulkier foes such as Hatterene and Azumarill. Toxic Spike eases the Dark and Fairy matchups due to their lack of entry hazard removal and applies pressure on teams in general, completing Ground's entry hazard stacking core. Toxic may be used instead to punish Pokemon like Rotom-W and Hydreigon, which freely switch-in to Clodsire otherwise. The given EV spread avoids the 2HKO from both Choice Scarf Greninja's Ice Beam and Choice Scarf Meowscarada's Flower Trick.

Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu appreciate Clodsire checking the aforementioned Water-types as well as other threats such as Iron Valiant and Flutter Mane. In return, Choice Scarf Great Tusk pressures Ice- and Dark-types like Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Choice Specs Greninja. Iron Treads clears entry hazards and threatens Hatterene, and Ting-Lu sets up entry hazards and switches into Psychic-type attacks from Espathra and Indeedee. Unaware Clodsire synergizes very well with Gastrodon, as it checks the aforementioned Grass-types, while Gastrodon switches into Water-type attacks from Dondozo and Barraskewda. Sandy Shocks threatens Flying-types like Corviknight and Pelipper and secures the Fire matchup. Quagsire pairs well with Water Absorb Clodsire, as it checks Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Great Tusk. Furthermore, Quagsire is capable of using Toxic to free up a moveslot for Toxic Spike on Clodsire, expanding the team's hazard stacking ability.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Poison)
sets.description:
Due to its exceptional Special Defense and ability in Unaware, Clodsire is a wall that checks threats like Hydreigon, Volcarona, and Flutter Mane for Poison teams. Earthquake lets it chip down and eventually beat threats like Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Gholdengo, while Low Kick deals with the aforementioned Nasty Plot Hydreigon and can heavily damage Kingambit in a pinch. Spikes lets Clodsire take advantage of forced switches and synergizes well with Glimmora, Toxapex, and Skuntank, all together forming Poison's entry hazard-stacking core. Alternatively, Curse turns Clodsire into a threatening wincon and lets it deal with physical attackers.

Amoonguss and Toxapex are physically defensive walls that complement Clodsire, as they take on threats such as Great Tusk, Scizor, and Quaquaval, which force Clodsire out. Amoonguss can also run Growth, which helps in the Ground matchup, while Toxapex also chips down the opposing team by setting Toxic Spikes and wearing down threats like Chien-Pao with Infestation, Baneful Bunker, and Rocky Helmet. Skuntank is a Psychic-immune teammate that switches into Hatterene, Espathra, and Indeedee, and it can set Toxic Spikes better against types like Fairy and Psychic by trapping switch-ins such as Klefki and Bronzong with Fire Spin. Glimmora provides entry hazard support and removal with Stealth Rock and Mortal Spin, respectively, and it can run Air Balloon or Choice Scarf to handle Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads due to its great coverage. Glimmora can also run Corrosion with Toxic and Mortal Spin, improving the Poison matchup and putting defensive Pokemon such as opposing Clodsire and Amoongus on a timer. Iron Moth is another plausible Choice Scarf user, as it handles Steel- and Dragon-types like Iron Treads and Baxcalibur, though it can also run a set with Substitute to handle Kingambit and break down types such as Flying and Water better.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big new changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• While Clodsire is lacking in physical bulk compared to Dondozo and Skeledirge, it makes up for it in having a fantastic support movepool.

  • Yawn: Yawn is very effective at forcing switches, which is especially dangerous if Stealth Rock is set up.

  • Protect: In addition to benefiting from Leftovers, Protect pairs well with Yawn.

  • Low Kick: This prevents Clodsire from being totally walled by Tera Steel Hydreigon.

  • Amnesia: With Amnesia, Clodsire has a far better match-up against powerful special attacking foes such as Hydreigon and Iron Bundle.

  • Black Sludge versus Leftovers: Black Sludge may seem appealing, but it punishes Clodsire for Terastalliizing unless it becomes Tera Poison, so Leftovers is preferred unless Leftovers is already on something else.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Clodsire no longer has to worry about Earthquake or Fissure.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type allows Clodsire to take on powerful Dragon-type attacks, without the worry of Gholdengo dealing massive damage.

  • Poison: With Tera Poison, Clodsire not only becomes a better check to Grass- and Water-types such as Meowscarda and Rotom-W, but it can also safely run Black Sludge to punish users of Trick.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type will stop powerful Dragon-type attacks cold without making Clodsire weak to Earthquake, but it comes at the cost of compromising its ability to check Gholdengo.

  • Dark: Espathra's Stored Power is a big issue for Clodsire, so Tera Dark can flip the tables on it.

Abilities

  • Unaware: If you're planning to use Clodsire to its fullest defensive potential, Unaware is the best bet against setup foes.

  • Water Absorb: Water Absorb sacrifices overall defensive potential in exchange for being able to wall Rotom-W without needing to Terastallize. If setting up Stealth Rock is important, this can be worth it.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: Maximizing Special Defense is Clodsire's best hope for handling powerful special attackers such as Choice Specs Hydreigon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: Clodsire's Defense may be mediocre, but with maximum investment, it can pull stunts such as usually avoiding a 2HKO from Jolly Dragonite's Outrage with Leftovers.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: A unique defensive typing, reliable recovery, and remarkable special bulk enhanced by Vessel of Ruin allow Clodsire to check prominent special attackers like Iron Moth and Gengar. Toxic can cripple non-grounded Pokemon such as Dragonite as well as Heavy-Duty Boots users like Volcarona and Kilowattrel. Toxic Spikes and Poison Jab are better on Prankster sets to punish Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu; in particular, Toxic Spikes lets Clodsire match up well against hyper offense teams filled with setup sweepers. Prankster + Haze allows Clodsire to shut down setup sweepers, like Volcarona and Polteageist, while they whittle down from poison damage. Pokemon like Garganacl and Scream Tail form a hazard-stacking core with Clodsire, and Good as Gold spinblockers like Skeledirge make great teammates as well. Physical walls like the aforementioned Pokemon, Corviknight, and Dondozo handle physical threats such as Dragonite and Earth Eater Kingambit that can exploit Clodsire's poor physical bulk.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description: Clodsire serves as a fantastic special wall, able to take on powerful attackers such as Dragapult and Mega Diancie while simultaneously stopping setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Volcarona. Spikes are preferred on Clodsire, as the move has more limited distribution and Clodsire enters the field commonly enough to have the opportunity to use the move. However, Stealth Rock can be used if Clodsire's team requires it. Toxic is used to cripple common switch-ins to Clodsire, such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Great Tusk. Poison Jab can be used to poison post-Tera Gholdengo attempting to remove its Ground weakness, and it forces damage on Tornadus-T faster. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on Clodsire to negate its weakness to opposing Spikes teams, although Leftovers are also viable to increase Clodsire's longevity. Unaware is preferred over Water Absorb to negate Clodsire's passivity against setup sweepers, and Water Absorb does little to help against the likes of Mega Swampert and Gastrodon. Tera Dark grants Clodsire a Ghost resistance, which helps against Choice Specs Dragapult and Gholdengo, especially if using Poison Jab against the latter. It also grants Clodsire with a Pursuit resistance against the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, which can both exploit its physical frailty. Clodsire fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its special walling and entry hazard support. As Clodsire is weak to most physical attackers such as Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Dragonite, teammates that can cover them, such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Buzzwole, make for good partners. In return, Clodsire can switch into Electric-type attacks for the former, and powerful special attackers such as Dragapult for the latter two. Pokemon that benefit from Spikes support, such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo, also pair well with Clodsire, as Spikes puts pressure on checks to them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar. In return, Clodsire appreciates these teammates being able to make more immediate progress. Knock Off users such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T as well as Weavile and Mega Scizor pair well with Clodsire, crippling Heavy-Duty Boots users such as opposing Clodsire and Toxapex, giving Clodsire's entry hazards support a greater impact.

vgc2023.overview:
• Farigiraf is currently one of the bulkiest Trick Room setters in the meta. Its ability, Armor Tail, prevents its teammates from succumbing to priority moves, making it difficult to prevent Farigiraf from setting Trick Room.

  • Hariyama, Amoonguss, and Kingambit are good partners for Farigiraf. Hariyama and Farigiraf both benefit from each other, as Fake Out allows Farigiraf to more consistently get up Trick Room, which enables Hariyama, as it thrives inside of Trick Room and checks Farigiraf's common counters. Amoonguss can redirect moves targeted at Farigiraf and Spore anything inside Trick Room to take them out of the game. Kingambit benefits from the Snarl that Farigiraf struggles against and plays well in Trick Room.

  • Choice Band Meowscarada and Hydreigon are the biggest checks to Farigiraf, as both threaten to OHKO it. Amoonguss is another check, as it can Spore Farigiraf before it manages to get Trick Room up. It also struggles against Imprison from Indeedee, Gallade, and opposing Farigiraf.

sets.name: Bulky Trick Room
sets.description:
• Hyper Voice is a decently strong Normal-type STAB move for Farigiraf to spread chip damage that softens up opponents for its allies.
