Psyshock tackles common Psychic-weak Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Gengar, whereas Dazzling Gleam improves its matchup into common checks like Meowscarada and Hydreigon. Helping Hand allows Farigiraf to supplement a harder hitting teammate's damage output. Imprison is used on fast offensive teams that would otherwise struggle against opposing Trick Room teams.

  • Safety Goggles provides an immunity to Spore from Amoonguss and Breloom, who would otherwise prevent Trick Room from going up with it. Sitrus Berry gives Farigiraf longevity with recovery. Colbur Berry allows Farigiraf to consistently get Trick Room up in the face of Meowscarada and Hydreigon.

  • For other notable items, Mental Herb prevents fast Taunt users like Talonflame from interrupting Farigiraf's Trick Room. Life Orb or Throat Spray are good options to improve Farigiraf's already decent damage output. Rocky Helmet can also be used for an answer to unsuspecting Maushold.

  • 180 EVs in HP allow Farigiraf to survive maximum HP Annihilape Final Gambit, and the defensive investment allows it to always survive Tera Steel Choice Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain and Focus Sash Meowscarada Knock Off.

  • Tera Fairy is more of a defensive Tera type, giving it a resistance to all the types that Farigiraf was previously weak to while gaining STAB on Dazzling Gleam. Tera Normal adds damage onto Hyper Voice and removes its Dark weakness.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Supreme Overlord Kingambit is a terrifying revenge killer and sweeper. Dark / Steel is a great offensive typing that can hit Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Gholdengo, Dragapult, Garganacl, and Iron Valiant super effectively as well as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Corviknight neutrally. Tera Flying completely reverses Kingambit's weaknesses and resistances and can catch Pokemon looking to KO Kingambit with Fighting- and Ground-type moves like Iron Valiant and Great Tusk, off guard. Alternatively, Kingambit can opt for Tera Ghost to better counter Tera Normal Dragonite, as Earthquake becomes neutral against Kingambit and Extreme Speed is ineffective. Similarly, Tera Fairy can be chosen because Kingambit then resists Roaring Moon's Crunch, which cannot OHKO Kingambit without Tera Steel. Kingambit chooses to run 144 Speed EVs to reliably outspeed Corviknight and Swords Dance Iron Hands; the rest of its investment is in HP to maximize bulk.

Kingambit fits very well on hyper and bulky offense teams, as it works very well coming in after its teammates have fallen, such as Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, Breloom, and Dragonite. On hyper offense particularly, Grimmsnarl and Glimmora both work as great leads that set up screens and entry hazards, respectively. Kingambit checks opposing offensive Pokemon such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Meowscarada thanks to its defensive typing but loses out against revenge killers such as Breloom and other threats like Calm Mind Iron Valiant, Iron Hands, Dodonzo, and Great Tusk; as such, Kingambit appreciates defensive support from Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W and offensive support from Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Dragapult.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Supreme Overlord makes Kingambit a threatening late-game sweeper and revenge killer.
  • 144 Speed EVs allow Kingambit to outspeed uninvested Alomomola, Skeledirge, and Corviknight.
  • Tera Flying allows Kingambit to survive otherwise super effective hits from Great Tusk, Iron Treads, non-Choice Band Koraidon, and Annihilape, allowing it to set up or dent these threats with a strong attack. Tera Ghost may be used to grant immunity to Fighting-type moves without a weakness to Ice-type attacks from Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao.
  • Teammates such as defensive Great Tusk, Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Toxapex are good checks to physical threats like Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Special walls such as Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire check fast special attackers like Miraidon and Iron Bundle while setting entry hazards for Kingambit. Setting entry hazards and spreading status is especially crucial, as most Kingambit checks have no viable recovery options.
  • Strong wallbreakers like Koraidon, offensive Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao support Kingambit late-game. Choice Scarf Koraidon is an excellent partner, as it outspeeds and threatens Kingambit's checks, and together they are able to overwhelm most of their shared checks.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Steel)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Kingambit sets itself apart from most other Dark-types with its bulk and typing, which make it a reasonable check against Gholdengo that lack Focus Blast.

  • Guillotine: This makes Kingambit far more difficult to wall with foes such as Dondozo.

  • Low Kick versus Brick Break: Low Kick is Kingambit's best option against other Kingambit, though Brick Break's destruction of dual screens makes it a great lead against Scream Tail and Grimmsnarl.

Tera Types

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type makes Kingambit even harder to wall and removes its irritating Ground weakness.

  • Flying: This Tera type covers Kingambit's issues with Fighting- and Ground-type attacks very well.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type and Tera Blast, Kingambit can deal serious damage to Iron Hands and Great Tusk, but it becomes vulnerable to Gholdengo.

Abilities

  • Supreme Overload: This is generally the more consistent ability since Intimidate foes are not very common.

  • Defiant: Defiant is still useful for punishing speed control options such as Rock Tomb, especially alongside Sucker Punch.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe: This simple spread maximizes bulk and power.

  • 108 HP / 252 Atk / 148 Spe: This EV spread has enough Speed to outspeed most Corviknight and Skeledirge, and it still has enough bulk to survive one unboosted Body Press from Corviknight. Since this is a fairly congested Speed range, feel free to move some Attack EVs to Speed.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: Using maximum Speed might seem absurd on such a slow Pokemon, but outspeeding most Skeledirge, Corviknight, and opposing Kingambit can make this worth it.

Items

  • Black Glasses: While its boost to Dark-type attacks isn't as high as Life Orb's, Black Glasses is a better fit for Kingambit's bulk due to the lack of recoil.

  • Sitrus Berry: The burst of recovery helps Kingambit check Gholdengo better.

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest makes Kingambit a better check against Gholdengo and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Kingambit's excellent bulk and offensive presence make it a good, if unexpected, setter of Stealth Rock.

  • Brick Break Brick Break makes Kingambit an effective stop against screen setters such as Grimmsnarl and Scream Tail and does good damage against opposing Kingambit.

  • Thunder Wave: Thunder Wave isn't a particularly common move on Kingambit, potentially letting it ruin some sweepers such as Roaring Moon by surprise.

Other Options

  • Guillotine: With Guillotine, passive play from foes like Corviknight and Dondozo becomes far more risky.

  • Taunt: Taunt is effective at shutting down common support Pokemon such as Dondozo and Scream Tail.

  • Low Kick: While it doesn't offer as much support as Brick Break, Low Kick deals far more damage to Tera Normal Dragonite and opposing Kingambit.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Fairy Blast is Kingambit's best shot against Iron Hands, one of its biggest checks. It also makes sense with Tera Flying to hit Great Tusk hard.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying covers Kingambit's Fighting- and Ground-type weaknesses, making it do especially well against Great Tusk leads that lack Ice Spinner.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy can help prevent Iron Hands, one of the best Kingambit checks in the game, from OHKOing it.

  • Dark: When using Sucker Punch, Tera Dark gives Kingambit some late-game cleaning potential.

Items

  • Black Glasses: Kingambit's bulk and support options make Black Glasses a preferable option over Life Orb for more power, especially when using Sucker Punch.

  • Chople Berry: Chople Berry eases Kingambit's devastating Fighting-type weakness, though note powerful STAB users of Close Combat such as Iron Hands require massive Defense investment to survive.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry's quick burst of recovery keeps Kingambit more relevant in the later stages of the game.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash will let Kingambit survive even the strongest Fighting-type attacks, if Stealth Rock desperately needs to be set up.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's constant recovery is a decent alternative to Sitrus Berry if another teammate is already using it.

Abilities

  • Supreme Overlord: Even though this Kingambit is often set out early-game to set up Stealth Rock, Supreme Overlord gives it the flexibility to function later in the game if Stealth Rock isn't needed or if it manages to set up Stealth Rock without much harm to itself.

  • Defiant: Besides punishing the rare use of Intimidate, Defiant lets Kingambit switch well into Pokemon that commonly use attacks that drop Speed, such as Scream Tail, and makes Parting Shot Grimmsnarl easier to punish when Kingambit is Terastallized.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 244 Atk / 12 Def: If you're using Chople Berry, the extra Defense EVs let Kingambit survive Focus Sash Iron Valiant's Close Combat.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: Maximizing Speed lets Kingambit get the jump on opposing Kingambit and slower variants of Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Iron Hands.

sets.name: Type Immunity
sets.description: Kingambit's good bulk and excellent typing allow it to check dangerous attackers like Gholdengo, Polteageist, and, with the correct ability, Volcarona and Dragonite. While every team appreciates Stealth Rock, Kingambit can use Swords Dance + Sucker Punch to pressure offensive and defensive checks alike. Alternatively, Kingambit can shut down Toxapex, Dondozo, and Ting-Lu with Taunt. Well-Baked Body counters Iron Moth and non-Mold Breaker Chi-Yu, while Earth Eater checks Iron Treads, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu. 140 Speed EVs outspeeds uninvested Corviknight. Spinners like Iron Treads and priority-fearing setup sweepers like Quaquaval gladly let Kingambit take on any Ghost-types or Triage Hatterene blocking their way to victory. Of the same token, Kingambit loves having Ghost-types like Gholdengho or reliable Fighting-type switch-ins like Scream Tail on its team; Kingambit also always appreciates a Water-type or Primordial Sea user if running Earth Eater and Corviknight if running Well-Baked Body.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit is a dangerous wallbreaker, owing to great base stats and Adaptability. After using Swords Dance, Kingambit threatens the entire tier, including incredibly bulky physical walls such as Fluffy Corviknight and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster threats, such as Cinderace and Barraskewda, making it difficult to check offensively. Life Orb provides the highest damage boost to Kingambit's attacks; alternatively, Black Glasses provides a damage boost without digging into Kingambit's limited healthpool, while Leftovers allows Kingambit to reliably switch in on weaker attacks. Kingambit best fits on offense teams, which appreciate its massive damage output and can provide opportunities for it to switch in safely. Slow pivoting teammates, such as RegenVest Iron Treads and Corviknight, are recommended, as they can safely pivot Kingambit in and also clear entry hazards. 144 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight, who may carry Body Press which threatens Kingambit.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Kingambit positions itself as a wallbreaker and late-game sweeper thanks to its signature ability in Supreme Overlord. Sucker Punch allows Kingambit to threaten faster opponents and would-be revenge killers such as Tornadus-T, Volcarona, and Mega Medicham. Tera Dark lets Kingambit strengthen its wallbreaking capabilities against bulkier teams. Tera Flying instead lets it play around potential revenge killers, putting them in checkmate situations by turning its Fighting and Ground weaknesses into resistances. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed Skeledirge. Entry hazard leads such as Glimmora, Landorus-T, and Annihilape help Kingambit power through its checks by punishing switches. Kingambit is susceptible to faster Fighting-type Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Mega Lopunny, and Urshifu-R, as they will not succumb to a boosted Sucker Punch. Thus, wallbreakers like Dragapult, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant that punish foes for using Fighting-type moves help form solid offensive cores; they can also pressure bulky Steel-types that check Kingambit, such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Heatran. In return, Kingambit helps check Psychic-, Ghost-, and Fairy-types, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Pursuit
sets.description: Kingambit is a potent Pursuit trapper, utilizing its great bulk to defensively check and trap Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Tapu Lele, as well as accrue chip damage on Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Clodsire that are forced out by it. Knock Off allows Kingambit to function as a decent wallbreaker while crippling switch-ins like Ting-Lu and Ferrothorn. Sucker Punch makes up for Kingambit's poor Speed tier, letting it revenge kill faster threats such as Volcarona and Mega Charizard Y, and it can potentially clean late-game if it acquires multiple Supreme Overlord boosts. Tera Dark boosts Kingambit's damage output, letting it threaten post-Tera Dragapult and Gholdengo and clean late-game with Sucker Punch. Defiant is an option to punish Defog attempts from Tornadus-T and Gliscor and punish Intimidate from Landorus-T, letting it wallbreak better, but it is less consistent. Black Glasses boosts Kingambit's already threatening STAB Dark-type moves, allowing it to break more easily, while Leftovers gives Kingambit passive recovery, patching up its lack of longevity. The given EV spread allows Kingambit to outspeed Skeledirge to Knock Off, with the rest in bulk in order to take hits from Dragapult and Gholdengo better. Due to its trapping capabilities, partners that appreciate Ghost- and Psychic-types gone such as Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult work really well with it. While its bulk is great, its lack of longevity leaves it easily worn down in the long-term, so having a solid defensive core utilizing Pokemon such as Toxapex, Slowking-G, Gastrodon, and Rotom-W to help it check threats is key. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Mega Diancie, and Garchomp have great synergy with Kingambit, as it removes items from common defensive Pokemon, wearing them down quickly by the entry hazards set. Defiant sets in particular work extremely well, as they are able to punish Defog attempts, threatening to turn Kingambit into a dangerous wallbreaker.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Great Tusk is the best offensive Rapid Spin user and a fantastic wallbreaker thanks to its typing, bulk, and high-Base Power STAB attacks. Great Tusk takes on a plethora of physical attackers in the tier, including Kingambit, Garchomp, and Scizor while also threatening entry hazard setters such as Glimmora, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Garganacl. Knock Off prevents Air Balloon Gholdengo from completely spinblocking Great Tusk, and it also removes items such as Rocky Helmet, Leftovers, and Heavy-Duty Boots from defensive Pokemon that commonly switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo, Corviknight, and Hatterene. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk take on Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Garchomp more easily, though the lack of Close Combat leaves Great Tusk walled by Corviknight and Rotom-W. Maximum Speed investment paired with a Jolly nature ensures that Great Tusk is able to outspeed Rotom-W, non-Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Jolly Dragonite. Tera Fighting makes Great Tusk much better at taking on Water-types such as Quaquaval while making Close Combat significantly harder to switch into; alternatively, Tera Steel lets Great Tusk flip its type weaknesses and take on Pokemon like Iron Valiant, and Tera Flying Roaring Moon. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Great Tusk from being worn down by Toxic Spikes and Spikes, letting it remove entry hazards consistently throughout a match; however, Leftovers provides Great Tusk with a form of recovery. Booster Energy is a niche option that provides Great Tusk with a one-time boost to its Attack, making it an immediately threatening wallbreaker without the use of Terastallization.

Great Tusk takes on Dark-type Pokemon such as Kingambit, and Ting-Lu, so Pokemon weak to Dark such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, Slowking, and Skeledirge appreciate Great Tusk; Slowking and Dragapult in particular are able to pivot in Great Tusk with Chilly Reception and U-turn, respectively. Great Tusk is also able to take on entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Garchomp and remove entry hazards from the field, so Pokemon that can be overwhelmed by hazards such as Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl appreciate Great Tusk's presence. Great Tusk struggles to take on faster special attackers such as Iron Valiant, Dragapult, and Volcarona, so special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Toxapex are great partners. Great Tusk also has difficulty with physical walls such as Dondozo, Tera Water and Tera Fairy Garganacl, and Tera Fairy Skeledirge. Spikes support from Ting-Lu, Glimmora, and Garchomp wears down these checks into range of Great Tusk's attacks, especially when paired with Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, Iron Hands, and Breloom make for good partners by being able to overwhelm shared checks; Gholdengo is a noteworthy wallbreaker for also blocking opposing hazard removal. Torkoal is also an excellent partner for Great Tusk, setting up the sun to activate Protosynthesis and weaken Water-type attacks, while supporting other wallbreakers that can pressure the aforementioned physical walls, such as Choice Band Roaring Moon, Scovillain, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Great Tusk has a solid niche as a defensive Pokemon by virtue of its utility, movepool, bulk, and typing. It can adequately check Pokemon like Kingambit, Cinderace, and Iron Hands, threatening them with a strong Earthquake in return. Stealth Rock lets Great Tusk compress even more roles, chipping away at the opposition. If another Stealth Rock user is already on the team, however, Body Press can take advantage of its high Defense stat and better threaten the likes of Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon. Body Press also lets Great Tusk catch Rotom-W with greater chip damage than Knock Off does on the switch. Knock Off provides valuable item removal, getting rid of Leftovers from Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Hatterene, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from Volcarona and Dragonite. Additionally, Knock Off is Great Tusk's only initial way to hit Air Balloon Gholdengo, which can't OHKO this defensive set. Rapid Spin, besides clearing entry hazards, also allows Great Tusk to outspeed faster foes like Focus Sash Glimmora and Gholdengo. Tera Fighting gets rid of Great Tusk's Ground typing, giving it a better matchup against Pokemon like Quaquaval and Floatzel while also strengthening Body Press if it is used. Alternatively, Tera Steel can give Great Tusk valuable resistances to Fairy, and Grass, turning the tables on Hatterene and Meowscarada. Leftovers greatly increases Great Tusk's longevity; however, Rocky Helmet can be used to wear down Pokemon like Scizor and Cinderace over time.

After Great Tusk sets Stealth Rock, Corviknight effortlessly switches in and uses Defog to remove entry hazards, so Pokemon like Cinderace, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W that handle it are great partners. With no good way to hit Flying-types and Pokemon that use Tera Flying, Great Tusk can be set up on very quickly, most notably against the likes of Dragonite and Roaring Moon;even though the former dislikes Knock Off. Therefore, checks to these such as Dondozo and Corviknight are appreciated. A different Stealth Rock setter like Garganacl or Ting-Lu lets Great Tusk comfortably run Body Press without losing out on anything major. Ting-Lu also forms a potent entry hazard-stacking core with Great Tusk via Spikes. Further, it takes on the special attackers that Great Tusk struggles with, like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Volcarona. Great Tusk is forced out by wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Quaquaval, so teammates that can check them like Amoonguss and Toxapex are welcome. Pokemon like Ceruledge, and Iron Moth appreciate the entry hazard removal that Great Tusk provides. Great Tusk's defensive qualities greatly help frail wallbreakers like Dragapult, and Iron Valiant, as these Pokemon need strong defensive Pokemon to fall back on very often.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
The combination of high Attack, powerful STAB moves, a decent movepool, and well-rounded physical bulk allows Great Tusk to function as a strong physical wallbreaker. It can support teams offensively with Knock Off and Rapid Spin as well as defensively through its ability to check Kingambit, Cinderace, and Choice Band Roaring Moon. Its dual STAB moves are able to OHKO or severely damage several key offensive Pokemon in the metagame such as Kingambit, and Tera Normal Dragonite. Knock Off allows Great Tusk to remove Leftovers from walls such as Corviknight and Dondozo. It can also remove important items from more offensive Pokemon, such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Dragonite, Volcarona, and bulky pivot Roaring Moon, and it can provide coverage against Air Balloon Gholdengo, which otherwise checks this set. Ice Spinner hits Dragon-types that Headlong Rush isn't as strong against like bulky Garchomp and Dragonite. Alternatively, Rapid Spin can be run if the team is still in need of entry hazard removal. With Tera Fighting, Close Combat becomes much stronger, guaranteeing OHKOs against offensive Scizor sets. Tera Fighting also improves Great Tusk's matchups against Dondozo, Rotom-W, and opposing Great Tusk. With Tera Steel, Great Tusk can better handle Grass- and Fairy-types such as Meowscarada and Hatterene, and it can also shrug off attacks it normally can't, such as Meowscarada's Flower Trick and Dragapult's Draco Meteor. When running Great Tusk on sun teams, an alternate EV spread making Speed its highest stat can be considered due to Protosynthesis boosting Speed; this allows Great Tusk to outspeed otherwise faster Pokemon like Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

Rotom-W, Skeledirge, and Torkoal make for good teammates, since their status spreading can help weaken foes and help Great Tusk wallbreak more efficiently. Rotom-W is able to paralyze faster Pokemon such as Iron Valiant and boosted Quaquaval, allowing Great Tusk to outspeed them. Skeledirge is able to spread burn, capitalize on foes afflicted with status with a boosted Hex, and check Iron Valiant sets lacking Shadow Ball. Lastly, Torkoal is able to force switches thanks to Yawn, spread status with Lava Plume, and set up sun to make Great Tusk an even scarier wallbreaker. Great Tusk appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Garganacl and Ting-Lu, since it can wallbreak more easily thanks to the chip damage they provide. Great Tusk is able to keep their hazards up in exchange while simultaneously removing hazards set by foes. Sweepers that are vulnerable to hazards like Iron Moth and Tera Flying Roaring Moon appreciate Great Tusk being able to remove hazards and beat walls such as Ting-Lu, allowing them to sweep more easily late-game. Lastly, other offensive Pokemon such as Kingambit and Dragonite make for good partners, since Great Tusk is able to weaken or cripple their common checks in Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Bulk Up Great Tusk can act as both a defensive backbone and a potential late-game sweeper, able to set up in front of Pokemon such as Dragonite, Iron Treads, Cinderace, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and opposing Great Tusk. Knock Off provides item removal against defensive walls like Dondozo and Corviknight, as well as coverage against Air Balloon Gholdengo that would otherwise wall Great Tusk. Rapid Spin lets Great Tusk provide entry hazard removal for the team in games where it would not be able to win with Bulk Up, while allowing it to boost its Speed in games where it can sweep with Bulk Up. Body Press is another option that gives Great Tusk a way to more immediately hit Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu. Tera Water turns Great Tusk's Water and Ice weaknesses into resistances, allowing it to better take hits from Azumarill, Quaquaval, and Floatzel. On the other hand, Tera Steel lets Great Tusk take on Grass-type attacks such as Breloom's Bullet Seed and Meowscarada's Flower Trick, Flying-type attacks like Roaring Moon's Acrobatics, and if need be, Fairy-type attacks such as Iron Valiant's Moonblast.

Bulk Up Great Tusk appreciates specially defensive teammates like Toxapex and Garganacl that can help play around fast special attackers such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Dragapult. In return, Garganacl and Toxapex appreciate the presence of a Terastallized Great Tusk as they can get overwhelmed by Kingambit and Belly Drum Azumarill. Teammates such as Gholdengo, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult can help break through physically defensive Pokemon like Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Skeledirge that Bulk Up Great Tusk can struggle against. Gholdengo in particular is a great partner, as it can struggle against Cinderace and Dragonite, both of which Great Tusk covers.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: These are samples sets while we work on new analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Tera Ground can turn Headlong Rush into a devastating STAB attack that can break through bulky targets Great Tusk normally wouldn’t, such as Scream Tail and Dondozo.
  • Tera Fighting lets Great Tusk crush Corviknight with Close Combat, which severely hurts defensive structures reliant on it. This opens up powerful teammates like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Earthquake makes Great Tusk harder to revenge kill than Headlong Rush does, as it doesn’t drop its defenses.
  • Rapid Spin works well for teams weak to entry hazards. It's a great way to support powerful threats weak to Stealth Rock, like Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle.
  • Knock Off provides fantastic item-removing support, and it especially cripples walls reliant on Leftovers like Scream Tail and Dondozo, allowing its team to more easily break past them.
  • Play Rough can be used to OHKO Koraidon without Terastallizing, as well as beating opposing Great Tusk. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk functions most effectively as a wallbreaker in the early- and mid-game, suited best for offensive structures that struggle with physical walls like the aforementioned Scream Tail and Dondozo. When building teams, remember Great Tusk must use Terastallization to actually break through said walls, so it may be hard for teammates to Terastallize.
  • Choice Band Great Tusk only functions well on Sticky Web teams, where the stronger and slower set appreciates Sticky Web dropping foes' Speed.
  • Koraidon is a great partner, setting up sun and activating Protosynthesis for Great Tusk. It further resists Water- and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, weakening the former. Koraidon also effectively baits in Skeledirge, which Great Tusk reliably threatens.
  • Miraidon is also a great partner, as it can threaten Flying-types, like Corviknight and the rarer Pelipper and Dragonite. This helps to make Great Tusk’s Headlong Rush much more spammable.
  • Gholdengo is also a good partner for Great Tusk, as it resists Ice-, Fairy-, and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, and it can threaten to KO Ice- and Fairy-types with super effective STAB Make It Rain. In addition, Gholdengo also blocks all hazard removal, helping to wear down walls for Great Tusk's team to eventually break through.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
• Great Tusk is the best offensive Stealth Rock or Rapid Spin user in the tier thanks to its solid typing and good physical bulk.
  • If Great Tusk is paired with Pokemon such as Corviknight, then Stealth Rock can be run instead of Rapid Spin. If paired with teammates that set Stealth Rock, then the best set would be Rapid Spin / Headlong Rush / Close Combat / Knock Off. Knock Off makes progress on Corviknight and covers the Air Balloon Gholdengo matchup.
  • Tera Ground lets Great Tusk deal incredible damage with Headlong Rush while also letting it survive Flutter Mane's Moonblast from full HP. Tera Steel flips the Fairy matchup and lets Great Tusk take on Ice- and Dragon-type attacks, but the additional weaknesses to Fighting and Ground make Great Tusk unable to take on Koraidon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads easily.
  • Great Tusk can be used to take on entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads one-on-one by forcing them out and removing hazards. Jolly is usually preferred to outspeed Gholdengo, Modest Chi-Yu, and Glimmora, but Adamant lets Tera Ground Headlong Rush OHKO Koraidon and specially defensive Annihilape after one layer of Spikes or Stealth Rock.
  • Great Tusk should be used aggressively to force out and keep entry hazards off the field against other setters, such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads, since Great Tusk is generally difficult to switch into. Great Tusk pairs well with Koraidon thanks to Orichalcum Pulse's sun, letting Great Tusk become an incredibly potent wallbreaker, and Great Tusk can clear entry hazards so that Koraidon can repeatedly come in. Miraidon also appreciates Great Tusk, as it forces out common checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads. Great Tusk also appreciates Blissey being able to take on all of the special attackers that force Great Tusk out, such as Flutter Mane, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Bulk Up allows Great Tusk to be a threatening sweeper. It can comfortably set up on common physical walls like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk.
  • The STAB combination of Headlong Rush and Close Combat hits most physical walls for at least neutral damage. Earthquake may be used as the Ground-type STAB move to avoid defensive drops, but it is a weaker move, and it can't secure important OHKOs and 2HKOs at +1 Attack against some physical walls such as Toxapex, Scream Tail, and Alomomola.
  • A Jolly nature is used to outspeed all viable unboosted Pokemon after one Rapid Spin. An Adamant nature makes Great Tusk stronger while still letting it outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle at +1 Speed, but it misses out on outspeeding maximum Speed Gholdengo and tying Jolly Great Tusk.
  • Terastallizing into the Ground typing boosts Headlong Rush and guarantees some additional OHKOs and 2HKOs on foes like Toxapex and Scream Tail. Additionally, getting rid of the Fighting typing lets Great Tusk survive Fairy-type attacks such as Dazzling Gleam from Miraidon and Moonblast from Flutter Mane without Life Orb or Choice Specs, and it facilitates taking Dazzling Gleam and Play Rough from Scream Tail and Alomomola.
  • Alternatively, using Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to Fairy-type attacks, Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, and Draco Meteor from Miraidon, allowing it to surprise them with a strong attack.
  • Koraidon is a solid partner because its sun activates Great Tusk's Protosynthesis, making its attacks even stronger. In return, Great Tusk can break through or strongly dent common Koraidon checks like Scream Tail, Alomomola, and Skeledirge, which allows Koraidon to clean more easily. Miraidon is also an excellent teammate, since Great Tusk can easily hard switch into its common checks and either threaten them with its attacks or set up on them.
  • Special attackers like Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle hugely threaten Great Tusk, so it is recommended to pair it with appropriate special walls like Blissey, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire. Gothitelle is a less popular pick but it helps eliminate bulky checks like Dondozo and Pelliper, allowing Great Tusk to sweep more easily.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Thanks to its solid physical bulk under sun and good defensive typing, Great Tusk acts as one of the best checks to Koraidon while also providing teams with entry hazard removal and a fantastic switch-in to other Ground-types in the tier such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads.
  • Play Rough threatens a KO on Koraidon after entry hazard damage. Knock Off can be used to take on Air Balloon Gholdengo and wear down foes that want to switch into Great Tusk such as Corviknight and Annihilape, but it is generally outclassed by the sheer utility of Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock. The combination of Knock Off and Body Press can be used to pressure Corviknight switch-ins. A set of Earthquake, Stealth Rock, Knock Off, and Rapid Spin can also be used for similar utility.
  • Great Tusk can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to take on physical attackers such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Palafin in sun. However, be wary of Terastallizing against Koraidon that can still Terastallize themselves, as Choice Band Tera Fire Koraidon can take on Great Tusk one-on-one. Great Tusk can also Terastallize into the Ground typing or the Water typing, with both options removing its weakness to Fairy. The former also lets it fire off stronger Earthquakes as well, while the latter provides useful resistances to Fire moves from Koraidon as well as Ice- and Water-type moves, barring Freeze-Dry, from Iron Bundle.
  • Great Tusk fits on most teams as a bulky Stealth Rock setter and Koraidon check. Great Tusk can utilize Rocky Helmet to punish the use of U-turn, though this hurts its longevity, as it then loses Leftovers's passive recovery.
  • Great Tusk pairs well with defensive Scream Tail and Blissey, both of which can take on Iron Bundle while also providing Wish support for Great Tusk. Blissey can also take on Chi-Yu and Miraidon, while Scream Tail can take on Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk also pairs well with Gholdengo, as it appreciates Great Tusk forcing out Koraidon while preventing hazard removal in exchange. Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a good partner due to its ability to pressure faster special attackers that trouble Great Tusk such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Great Tusk also pairs well with Miraidon, as non-Heavy-Duty Boots Miraidon appreciates it removing entry hazards and taking on Clodsire, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. Finally, Koraidon is a good partner, as it can set up sun, pivot into Great Tusk, and force out most hazard removal options besides opposing defensive Great Tusk.

sets.name: Offensive Utility (Fighting)
sets.description:
Boasting impressive bulk, Great Tusk is a physical wall for Fighting teams that can pivot in and out around hard hitting physical attackers such as Iron Hands and Kingambit. Earthquake is a powerful STAB move that threatens Poison-types such as Clodsire and Toxapex. Knock Off complements Great Tusk's ability to spin by strongly hitting Ghost-types such as Brambleghast, Gholdengo, and Dragapult hard while also removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Lastly, Great Tusk provides Stealth Rock support for the team, which helps to break Focus Sash on Breloom. Heavy-Duty Boots is the premier choice, as it allows Great Tusk to spin away hazards without being poisoned by Toxic Spikes or worn down by Spikes. Leftovers is a solid alternative to provide Great Tusk with passive recovery, but generally avoiding hazard damage is more important. The EV spread outpaces neutral nature Tyranitar and uninvested Brambleghast while maximizing Great Tusk's physical bulk.

Assault Vest Iron Hands is a great partner to Great Tusk, sponging special hits aimed at it while also threatening Pokemon such as Choice Specs Pelipper and Hatterene. Iron Hands also appreciates Great Tusk's ability to keep entry hazards off the field so it doesn't get worn down. Wallbreakers such as Iron Valiant and Breloom appreciate Great Tusk's ability to threaten Poison-types such as Clodsire and Skuntank, allowing them to continue rampaging against the opponent. Due to it being an amazing special attacker, Iron Valiant in particular can threaten physical walls like Quagsire, Sableye, and Dondozo, which like to switch into Great Tusk. Choice Scarf users such as Flamigo, Quaquaval, and Slither Wing pressure special attackers faster than Great Tusk such as Choice Specs Greninja, Dragapult, and opposing Iron Valiant. Gallade is also a really nice partner to handle Pokemon such as Amoonguss, who would otherwise beat Great Tusk one-on-one, thanks to its Psychic STAB attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ground)
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Great Tusk is an exceptional revenge killer because of its great bulk, terrifying Attack stat, and unique STAB combination, allowing it to pummel many threats like Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Flutter Mane. Earthquake may be used instead of Headlong Rush to avoid contact and the stat drops at the cost of dealing less damage. Ice Spinner hits Dragonite and Garchomp. Knock Off greatly hinders Leftovers-reliant Pokemon like Bronzong and Rotom-W, and it leaves common Heavy-Duty Boots users such as Slowbro and Amoonguss to be susceptible to entry hazards from teammates like Clodsire and Ting-Lu.

Iron Treads, Quagsire, and Ting-Lu are great switch-ins to faster threats such as Choice Scarf Greninja and Gengar, as well as Baxcalibur after a Dragon Dance. Clodsire appreciates the removal of Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads as well as the aforementioned Ice-types and Gastrodon appreciates the removal of Grass-types such as Meowscarada and Breloom. In return, Clodsire and Gastrodon switch into Water-type attacks from Quaquaval and Pelipper and set entry hazards to enhance Great Tusk's wallbreaking. Furthermore, Clodsire cripples Quagsire and Rotom-W with Toxic and Gastrodon prevents setup with Clear Smog. Sandy Shocks and Garchomp can aid against Corviknight and Amoonguss to alleviate Steel and Poison matchups, respectively.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Great Tusk's primal physical prowess and great support options make it a prime choice for a bulky Fighting-type.

  • Earthquake versus Headlong Rush: Headlong Rush's defensive drops and vulnerability to Rocky Helmet make it a riskier option than Earthquake, but the extra power OHKOes maximum HP Gholdengo.

  • Ice Spinner: This is highly recommended to avoid getting walled by Dragonite before it Terastallizes, while also dealing good damage to common Tera Flying Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is a good speed control option, great for breaking through Dragonite's Multiscale while nullifying its potential Speed boost, while letting other teammates take advantage of speed control. It also lets Great Tusk hit troublesome Focus Sash Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane and Gengar, something Rapid Spin can't do.

  • Rapid Spin: Great Tusk is one of the best Rapid Spin users, being able to take advantage of it offensively and supporting Pokemon such as Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Focus Sash partners very well with it.

  • Knock Off: Beyond the usefulness of removing items, this is Great Tusk's best move against Air Balloon Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Iron Head: If using Tera Steel, Iron Head is a decent option for OHKOing Flutter Mane without using Headlong Rush, and it deals heavy damage to Baxcalibur and Tera Fairy Rotom-W.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel greatly aids against the many Fairy-, Ice-, and Flying-types that would otherwise prey on Great Tusk, such as Mimikyu, Iron Bundle, and Tera Flying Dragonite.

  • Ground: The furious increase in power Tera Ground provides can be useful late game, giving Earthquake a high chance to OHKO even defensive Gholdengo and Headlong Rush the ability to 2HKO Terastallized Skeledirge.

Items

  • Assault Vest: This patches up Great Tusk's poor Special Defense, which can be paired with Tera Steel to survive new threats such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

  • Booster Energy: When saving Great Tusk for late-game sweeps, Booster Energy is preferred over Life Orb for preserving its HP against priority attacks.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash on such a bulky Pokemon may seem wasteful, but it vastly improves Great Tusk's matchups against special attackers such as Rotom-W and makes setting up Stealth Rock a far simpler task.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximizing Great Tusk's Speed lets it outspeed some important bulky threats, such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W.

  • 252 HP / 228 Atk / 28 SpD with Adamant: This bulkier spread is best used with Assault Vest, ensuring Tera Steel Great Tusk performs decently against non-Choice Specs Flutter Mane due to avoiding a 2HKO from Mystical Fire.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Great Tusk's fantastic Defense stat makes it a great option for setting up Bulk Up late-game.

  • Taunt: Taunt preys on defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Garganacl.

  • Ice Spinner: Dragonite is such a problematic foe that hitting it hard is worth more than a Fighting-type STAB move.

Other Options

  • Body Press: Although it is difficult to fit in without sacrificing utility or coverage, Body Press is a reasonable option if a Fighting-type STAB move is needed.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel is the best option for dealing with Great Tusk's weaknesses, such as Fairy-types and makes Iron Bundle usually fail to 2HKO specially defensive Great Tusk without Choice Specs.

  • Ground: Tera Ground keeps Great Tusk safer against predicted Fire-type coverage from Flutter Mane and lets it break through Skeledirge more easily.

  • Fire: Fire is not a great defensive type; however, not only does it do well against Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane, it also protects Great Tusk from fast Will-O-Wisp users such as Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Volcarona.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a decent alternative to Tera Steel, providing the vital Fairy-type resistance without the weaknesses to Fighting- and Fire-type attacks and an extremely useful immunity to being poisoned that eases the match-up against Toxic Spikes foes such as Clodsire and Meowscarada.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Depending on the EV spread, Booster Energy can boost Attack or Speed to increase Great Tusk's late-game cleaning potential.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry's quick burst of recovery makes Great Tusk far more difficult to 2HKO, with Tera Steel most notably avoiding a 2HKO from Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump without Choice Specs.

  • Covert Cloak: If a Garganacl check is desperately needed, Covert Cloak Great Tusk is up for the task.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 SpD with Careful: Maximum investment in special bulk makes Great Tusk much more difficult to revenge kill with the likes of Gholdengo and Iron Bundle. The 4 Attack EVs gives an Attack boost from Protosynthesis, which is preferred for improving the Skeledirge matchup and sweeping more easily.

  • 4 HP / 252 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly: This set trades more reliable matchups against special attackers for getting a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, making Great Tusk an even better late-game sweeper and ruining fast Will-O-Wisps from the likes of Dragapult and Volcarona via Taunt.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Great Tusk's high power attacks make it a fine Choice item holder.

  • Headlong Rush versus Earthquake: Headlong Rush is preferred for stampeding over maximum HP Gholdengo, but Earthquake avoids chip damage from Rocky Helmet and makes Great Tusk far less vulnerable to priority attacks from foes like Dragonite and Palafin-H.

  • Ice Spinner: Great Tusk should never leave its cave without a move to hit Dragonite hard!

  • Knock Off: Knock Off deals massive damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo and is almost guaranteed to OHKO offensive Dragapult after Stealth Rock damage.

Other Options

  • Iron Head: If using Tera Steel, this is a reasonable option over Knock Off if Tera Fairy Rotom-W is an issue.

Tera Types

  • Ground: Tera Ground is the best option for late-game cleaning, dealing significant damage to Dondozo and Tera Fairy Skeledirge and OHKOing Dragapult with Headlong Rush.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting threatens to 2HKO Corviknight, an otherwise decent check to Great Tusk.

  • Steel: While Great Tusk's special bulk is mediocre, Tera Steel can prevent it from being OHKOed by foes such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Since it outspeeds other major Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Rotom-W, Great Tusk makes for a good revenge killer.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band is a more niche option due to being extremely vulnerable to revenge kills, but does a much better job of wall-breaking, with Tera boosted Great Tusk even being able to 2HKO a maximum Defense Dondozo with Close Combat or Headlong Rush!

sets.name: Booster Energy (Speed)
sets.description:
• Bulk Up further boosts Great Tusk's naturally high Attack and Defense stats.
  • Booster Energy lets Great Tusk outspeed Meowscarada, Annihilape, and Corviknight.
  • Knock Off can be used to remove Choice items from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Magnezone.
  • Great Tusk’s EV spread allows for maximum Attack while still procuring the Speed boost from its Booster Energy. The HP investment increases Great Tusk's bulk and ensures its HP remains odd to have a better matchup against Leech Seed.
  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense stat, it's weak to bulky special attackers such as Weakness Policy or Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge.
  • Great Tusk is strong against Pokemon that it is able to outspeed due to Booster Energy and should use a damaging move against Choice Specs Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, and Chien Pao.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• With maximum Attack and Speed EVs and Choice Scarf, Great Tusk can outspeed and OHKO Meowscarada, non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao.

  • Head Smash is for Volcarona and Iron Jugulis.

  • Heavy Slam is for bulky Flutter Mane sets and Choice Specs Sylveon.

  • Alternatively, an EV spread of 164 Atk / 92 SpD / 252 Spe with Knock Off beats Modest Gholdengo, while some rolls, such as against Choice Specs Sylveon, become worse.

  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense, it is weak to special attackers like Skeledirge, Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, Babiri Berry Sylveon, and Iron Valiant.

  • Since Great Tusk will be locked into an attacking move, opposing Annihilape can set up with Bulk Up and OHKO Great Tusk afterwards.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description: Great Tusk is an excellent Pokemon due to its amazing physical bulk, defensive typing, role compression, and movepool. It also has a very strong offensive presence and has utility moves in Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock to back it up. Headlong Rush is an amazing STAB move, letting Great Tusk force out Pokemon such as Heatran, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge very well. Earthquake can be used for a no-drawback STAB move, but the lack in power is certainly noticeable. Close Combat allows Great Tusk to annihilate Pokemon like Kingambit, and Ferrothorn, and it does a nice chunk to Rotom-W on the switch. Rapid Spin provides reliable entry hazard control, which is especially useful because Great Tusk forces out common Stealth Rock users like Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. It also lets Great Tusk outspeed foes like Iron Valiant, non-Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Tornadus-T. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Tornadus-T for good damage. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Great Tusk an entry hazard immunity and allows it to safely Rapid Spin, while Leftovers gives it passive recovery and lets it reliably check Pokemon like Kingambit and Garchomp. Booster Energy can be used to improve Great Tusk's already great offensive output, but since it is a one-time use item, it can be quite unreliable. Tera Water improves the matchup into Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Floatzel. Tera Ground removes Great Tusk's Fairy and Psychic weakness and bolsters its offensive output, letting it OHKO Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Volcarona. Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to the majority of its weaknesses, letting it KO Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko after luring them. Gholdengo and Kingambit make excellent partners for Great Tusk, as Gholdengo safely handles Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant while Kingambit can force out and Pursuit Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Dragapult. Great Tusk is commonly used as setup fodder against Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Volcarona, so partners like Clodsire and Dragonite can support it in that case. Entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn appreciate Rapid Spin support from Great Tusk, as it lets them keep entry hazards up while removing opposing ones, preventing the team from being worn down quickly. Stealth Rock-weak wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y also appreciate entry hazard removal from Great Tusk, as it lets them come in multiple times and poke holes in the opposition.

sets.name: Wish Support
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic. However, Tera Steel can let it check Gardevoir, Grafaiai and Staraptor in a pinch.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic. Additionally, its sole purpose is to set up dual screens and entry hazards, and changing to another type will not make a massive impact compared to another teammate.

sets.name: I Have No Tail And I Must Scream (Physical Wall)
sets.description:
• Scream Tail is a nice option for bulkier balance teams thanks to its huge invested bulk and access to support moves like Wish and Encore, making it a much-needed check to very threatening Pokemon like Koraidon and offensive Great Tusk.
  • Encore takes advantage of Pokemon that want to take advantage of Scream Tail's passivity, such as Swords Dance Koraidon, locking them into an unfavorable move for Scream Tail's teammates to deal with them.
  • Perish Song works as a pseudo-OHKO move, letting Scream Tail scare out setup sweepers like Swords Dance Koraidon and Chien-Pao as well as bulkier Pokemon like Iron Defense Garganacl and Bulk Up Annihilape.
  • The given EVs let Scream Tail outspeed Adamant Great Tusk while maximizing physical bulk.
  • Tera Water allows Scream Tail to check Pokemon that would overwhelm it like Choice Band Koraidon locked into Flare Blitz and Choice Band Chien-Pao locked into Icicle Crash. It also lets Scream Tail check Palafin and rain teams in general. Alternatively, Tera Poison retains Scream Tail's Fighting-type resistance while enabling it to absorb Toxic Spikes.
  • Physically defensive Scream Tail should be sent into Pokemon like Koraidon to punish moves like U-turn and Flare Blitz with Rocky Helmet.
  • Koraidon can potentially lure Scream Tail and take it out with a Choice Band-boosted Flare Blitz or Heavy Slam. Because of this, revenge killers to it such as Choice Scarf Koraidon are wanted. Koraidon's sun also increases Scream Tail's bulk further.
  • Pokemon that can take special hits such as Ting-Lu, Blissey, and specially defensive Corviknight are recommended, as they check Pokemon like Miraidon and Iron Bundle that can overwhelm Scream Tail.
  • Offensive Pokemon like Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk are also recommended, as they appreciate Scream Tail healing them with Wish.

sets.name: Allied Mastercomputer (Mixed Wall)
sets.description:
• Scream Tail can also run a more specially defensive EV spread to check Pokemon like Iron Bundle.
  • The given EVs allow Scream Tail to check Iron Bundle while still being able to pivot into Choice Scarf Koraidon and defensive Great Tusk.
  • Tera Steel allows Scream Tail to completely wall Iron Bundle while also resisting both of Flutter Mane's STAB attacks. Alternatively, Tera Water variants check rain teams and Palafin while also helping against Choice Specs Chi-Yu in sun, while Tera Poison retains Scream Tail's useful resistances to Fighting-type attacks while allowing it to absorb Toxic Spikes from Pokemon like Toxapex and Clodsire.
  • Scream Tail should always be sent into Pokemon like Iron Bundle and weaker ones like defensive Great Tusk to heal either itself or one of its teammates with Wish or lock a Pokemon like Corviknight or Toxapex into an unfavorable move with Encore.
  • Strong attackers like Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Chi-Yu make for excellent partners, as they greatly appreciate Scream Tail's Wishes.
  • Other defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight and Iron Treads, help Scream Tail by checking Pokemon like Flutter Mane and Miraidon, as well as Chien-Pao in Corviknight's case.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's incredible support movepool and bulk makes it a fine Stealth Rock supporter.

  • Thunder Wave versus Fling: Thunder Wave is the easiest form of paralysis to fit in, but with Light Ball, Fling can paralyze Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp, and Gholdengo that lack Covert Cloak, at the cost of leaving Scream Tail extremely vulnerable to Encore. Fling can also get rid of devastating Choice items from Trick users such as Rotom-W.

  • Encore: Scream Tail's great Speed tier makes it an especially effective user of Encore, letting it punish foes that attempt to set up, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song is another way for Scream Tail to threaten setup sweepers such as Dragonite, and it can become a win condition late in the game. It's also a fantastic response to Baton Pass foes such as Espathra and opposing Scream Tail.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb's additional Speed control is helpful against threats that boost their Speed, such as Dragonite and Baxcalibur.

  • Dazzling Gleam: While a rather weak STAB move, Dazzling Gleam threatening to 2HKO offensive Great Tusk can make it a good way to punish Rapid Spin use.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower 2HKOes Scizor, though it does not 2HKO Gholdengo, making Recover sets still problematic.

  • Disable: Disable is particularly apt at ruining Choice item foes that need a specific move to 2HKO Scream Tail, such as Scizor, though compared to Encore, it's less useful against support moves.

  • Psychic Fangs: In addition to 2HKOing Iron Moth, Psychic Fangs breaking dual screens can be extremely useful, though this doesn't work against Grimmsnarl.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal might seem like an underwhelming defensive option, but taking on Ghost-type attacks while avoiding a 2HKO from Gholdengo can be valuable.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives a vital Steel resistance and is a great defensive typing in general.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy improves Scream Tail's matchup against Dark-types such as Hydreigon.

  • Fire: If using Flamethrower, Tera Fire Scream Taill will have a 97.3% chance to 2HKO Tera Steel Scizor, making it an effective lure.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Blocking the first use of Taunt makes Scream Tail an extremely reliable setter of Stealth Rock.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is the safest way to increase Scream Tail's longetivity, and it can avoid certain 2HKOs depending on the EV spread, such as that from Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Hydro Pump with specially defensive spreads.

  • Light Ball: Light Ball is a requirement when using Fling, ensuring Scream Tail can inflict paralysis once and get rid of Choice items with one move.

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy being instantly consumed makes Scream Tail less flexible, but boosting Speed lets it outspeed key threats such as Dragapult. This item can also be used with bulkier EV spreads to make Scream Tail even bulkier, pulling off incredible stunts such as surviving Timid Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

EV Spreads

  • Scream Tail has an incredible number of viable EV spreads at its disposal: consider these as mere examples rather than all of its viable EV spreads!

  • 180 HP / 156 SpD / 172 Spe with Calm or Careful: This EV spread outspeeds Baxcalibur and Great Tusk and survives Timid Choice Specs Iron Moth's Sludge Wave 93.7% of the time.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: The Speed investment outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and Scream Tail avoids OHKOs from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane.

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Calm or Careful: This EV spread avoids an OHKO from Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and Scream Tail has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Scizor's Choice Band Bullet Punch. If outspeeding Baxcalibur and Great Tusk is a must, a Speed-boosting nature and 68 Speed EVs can be used instead.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Timid or Jolly: With maximum Speed investment, Scream Tail outspeeds not only Iron Moth, but also major Encore targets such as Garchomp and Annihilape.

sets.name: Baton Pass
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's diverse setup options and bulk make it one of the most unpredictable Baton Pass Pokemon in the metagame.

  • Encore: Encore is perfect for punishing passive play, giving Scream Tail many new setup opportunities.

  • Sing: Sing is a high-risk, high-reward option to set up in otherwise impossible situations, and it is especially effective with Blunder Policy.

  • Substitute: Not only is Substitute useful to pass with Baton Pass, but it makes weak Pokemon such as Garganacl into easy setup bait.

Other Options

  • Flamethrower: When using Calm Mind, Flamethrower can threaten Gholdengo and Scizor.

  • Psychic Fangs: Psychic Fangs 2HKOes Clodsire and, after a Bulk Up boost, can OHKO Iron Moth that don't invest in Defense. However, Grimmsnarl holds back its dual screens-breaking potential.

  • Drain Punch: Drain Punch gives Scream Tail some offensive presence against Kingambit.

  • Stored Power: When combined with Calm Mind and Blunder Policy, Stored Power can threaten Unaware walls such as Skeledirge.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Tera Normal gets rid of Scream Tail's key weakness to Steel, and it performs well against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo in particular.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Scream Tail a fantastic defensive typing, resisting Scizor's Bullet Punch in particular.

  • Dark: If Grimmsnarl is particularly problematic for your team, Tera Dark will block its Prankster Taunt from stopping Scream Tail.

Items

  • Mental Herb: Mental Herb is the most reliable option for getting Baton Pass off against faster Taunt users.

  • Blunder Policy: When paired with Sing, Scream Tail can pass Speed when Sing misses.

  • Sitrus Berry: A burst of recovery from Sitrus Berry eases setup in general.

  • Booster Energy: While it's impossible to pass Protosynthesis boosts via Baton Pass, either outspeeding disruptive foes such as Iron Bundle, or surviving Choice Specs holders like Iron Moth and Gholdengo, can be a deadly surprise.

General EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 68 SpD with Careful or Calm: This EV spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to survive Timid Gholdengo's Make It Rain after Stealth Rock damage, and it has a 93.7% chance of surviving Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch.

  • 180 HP / 124 SpD / 204 Spe with Calm or Careful: This spread outspeeds Jolly Annihilape, and with Blunder Policy, it can even outspeed Booster Energy Iron Bundle after missing Sing. The bulk lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

  • 252 HP / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Jolly or Timid: Maximizing Speed lets Scream Tail outspeed high-profile targets such as Iron Moth and Garchomp.

Blunder Policy-Specific EV Spreads

  • 220 HP / 220 Def / 4 SpA / 4 SpD / 60 Spe with Careful or Calm: This spread gives Scream Tail enough bulk to usually survive Tera Steel Choice Band Scizor's Bullet Punch, and it also outspeeds Booster Energy Iron Valiant after missing Sing. The remaining 8 EVs can only boost Special Defense and an offensive stat of your choice.

  • 180 HP / 212 SpD / 116 Spe with Jolly or Timid and 180 HP / 100 SpD / 228 Spe with Careful or Calm: These functionally identical stat spreads let Scream Tail outspeed even Choice Scarf Dragapult after missing Sing! The Special Defense investment lets Scream Tail survive a hit from Timid Gholdengo and Choice Specs Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• Scream Tail's bulk and impressive Speed make it a great dual screens setter.

  • Encore: Encore punishing setup is extremely valuable considering Scream Tail's passive nature compared to other dual screens setters.

  • Perish Song: Perish Song can ruin Baton Pass attempts from the likes of Espathra or opposing Scream Tail, and it does well against most setup sweepers, except Gholdengo.

  • Light Clay versus Mental Herb: Light Clay is the preferred choice, but Mental Herb can save Scream Tail from some particularly difficult users of Taunt such as Corviknight and Annihilape.

Tera Types

  • The extreme support focus of this set means that Terastallization should only be used as a last resort, or when it can clearly lead to a win.

  • Normal: In emergencies, Tera Normal can let Scream Tail set up dual screens against Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. Note that Scream Tail is completely passive against Gholdengo, though.

  • Dark: Tera Dark is a niche answer to Prankster Taunt users such as Grimmsnarl.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Scream Tail's high overall bulk, great defensive typing, and utility moves make it a valuable support Pokemon that can check common offensive threats like Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon, especially when backed up by Tablets of Ruin or Unaware. Thunder Wave cripples foes like Volcarona and Cinderace, prevents Iron Moth and Gengar from freely switching in, and grants more opportunities to pass beefy Wishes to Scream Tail's teammates. Calm Mind turns Scream Tail into a bulky setup sweeper and lets it stand against special attackers like Greninja, Chi-Yu, and Sandy Shocks. Scream Tail's ability to contest and outlast hazard removers like Quaquaval and Corviknight makes it a solid Stealth Rock setter. Encore lets Scream Tail make use of its naturally high Speed tier to annoy slower Pokemon like Kingambit, Florges, and defensive Garchomp and punish setup attempts from Volcarona, Chi-Yu, and Ceruledge, which works well on non-Unaware variants. Alternatively, Regenerator + Heavy-Duty Boots makes Scream Tail a better defensive pivot and Wish passer, and it reduces Scream Tail's reliance on Wish. Defensive partners like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Corviknight can help check dangerous Pokemon such as Gengar and Polteageist; the former two provide entry hazards, freeing Scream Tail to forgo Stealth Rock, while Corviknight's Defog makes non-Heavy Duty Boots variants less vulnerable to entry hazards. Defensive Pokemon that lack reliable recovery, such as non-Regenerator Iron Treads and Dondozo, appreciate Scream Tail's Wishes.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Scream Tail makes use of Trick + Choice Scarf and Encore to shut down defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu as well as bulky setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Scream Tail and Curse Dondozo. Scream Tail can also revenge kil offensive threats like Chien-Pao, Greninja, and Roaring Moon; entry hazards from Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire can put them into its KO range. After giving its Choice Scarf away, Scream Tail becomes an effective Wish passer courtesy of its high HP and Regenerator recovery. Defensive Pokemon without reliable recovery such as Ting-Lu and Dondozo appreciate being passed Wishes; in return, they help cover offensive threats such as Gengar, Kingambit, and Ceruledge, respectively. They also enjoy Scream Tail's ability to use Encore and Trick to handle bulky setup sweepers that can overwhelm them in the long run, such as Bulk Up Garganacl and Corviknight. Teammates such as Iron Treads provide Rapid Spin to prevent Scream Tail from being overwhelmed by entry hazards, which would mitigate Regenerator and force it to use its own Wishes regularly. Offensive Pokemon like Iron Moth, Dragonite, and Gengar can compensate for Scream Tail's overall passivity.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Speedy Spore
sets.description:
• Don't be fooled by Brute Bonnet's low Speed stat; after two uses of Trailblaze, it even outspeeds Dragapult, which is a very feasible feat thanks to Spore. With the lack of Sleep Clause, this Speed turns Brute Bonnet into a terrifying sleep inducer!

  • Crunch versus Sucker Punch: Crunch is the preferred STAB move, reliably hitting the most common Spore check, Gholdengo, which makes it the ideal STAB attack to use with Substitute. However, Sucker Punch lets Brute Bonnet pick off threats when it doesn't have the chance to Spore and set up Trailblaze.

  • Close Combat versus Substitute: On one hand, Close Combat deals massive damage to Dark-type resistances, such as Roaring Moon, but it leaves Brute Bonnet fairly vulnerable to priority attacks. On the other hand, Spore gives Brute Bonnet ample opportunity to set up Substitute, easing the cost of early wake ups.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Powering up Crunch makes it easier to sweep with Crunch or Sucker Punch while still leaving it immune to Grimmsnarl's Prankster Taunt.

  • Fire: Tera Fire turns Brute Bonnet's devastating U-turn and Fairy-type weaknesses into resistances, giving it the edge against Flutter Mane and letting it fry Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Poison: Tera Poison grants Brute Bonnet important resistances to U-turn, Fighting, and Fairy without compromising itself against Water-types.

  • Fairy: With Tera Fairy, Brute Bonnet deals with Dragon-types far more reliably, and gains a valuable tool against opposing Dark- and Dragon-types with Tera Blast.

EV Spreads

  • 148 HP / 100 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Adamant: With Adamant, Brute Bonnet will still outspeed Great Tusk and Annihilape after Trailblaze and Dragapult after two uses of Trailblaze. Brute Bonnet's bulk lets it survive some powerful attacks, such as Iron Moth's Sludge Wave, Choice Specs Gholdengo's Make It Rain, and almost always surviving Choice Specs Iron Bundle's Freeze-Dry.

  • 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: At the cost of bulk, maximizing Speed lets Brute Bonnet outspeed threats such as Garchomp and Iron Treads after just one use of Trailblaze

Items

  • Booster Energy: Activating Protosynthesis takes dvantage of Brute Bonnet's power, though it means switching out will weaken Brute Bonnet.

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers is by far the preferred item, as Brute Bonnet has plenty of turns to recover its health against sleeping foes.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb is the most consistent way to boost Brute Bonnet's power, letting it switch out after using Spore when needed.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Brute Bonnet's good bulk, Focus Sash is a great option to stop potential sweeps, assuming entry hazards aren't set up.

sets.name: Bulky Spore
sets.description:
• With good bulk and access to strong priority, Brute Bonnet is a great offensive user of Spore.

  • Bullet Seed versus Seed Bomb: Even when not using Loaded Dice, Bullet Seed is useful for potentially KOing foes like Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane through Focus Sash and punishing Mimikyu switch ins. Nontheless, Seed Bomb is the more reliable option when not using Loaded Dice.

  • Substitute: Substitute is easy to set up thanks to Spore and eases the risk early wake-ups can pose. If using Substitute, using Crunch or Payback over Sucker Punch is preferred due to the issues Substitute Gholdengo can cause.

  • Crunch versus Payback: Having a reliable Dark-type STAB move is helpful when facing foes like Substitute Gholdengo. Payback has higher damage potential, but Crunch won't have its power dropped by foes switching in.

  • Close Combat: Close Combat crushes Roaring Moon and opposing Brute Bonnet, though the drop in bulk can be troublesome for this set.

Tera Types

  • Dark: Tera Dark works fantastically with Sucker Punch, giving Brute Bonnet good revenge killing capability.

  • Poison: Tera Poison covers Brute Bonnet's major weaknesses to U-turn, Fairy, and Fighting, giving it an easy chance to use Spore.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness can be troublesome, Tera Fire still does well against Flutter Mane and lets Brute Bonnet melt Scizor and Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Powerful Dragon-type attacks such as Outrage and Draco Meteor can be turned into Spore bait with Tera Fairy, in addition to arming Brute Bonnet with a powerful Tera Blast against them.

  • Grass: If using Bullet Seed, Tera Grass can make sense for increasing the chance of shooting down Focus Sash leads such as Flutter Mane and still keeping the Spore immunity against Breloom and opposing Brute Bonnet.

Items

  • Leftovers: The extra recovery pairs very well with Spore and Substitute.

  • Sitrus Berry: If not using Substitute, the quick burst of recovery with Sitrus Berry is preferred.

  • Loaded Dice: Guaranteeing 4 hits with Bullet Seed means Brute Bonnet will always OHKO Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle through their Focus Sash, and the higher chance for 5 hits can even shoot down Mimikyu and offensive Great Tusk.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane functions as a great wallbreaker and revenge killer thanks to its already high Special Attack and Choice Specs, allowing it to break through unprepared teams with its dual unresisted STAB moves.
  • Mystical Fire 2HKOes specially defensive Iron Treads and serves as a way to hit Corviknight.
  • Psyshock is preferred in the last slot as a way to threaten specially defensive walls such as Blissey and Clodsire. Thunderbolt can be used to 2HKO Mirror Armor Corviknight and Toxapex.
  • Flutter Mane can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to further increase its damage output.
  • Flutter Mane pairs extremely well with Koraidon, as it can set up sun to further boost Flutter Mane's already impressive Speed. Koraidon can also pivot out via U-turn against Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Skeledirge, which Flutter Mane can threaten.
  • Physically defensive Corviknight is a great partner for Flutter Mane that can come in on attacks that target Flutter Mane's weaker physical defenses while also providing it safe entry via a slow U-turn.
  • This set appreciates entry hazard support from Great Tusk, which can also threaten Flutter Mane's checks such as Clodsire, Blissey, and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane can deal incredible damage to every Pokemon in the metagame due to its great coverage, notably 2HKOing most defensive foes.
  • Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to OHKO Ting-Lu with Tera Fairy-boosted Moonblast, as well as defensive Great Tusk with Shadow Ball. Taunt can be used instead to stop bulky Pokemon like Blissey, Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex from recovering health, giving Flutter Mane the advantage against bulkier teams.
  • Thunderbolt covers specially defensive Corviknight and Toxapex, whereas Mystical Fire hits Iron Treads.
  • Psyshock is a great option to strongly hit Blissey and Clodsire; Clodsire is an important target, as it otherwise walls Calm Mind + Life Orb variants due to Unaware.
  • Booster Energy can be used instead of Life Orb to boost Speed upon entry, but the drop off in damage is noticeable.
  • Tera Fairy allows Flutter Mane to dish out great levels of damage and lets it resist Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao. Tera Ghost allows Flutter Mane to 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Fire lets Flutter Mane resist Ice Shard from Chien-Pao and Ice Beam and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle, while Tera Normal makes it immune to Shadow Ball from opposing Flutter Mane.
  • Entry hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads is appreciated, as residual damage can stack up quickly between entry hazards and Life Orb recoil.
  • Koraidon acts as a great teammate, setting sun for Flutter Mane's Protosynthesis to trigger.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Psyshock allows Flutter Mane to 2HKO Clodsire and hit Blissey harder than any other move at Flutter Mane's disposal.
  • Thunderbolt is a roll to 2HKO Corviknight after Stealth Rock chip damage and will always 2HKO it if Flutter Mane has a Protosynthesis boost.
  • Tera Fairy boosts Flutter Mane's Moonblast damage output while removing its Ghost typing, which allows Flutter Mane to avoid being 2HKOed by opposing Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball. Tera Psychic is an option to OHKO Clodsire and 2HKO Blissey in the sun while guaranteeing the OHKO on Iron Moth that Flutter Mane might be trying to check.
  • The EV investment allows Flutter Mane to outspeed Chi-Yu and survive two Moonblasts from opposing Choice Specs Flutter Mane.
  • This Flutter Mane acts as both a good blanket check to the special attackers in the tier and an unexpectedly powerful bulky attacker that can turn the tables on Pokemon like Miraidon, Iron Bundle, Iron Moth, Espathra, and Chi-Yu.
  • With no recovery and a vulnerability to entry hazards, Flutter Mane cannot be your only answer to these threats, especially Miraidon. As such, this Flutter Mane is best used on offensive teams that wish to have a one-time check to threatening special attackers.
  • Koraidon is appreciated as a teammate, as it sets up sun that boosts Flutter Mane's damage output while also weakening opposing Iron Bundle's Water moves, letting Flutter Mane come in on it with greater ease.
  • Rapid Spin users like Great Tusk and Iron Treads enable Flutter Mane to take more hits from opposing offensive threats and appreciate this Flutter Mane's ability to damage common answers such as Corviknight. Rapid Spin is preferred over Defog due to the offensive nature of the teams this Flutter Mane fits on.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Fairy)
sets.description:
Flutter Mane has a powerful dual STAB combination in Moonblast and Shadow Ball, as well as a plethora of coverage moves that allow it to choose its good matchups. Mystical Fire hits Steel-types such as Klefki and Iron Treads. Psyshock allows Flutter Mane to punish specially defensive switch-ins like Dragalge, Blissey, and Clodsire. Flutter Mane can run Power Gem to pressure Fire teams, OHKOing foes like Volcarona and Torkoal, and it also benefits from Protosynthesis allowing it to outspeed Scovillain under the sun. Additionally, Flutter Mane usually goes with either Thunderbolt or Energy Ball. Both are useful against Water teams, with the former helping against Toxapex and Pelipper while the latter deals with Gastrodon and Quagsire. Choice Specs further enhances Flutter Mane's wallbreaking power, allowing it to overwhelm foes such as Ting-Lu after some chip damage.

On Fairy teams, Flutter Mane is a menacing wallbreaker that excels at taking down slower foes such as Hydreigon, Skeledirge, and Corviknight. When paired with Iron Valiant, Flutter Mane forms an offensive core that's able to alternate between Fairy-, Ghost-, and Fighting-type STAB to take down a wide range of enemies. Flutter Mane can handle Psychic-type foes such as Espathra and Hatterene, while Iron Valiant takes care of Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Flutter Mane can fall back on either Hatterene or Tinkaton when faced with an unfavorable matchup. Both of these Pokemon provide dependable defensive options and some type of entry hazard control, but Hatterene is particularly useful due to it breaking down walls like Dondozo and Clodsire. Flutter Mane also pairs well with setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Mimikyu, as it is able to poke holes in the opponent's team, allowing them to clean late-game. In return, Azumarill can take care of priority users, such as Ceruledge and Chien-Pao. In terms of support options, Flutter Mane can rely on Fairy's Prankster users, Klefki and Grimmsnarl, to set up dual screens, therefore allowing it to withstand hits such as Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Gholdengo's Make It Rain. Grimmsnarl can then bring in Flutter Mane relatively safely thanks to Parting Shot. Klefki's Spikes and Tinkaton's Stealth Rocks also support Flutter Mane in breaking its checks such as Iron Hands and Ting Lu. Entry hazard stacking proves particularly useful against less bulky teams, as it highly limits their capacity to scout Flutter Mane without having to sacrifice a member in the process.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ghost)
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Flutter Mane is an incredibly potent revenge killer and late-game cleaner thanks to its strong STAB combination, solid coverage options, and blazing Speed tier. Notably, it outspeeds faster Pokemon like Dragapult, boosted threats such as Baxcalibur and Quaquaval, and Choice Scarf users like Greninja and Meowscarada, all of which can threaten the offensive teams that Flutter Mane is part of. Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types such as Corviknight and Iron Treads, while Psyshock revenge kills Choice Scarf Iron Moth and hits specially bulky Pokemon like Clodsire. Thunderbolt pressures Corviknight better and 2HKOes physically defensive Toxapex after Stealth Rock, while Energy Ball takes care of Gastrodon.

Spikes from the likes of Brambleghast and Froslass are terrific support options, chipping down bulky foes like Toxapex and Ting-Lu that would otherwise switch into Flutter Mane freely. Thanks to Good as Gold blocking Defog and its Ghost-typing, Gholdengo is a notable partner to keep Spikes up. Brambleghast also helps threaten Gastrodon and provides Rapid Spin support as well.
