Wallbreakers like Mimikyu and Gholdengo can pressure the opposition early-game, allowing for Flutter Mane to clean up late-game with ease; moreover, Mimikyu can overwhelm Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads with Drain Punch, while Gholdengo can make use of Trick to cripple walls like Clodsire and Corviknight. Setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Ceruledge are valuable teammates that function as back-up late-game cleaners, especially against types Flutter Mane can struggle with such as Poison and Steel. Moreover, Ceruledge and Mimikyu have the added benefit of safely revenge killing opposing fast threats Flutter Mane can't handle easily, like Choice Scarf Flutter Mane and Dragon Dance Dragapult, with Shadow Sneak. Skeledirge is a notable partner to compensate for Flutter Mane's lack of physical bulk, taking on Bullet Punch users like Scizor and Lucario as well as being fantastic in the Steel, Fighting, and Bug matchups.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane's blistering Speed and Special Attack along with its powerful unresisted STAB combination exerts an oppressive amount of pressure on most teams.

  • Mystical Fire: Mystical Fire heavily disrupts enemy special attackers, especially in tandem with its already impressive base 135 Special Defense.

  • Taunt and Thunder Wave: Taunt and Thunder Wave take advantage of Flutter Mane's incredible Speed to disrupt opposing setup strategies.

  • Psyshock versus Power Gem: Power Gem can be used to catch opposing bulky special sweepers such as Volcarona off guard, while Psyshock significantly dents defensive checks like Clodsire and Toxapex in addition to punishing Iron Moth.

Tera Types

  • Fire: Tera Fire gives Flutter Mane a resistance to Steel, most notably living Scizor's Bullet Punch. It also boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

  • Normal: Tera Normal should be considered mostly for the mirror match as well as the opportunity to avoid Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak.

EV Spreads

  • 116 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 132 Spe: This alternate EV spread outspeeds Jolly Roaring Moon and survives an opposing Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball without Tera. In addition, Life Orb Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak has a fairly low chance of OHKOing, and Iron Bundle fails to KO with the combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze Dry.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs transforms Flutter Mane into a potent wallbreaker.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock hits common switch-ins like Clodsire and Assault Vest Iron Hands on their weaker Defense stat.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt 2HKOes Assault Vest Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Fire: Tera Fire helps Flutter Mane deal with Scizor and boosts the power of Mystical Fire.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy Further boosts Moonblast's impressive damage output while removing Flutter Mane's Ghost weakness.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost powers up Shadow Ball and still dodges Extreme Speed.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is a purely defensive option, ridding Flutter Mane of its conventional type disadvantages altogether.

sets.name: Charm
sets.description:
• The combination of Charm and Pain Split turns Flutter Mane into a devastating control option, massively crippling opposing offensive threats and healing itself with the combination of Pain Split and Draining Kiss.

  • Calm Mind: Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to maintain its role as a sweeper by increasing its damage output while simultaneously reinforcing its longevity.

  • Draining Kiss versus Moonblast: Moonblast's far superior damage output is a great option versus more defensive teams, while Draining Kiss supplies superior lasting power against more offensive teams.

EV Spreads

  • 124 HP / 252 Def / 132 Spe with Timid: The chosen EVs ensure that Flutter Mane will always outspeed Jolly Booster Energy Roaring Moon. Maximum Defense investment gets the most out of Charm with the rest placed into HP.

sets.name: Normalize
sets.description: Normalize Flutter-Mane is a dangerous setup sweeper that requires specific counterplay to deal with. Entrainment + Normalize prevents foes from damaging Flutter Mane, with its Fairy typing giving it an immunity to the common Draco Plate Judgment. Quiver Dance increases damage output and allows Flutter Mane to outspeed and nullify would-be faster threats like Zacian-C. Taunt prevents defensive checks from PP stalling Flutter Mane and denies Glare; alternatively, Strength Sap provides Flutter Mane with longevity, allowing it to repeatedly switch into passive Pokemon. Pixie Plate lets Flutter Mane hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Arceus-Dark super effectively, whereas Spooky Plate lets it hit Imposter users and opposing Ghost-types harder. A Modest nature provides a power boost, while Timid can be used to outspeed positive natured Arceus formes to use Entrainment first. Flutter Mane struggles against bulky Magic Bounce and Good as Gold users, so strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Zacian-C and Choice Specs Miraidon are good partners. Even with Normalize, Flutter Mane can still be statused by moves like Glare and Will-O-Wisp, so a Heal Bell user can be helpful. Flutter Mane also has poor physical bulk, so slow defensive pivots like Ting-Lu and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra are appreciated to bring Flutter Mane in safely while also providing Knock Off support to remove Ability Shield.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Thunder is for Azumarill, Corviknight, and some Dondozo.
  • Psyshock is for Iron Moth and Clodsire.
  • Power Gem is for Volcarona.
  • Mystical Fire helps against Abomasnow and Choice Specs Magnezone.
  • Alternatively, an EV spread of 160 Def / 172 SpA / 176 Spe with a Timid nature noth outspeeds and survives Sucker Punch from Adamant Choice Band Meowscarada. The remaining EVs are put in SpA.
  • Due to its low Defense, Flutter Mane is weak against bulky Pokemon that can live a hit and OHKO back such as Iron Treads, Slaking, and Donphan.

sets.name: All-Out-Attacker
sets.description: Tera Bug powers up Slither Wing's First Impression and U-turn to maximize its revenge killing potential and chip damage.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description:
Morning Sun lets Slither Wing use its typing more effectively to check Pokemon such as opposing Slither Wing and Tsareena. Stun Spore instead lets Slither Wing cripple switch-ins like Salamence and Talonflame to create openings for teammates such as Choice Specs Toxtricity.

Tera Ghost lets Slither Wing spinblock and check Maushold and Lucario. Tera Bug is an alternative that improves its ability to revenge kill Pokemon.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing’s massive Attack stat combined with STAB U-turn and First Impression allow it to be a great wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Earthquake is an option to bash Skeledirge whereas Flare Blitz is better into Corviknight and bulky Fighting resistant foes such as Scream Tail on non-Tinted Lens sets. Tinted Lens is useful for revenge killing Dragonite, and Volcarona with First Impression after minimal chip, Sword of Ruin provides the most power against neutral targets. Special wallbreaker partners such as Sheer Force Iron Moth and Gengar break physical walls that trouble Slither Wing and appreciate Slither Wings's ability to break their checks in return. Slither Wing loves being partnered with bulky pivots such as Chilly Reception Slowking, Corviknight, and Desolate Land Volcarona to get it in safely against the opposing team and start punching holes in defensive cores. Slither Wing tends to invite in Fire-types onto the field, so fire resistant teammates such as Garchomp and Garganacl are appreciated.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Good natural bulk, useful defensive typing, and an excellent support movepool make Slither Wing a good mixed defense pivot that repeatedly pivots and most notably switches into Ground-types like Iron Treads. Regenerator makes the most of its pivoting ability, but Unaware is an option for deterring setup. Will-O-Wisp allows it to punish switch-ins like Garchomp with a burn. Its massive Attack allows it to use STAB U-turn to maintain momentum while bringing in more offensive teammates like Chi-Yu and Greninja. Even with investment, Slither Wing struggles to check certain physical attackers like Ceruledge and Dragonite, so Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight make good teammates. Slither Wing also has difficulty against Fairy- and Flying-types like Scream Tail and Dragonite, so it appreciates teammates like Iron Moth and Garganacl that are able to handle them.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Iron Moth and Gengar, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and can fire off Terrain-boosted Discharge and Thunderbolt, respectively. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• A decent defensive typing allows Iron Treads to act as a check to Miraidon and Flutter Mane, and use the opportunity to remove or set entry hazards.
  • Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight, while Volt Switch keeps momentum for your team.
  • 16 IVs in Defense mean that Iron Treads will receive a Special Defense boost in Electric Terrain, helping with switching into Miraidon.
  • Iron Treads can use Tera Fairy to remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire, which can be helpful versus Koraidon and Chien-Pao, and with taking coverage from Miraidon and Flutter Mane. However, it loses its immunity to Electric and resistances to Dragon and Fairy. Iron Treads can alternatively use Tera Ground for an extra boost to Earthquake, but it suffers from similar demerits as Tera Fairy.
  • Since both Miraidon and Flutter Mane have Fire-type coverage options, Iron Treads appreciates being paired with Pokemon such as Ting-Lu that can handle those attacks. Choice Scarf Koraidon and Booster Energy Flutter Mane are also good teammates, as they can revenge kill Miraidon and Flutter Mane while benefitting from Iron Treads removing entry hazards.
  • Skeledirge's ability to check Koraidon and Iron Valiant also makes it a great partner for Iron Treads. Teammates that can switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo and Alomomola also pair well, with Alomomola even providing Wish support to increase Iron Treads's longevity.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Assault Vest allows Iron Treads to utilize an offensive spread while still letting it be a fairly safe option against Miraidon and Flutter Mane.
  • Iron Head allows Iron Treads to beat Tera Fairy Miraidon.
  • Knock Off can remove crucial items from foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Volt Switch is useful for grabbing momentum on non-Ground-type foes that switch in on Iron Treads like Corviknight, Koraidon, Dondozo, and Pelipper.
  • A Jolly nature gives Iron Treads a Speed boost from Quark Drive, which is often crucial to be able to beat Choice Specs Miraidon one-on-one, and lets it pick off foes that would normally outspeed it without Electric Terrain.
  • Ground is the preferred Tera type to boost the power of Earthquake while weakening incoming Fire- and Fighting-type attacks; alternatively, other Tera types can provide defensive utility but not any offensive boost.
  • This set works best on offensive teams where it is paired up with teammates that are weak to Fairy-type moves, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Iron Treads allows these Pokémon to be played more freely because it can reliably deal with Flutter Mane and opposing Miraidon while applying offensive pressure itself.
  • Flutter Mane is another great teammate because Iron Treads lures Corviknight and weakens it with Knock Off or Volt Switch, this gives Flutter Mane an easier time to break through enemy teams.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Steel)
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Iron Treads gives Steel teams a much appreciated revenge killer as well as counterplay against Fire-types such as Tauros-Paldea-Blaze and Volcarona, which can overwhelm Steel teams with ease. Heavy Slam utilizes Iron Treads's fairly hefty size to hit Fairy-types such as Hatterene and Mimikyu hard; however, Iron Head can be used as a more consistent STAB to nail heavier targets such as Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Garganacl. Ice Spinner provides great coverage alongside Iron Treads's STAB moves, nailing Grass-types such as Meowscarada before Protean activates and Amoonguss while also nailing Garchomp and Dragonite. Knock Off provides good team support by getting rid of the foe's item, such as Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from the likes of Dragonite, Volcarona, and Garchomp, whereas Volt Switch allows Iron Treads to pivot out of Pokemon that wall it such as Corviknight and Dondozo.

Corviknight is a fantastic partner for Iron Treads, as it can take Fighting- and Ground-type moves while Iron Treads takes on Electric-types such as Iron Hands and Magnezone for Corviknight. Corviknight can also keep entry hazards off the field with Defog, aiding in Iron Treads's longevity and letting it forgo Rapid Spin. Gholdengo is another great partner, as it not only also helps against Fighting-types that Corviknight can't handle such as Iron Valiant, but it also overwhelms physical walls such as Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo. Entry hazards from Pokemon such as Tinkaton, Orthworm, and Bronzong also aid in Iron Treads sweeping. Tinkaton specifically ensures Stealth Rock being set due to Mold Breaker while having a decent offensive presence thanks to Gigaton Hammer being so powerful. Orthworm provides a Ground immunity, easing pressure off other teammates such as Corviknight, all while also having Spikes and Stealth Rock. Bronzong can not only set up Stealth Rock, but it can also take on Fire-type moves that are aimed at Iron Treads. Kingambit is a great mid- to late-game sweeper that appreciates Iron Treads's ability to punch holes early game or clean up after Kingambit has punched holes itself, providing the team with multiple avenues of winning.

sets.name: Utility (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon has a few niches in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• With a decent defensive typing in Ground / Steel and good bulk, Iron Treads can run an effective Assault Vest set.

  • Iron Head versus Heavy Slam: While Heavy Slam is not as consistent as Iron Head due to Iron Treads's middling weight, it reaches maximum power against targets such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant. Heavy Slam gets a OHKO on Iron Valiant and 2HKOes Iron Bundle, which is something that's not achievable with Iron Head, however, Iron Head 2HKOes Baxcalibur, and does non-negligible damage to Dragonite, which isn't possible with Heavy Slam.

  • Rapid Spin: It may seem weird to run Rapid Spin on such a fast-paced-format, but with it, Iron Treads can support teammates like Dragonite and Focus Sash Flutter Mane. Additionally, with a Jolly nature and minimal Speed investment Iron Treads can outrun Timid Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner gives Iron Treads a move to hit Dragonite, Hydreigon, Garchomp, and Great Tusk hard.

  • Knock Off: Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move against Rotom-W and Rotom-H, and its item removal is valuable all around, crippling both the Pokemon it's supposed to check as well as common switch-ins.

  • Volt Switch: Pivoting can help Iron Treads against physically bulky Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Terastallized Garganacl.

  • EV Spread: The EV Spread aims to maximize Iron Treads's ability to take special attacks, especially when coupled with an Assault Vest; the Speed allows it to outspeed Jolly Breloom before a Rapid Spin and Timid Iron Bundle.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying provides Iron Treads with a Ground immunity and a Fighting resistance, along with neutralizing its Fire weakness, which can be useful against Tera Fire Flutter Mane and Sylveon, Skeledirge, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description:
• Iron Treads possesses an incredible support movepool along with a great base 106 Speed stat, making it a great support option.

  • Electric Terrain: A manual Electric Terrain may seem odd, but Iron Treads has the bulk to run it and use it to activate its own Quark Drive along with its teammates' if applicable, and the lack of other Terrains in the current series means Electric Terrain can run for its full duration a lot of times. Electric Terrain also blocks sleep moves from foes such as Skeledirge, Espathra, Iron Valiant, Gengar, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Rapid Spin: Despite the fast-paced-nature of BSS, Rapid Spin allows Iron Treads to both boost its speed and clear entry hazards from its side of the field, supporting teammates such as Focus Sash Iron Bundle and Dragonite.

  • Knock Off: Along with its item removal ability, Knock Off is Iron Treads's best move to hit Rotom-W and Rotom-H.

  • Ice Spinner: Ice Spinner allows Iron Treads to hit foes such as Dragonite and Great Tusk hard, but it should be used carefully if it's run alongside Electric Terrain, as it ends the current active Terrain.

Other Options

  • Heavy Slam: With Heavy Slam, Iron Treads can OHKO Iron Valiant, as well as 2HKO Iron Bundle without Tera Steel. After Terastallizing into Steel, Heavy Slam can OHKO Iron Bundle after a Rapid Spin.

  • Wild Charge: If Iron Treads is holding a Life Orb, Wild Charge is capable of 2HKOing Corviknight in Electric Terrain.

  • Bulldoze: While weaker than Earthquake, Bulldoze is a speed control option for Iron Treads that affects Ghost-types, unlike Rapid Spin.

Tera Types

  • ** Ground**: Tera Ground neutralizes Iron Treads's Fire, Ground, and Fighting weaknesses and ramps up the power of its Earthquake.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gets rid of Iron Treads's Water weakness and gives it resistances to Ice and Grass.

Items

  • Booster Energy: Booster Energy increases Iron Treads's speed even further, allowing it to outspeed Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Dragapult and slower Choice Scarf foes, making it very likely to get a move off first.

  • Terrain Extender: Terrain Extender increases the duration of Terrains to eight turns, giving Iron Treads or one of its Quark Drive teammates more turns to make use of their ability.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is an option for ensuring Iron Treads can get at least one move off against faster foes that can KO it.

  • Air Balloon: An Air Balloon allows Iron Treads to have an edge against other Ground-type leads such as Garchomp.

  • Life Orb: When used alongside Electric Terrain, Life Orb boosts Iron Treads's offensive pressure, and a Terrain-boosted Wild Charge can 2HKO Corviknight.

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Hatterene and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Dragonite, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Noivern and Cinderace.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description:
• Freeze-Dry and Hydro Pump make Iron Bundle incredibly threatening with perfect coverage.
  • Taunt can be used to stop recovery and status attempts from walls like Corviknight, while Flip Turn can gain momentum. Encore is effective at PP stalling recovery attempts from Pokemon while also locking Pokemon into suboptimal moves like Stealth Rock to take advantage of.
  • Tera Ice boosts Freeze-Dry's and Ice Beam's power to high levels and also removes the neutrality to Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle, making a potential mirror match safer.
  • Tera Water Iron Bundle has immense power on Hydro Pump; Tera Water also removes its Fighting-type weakness and Fire-type neutrality, which helps against Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Koraidon trying to revenge kill it.
  • Iron Bundle has to use its high Speed to force out frail Pokemon or force defensive Terastallization, both of which it can take advantage of.
  • Getting Iron Bundle safe switch-ins on defensive Pokemon that are threatened by Hydro Pump is the best way to use its offensive capabilities, allowing for defensive answers to be Taunted or pivoted on to wear down opposing teams.
  • Pelipper and Miraidon are strong teammates for Iron Bundle, providing rain and Electric Terrain support to power it up.
  • Entry hazard setters are also very strong, since Iron Bundle appreciates checks like Corviknight and Annihilape being worn down. It also can use Taunt to stop Defog Corviknight and pressure the premier spinners in Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• The combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze-Dry gives Iron Bundle an unresisted STAB combination, making it extremely threatening with Choice Specs.
  • Flip Turn allows Iron Bundle to pivot in order to gain momentum, while Ice Beam OHKOes Koraidon and uninvested Miraidon.
  • Tera Ice allows Iron Bundle to further boost its Ice-type moves and resist Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle and Ditto. Tera Water is a good option on teams with rain support in order to let it 2HKO Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey in rain after slight chip.
  • Choice Specs allows Iron Bundle to 2HKO walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Scream Tail with Hydro Pump as well as Toxapex with Freeze-Dry.
  • Miraidon is a great teammate, as it can lure in Pokemon weak to Hydro Pump such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads and pivot into Iron Bundle using U-turn. It also sets Electric Terrain, giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost upon entry.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and defensive Great Tusk are great teammates, as Iron Bundle can get worn down pretty quickly from repeatedly switching into Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description: • The given EV spread, nature and Assault Vest allow Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Overheat from Chi-Yu and OHKO it in return with Hydro Pump while retaining enough speed to move before Meowscarada. Incidentally, the spread also allows Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Santa's Slay
sets.description:
• With nearly perfect coverage and an incredible Speed stat, Iron Bundle's ferocious brand of holiday spirit is a metagame-defining force!

  • Encore: Giving the gift of an encore lets Iron Bundle punish passive Pokemon and naughty sweepers alike.

  • Ice Beam: With a power-boosting item, Ice Beam OHKOes Dragonite through Multiscale.

  • Flip Turn: Pivoting is a big help when Iron Bundle is facing Pokemon likely to Terastallize such as Garchomp or against bulky Assault Vest foes such as Baxcalibur, Iron Hands, and Magnezone.

  • Taunt: Taunt will make support Pokemon such as Clodsire and Tinkaton want to take a holiday, though watch out for common users of Mental Herb such as Scream Tail.

Other Options

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Iron Bundle take further advantage of encored Pokemon and is a decent way to scout for Tera types when using Booster Energy or Life Orb.

  • Whirlpool: Although difficult to pull off with Iron Bundle's mediocre bulk, trapping foes with Whirlpool can make Encore especially deadly.

  • Electric Terrain: Giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost via Electric Terrain isn't nearly as flexible as Booster Energy, but it does let Iron Bundle support potentially deadly Quark Drive teammates such as Iron Valiant and Iron Hands.

Tera Types

  • Water: Besides the power boost for Hydro Pump and resistance to Scizor's Bullet Punch, Tera Water enables a reliable Water-type STAB move in Tera Blast.

  • Ice: With Tera Ice, Freeze-Dry will OHKO offensive Dragonite through Multiscale and Ice Beam will OHKO even bulky Dragonite.

  • Ground: An immunity to Electric-type attacks lets Iron Bundle potentially give Magnezone's and Rotom-W's momentum a snow day and deal more damage to Gholdengo via Tera Blast.

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Iron Bundle an important immunity to Extreme Speed, which can especially ruin Dragonite's holiday with Encore. It also gives Iron Bundle a reliable way to 2HKO Flutter Mane.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Iron Bundle a handy Sucker Punch resistance and a Tera Blast that threatens Kingambit and Tyranitar.

  • Fire: While Tera Fire's resistances aren't fantastic, the ability to roast Scizor like a chestnut is useful, and it gives Iron Bundle an improved matchup against Gholdengo.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Getting around Iron Bundle's iffy bulk makes it a fantastic lead and revenge killer.

  • Booster Energy: Quark Drive's Speed boost lets Iron Bundle outpace key threats such as Dragapult, +1 Baxcalibur, +1 Roaring Moon, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs Iron Bundle regifts support moves so it can wallbreak, with moves such as Tera Water Hydro Pump now OHKOing Tera Fairy Skeledirge.

  • Life Orb: While Life Orb compromises Iron Bundle's ability to take priority attacks, it boosts damage without passing on powerful support moves.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Assault Vest (Fighting)
sets.description:
Iron Hands is the premier specially defensive pivot on Fighting teams thanks to its massive HP stat in conjunction with Assault Vest. It is bulky enough to respond to the strongest special attackers in the tier, such as Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, Greninja, and Iron Moth. Drain Punch provides much needed recovery while using Assault Vest while Thunder Punch is used instead of Wild Charge to avoid chip damage. Heavy Slam hits Fairy-types like Hatterene and allows it to revenge kill Flutter Mane. Despite these strengths, Iron Hands is unable to freely switch in on Flutter Mane and Greninja, as they often run Choice Specs and heavily damage Iron Hands or 2HKO it altogether. Volt Switch allows Iron Hands to keep momentum when it forces switches, allowing it to pivot on physically bulky switch-ins like Skeledirge and Amoonguss. Earthquake is a strong coverage option that hits Poison-types like Clodsire and Iron Moth. Rock Slide is an alternative option to hit Kilowattrel and deal with Volcarona without risking a burn from Flame Body.

Great Tusk appreciates Iron Hands's ability to tank neutral special hits like Water-type attacks from Greninja and Pelipper and force them out. In return, Great Tusk takes Ground-type attacks from opposing Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Furthermore, Great Tusk removes Ting-Lu's Spikes and Clodsire's Toxic Spikes, which cut into Iron Hands's longevity. Breloom and Gallade assist Iron Hands with the Ground and Psychic matchups, respectively, threatening foes like Quagsire and Gastrodon for the former, and Amoonguss and Clodsire for the latter. Breloom appreciates Iron Hands switching into Fire-type attacks from Volcarona and forcing Flying-types like Iron Jugulis to switch. Iron Valiant appreciates Iron Hands's slow Volt Switch, allowing Iron Valiant to switch in freely against opposing Fighting teams. Iron Valiant also threatens common physically defensive Pokemon like Dondozo, Skeledirge, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk. Choice Scarf users such as Quaquaval and Paldean Tauros-F check threats to Iron Hands like Choice Specs Greninja and Flutter Mane, while Iron Hands handles defensive checks such as Calm Mind Hatterene with Heavy Slam in return.

doublesou.overview: Iron Hands is a slow but exceptionally bulky and strong physical attacker, as well as one of the best Fake Out users in the tier. It fits best on Trick Room teams that benefit from its low Speed but also has enough bulk to compensate for its slowness and perform adequately on any team that appreciates the safe turns that Fake Out can provide. Iron Hands most commonly holds an Assault Vest to patch up its lower Special Defense stat and comfortably endure and trade attacks with its enemies. Another popular set foregoes Assault Vest to enable the use of Swords Dance, turning Iron Hands into a fearsome setup sweeper. With either set, Iron Hands is a reliable and well-rounded Pokemon that matches up decently into much of the metagame, although it does need to be wary of a few commonly encountered threats. Amoonguss, the tier's most common and bulkiest redirector, walls both of Iron Hands's STAB attacks and can survive two of its Ice Punches. Despite Iron Hands's massive bulk, a few especially hard-hitting Pokemon like Great Tusk and Armarouge have the offensive capability to break through it with ease. Finally, Iron Hands needs to be wary of priority blockers like Farigiraf, Indeedee-F, and Tsareena when using Fake Out.
doublesou.comments:
Other Options

Iron Hands can be made even bulkier by shifting some or all of its Attack EVs into HP and Defense. Moving 64 EVs into HP allows the Assault Vest Iron Hands set to survive two boosted Shadow Balls from Modest Nasty Plot Gholdengo, as well as one Overheat from a Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu. In addition to the 64 HP EVs, an additional 48 EVs can be moved into Defense to allow Iron Hands to survive two Extreme Speeds or Dragon Claws from Tera Normal Choice Band Dragonite, as well as one Headlong Rush from Adamant Great Tusk. Iron Hands can also invest 124 EVs in Speed to outspeed Garchomp under Tailwind but should retain at least 100 Attack EVs and an Adamant Nature when doing so to ensure Ice Punch OHKOes Garchomp. Tera Fire can be used to prevent burns from Will-O-Wisp users like Arcanine while also providing a STAB boost to Fire Punch. Heavy Slam can be run as a coverage move if Fairy-types such as Sylveon are a concern. Finally, Belly Drum can be used in place of Swords Dance as a higher-risk, higher-reward Attack-boosting move, but losing 50% HP in the process is a high price to pay for a Pokemon that prides itself on its bulk and longevity. When using Belly Drum in combination with a Sitrus Berry, ensure that Iron Hands's HP stat is an even number so that Sitrus Berry activates after the 50% HP drop.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Fake Out is a high-value utility move that creates safe turns for partners to provide speed control, boost stats, switch out, or attack.

  • Close Combat is Iron Hands's strongest available STAB move and can inflict massive super effective damage on several top-tier Pokemon such as Iron Bundle, Ting-Lu, and Chi-Yu. It has the unwelcome side effect of lowering Iron Hands's highly desirable bulk, however. Drain Punch can be run instead as a weaker alternative that provides healing.

  • Wild Charge and Thunder Punch are secondary STAB moves that are useful for hitting Pokemon with an immunity or resistance to Close Combat, such as Gholdengo and Armarouge, as well as Pokemon weak to Electric-type attacks such as Palafin and Gyarados. Wild Charge provides a higher damage output than Thunder Punch at the expense of recoil damage, and either option is valid depending on personal preference.

  • Ice Punch stops Iron Hands from being completely walled by Amoonguss while also hitting Garchomp and other Ground-types for super effective damage. Alternatively, Drain Punch can be run in this slot as a secondary Fighting-type STAB attack and used when Close Combat's drawbacks aren't worthwhile, while Volt Switch is useful to pivot out of an unfavorable matchup or to safely switch in a partner.

  • The given EV spread with an Adamant nature prioritizes maximizing Iron Hands's Attack before using the remaining EVs and an Assault Vest to patch up its lower Special Defense. A Brave nature with 0 Speed IVs is sometimes preferable when using Iron Hands as a Trick Room attacker, but either way just be aware that an Adamant nature makes Iron Hands faster than Ting-Lu, while a Brave nature makes it slower.

  • Tera Grass provides an immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder as well as a resistance to Ground-type attacks that Iron Hands is otherwise weak to. Tera Fighting can be used instead to boost Iron Hands's offensive presence, notably guaranteeing an OHKO versus standard Ting-Lu sets with Close Combat.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance boosts the damage output of Drain Punch and Thunder Punch to highly threatening levels. This move is especially useful for punishing opponents who play passively in anticipation of a more conventional set, which is inclined to click its STAB attacks or Fake Out immediately.

  • Drain Punch is preferred over Close Combat on this set, since Iron Hands has access to Swords Dance to increase Attack and would rather take advantage of the HP recovery that boosted Drain Punches can provide.

  • Thunder Punch is a secondary STAB attack that hits Pokemon with an immunity or resistance to Drain Punch, such as Gholdengo and Armarouge, as well as Pokemon weak to Electric-type attacks such as Palafin and Gyarados. Fire Punch can be run instead to prevent Iron Hands from being walled by Amoonguss while also hitting Gholdengo for super effective damage, at the cost of leaving Iron Hands without an effective move to hit Armarouge with.

  • Protect is the preferred final move on this set for teams that want to make full use of Iron Hands's potential as a setup sweeper with longevity. Fake Out can be run instead to provide safe turns for Iron Hands's partners to move.

  • The given EV spread and Adamant nature prioritize maximizing Iron Hands's Attack before using the remaining EVs to patch up its lower Special Defense. A Brave nature and 0 Speed IVs are sometimes preferable when using Iron Hands as a Trick Room attacker, but either way just be aware that an Adamant nature makes Iron Hands faster than Ting-Lu, while a Brave nature makes it slower.

  • Tera Grass provides an immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder as well as a resistance to Ground-type attacks that Iron Hands is otherwise weak to. Tera Flying is an alternative option that offers full immunity to Ground-type attacks at the expense of powder move immunity, but this can be patched up with Safety Goggles, which is the preferred item for Tera Flying Iron Hands.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: CATCH THESE HANDS (Assault Vest)
sets.description:
• With its great Attack, good natural bulk and excellent offensive typing, Iron Hands stands out as a premier attacker.

  • Drain Punch: While weaker than Close Combat, Drain Punch's recovery keeps Iron Hands healthy and takes advantage of its great bulk.

  • Thunder Punch versus Wild Charge: Wild Charge lets Iron Hands muscle through bulky foes like physically defensive Dondozo at the cost of longevity.

  • Fake Out: Fake Out picks off weakened, normally faster threats, such as Dragonite and Volcarona. It can also beat Focus Sash leads, such as Iron Bundle.

  • Heavy Slam: Heavy Slam is Iron Hands’s best option to hit Fairy-types, notably OHKOing Flutter Mane.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch gives Iron Hands a good option to hit Dragonite and Great Tusk.

  • Volt Switch: Volt Switch, though incredibly weak, can scout switches and maintain offensive momentum.

Tera Types

  • Electric:Tera Electric elevates Thunder Punch’s power to more acceptable levels, makes Wild Charge very difficult to switch in to, and removes Iron Hands’s weakness to Fairy.

  • Steel: Tera Steel grants a resistance to Fairy and boosts Heavy Slam’s power, drastically improving Iron Hand’s matchup against Flutter Mane.

  • Ground: Tera Ground lets Iron Hands perform better against other Iron Hands, becoming immune to Electric-type attacks and allowing it to hit much harder with Earthquake.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting allows Iron Hands to deal more damage with Drain Punch and Close Combat while also removing its weakness to Ground-type attacks.

  • Flying: Tera Flying lets Iron Hands completely flip its matchup against Great Tusk by resisting both of its STAB types and dodging Fissure attempts from the likes of Dondozo.

  • Fire: A Fire-type Tera grants a Fairy resistance while not being vulnerable to Fighting-type attacks or Will-O-Wisp, though it does make Iron Hands more vulnerable to Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: A Fairy-type Tera allows Iron Hands to take advantage of its great bulk by giving it a better defensive typing and threatens Dragon-types and other Iron Hands with a stronger Play Rough.

sets.name: Bulky Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Iron Hands is a potent wincon, using its amazing bulk in conjunction with its perfect coverage to punch holes in faster teams that lack the means to consistently wall it and trade extremely well. Wild Charge and Close Combat are higher power options over Thunder Punch and Drain Punch that allow for a few notable benchmarks, such as having a chance to 2HKO Tera Water Skeledirge and OHKOing defensive Rotom-W after Stealth Rock and a Swords Dance, but they both greatly sacrifice longevity. Ice Punch lets it nail Ground-, Flying- and Dragon-types that resist its STAB combination such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, Zapdos, and Great Tusk. Tera Water lets Iron Hands gain a much stronger defensive type overall, preventing Ground-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types from revenge killing it while improving the rain matchup significantly. The given EV spread allows Iron Hands to KO Tapu Lele with Thunder Punch after a Swords Dance and outspeed Chansey, with the rest dumped into Special Defense to maximize its lower special bulk. Entry hazard support from Garchomp, Gastrodon, Ferrothorn, and Mega Diancie is crucial to Iron Hands, as it quickly wears down all of its checks for it to clean late-game. Future Sight support is also notable, as it allows Iron Hands to bypass would-be checks such as Buzzwole and Skeledirge. Pivots such as Tapu Koko, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T also work well with Iron Hands, as they bring it in safely and prevent it from being worn down quickly. Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain also activates Iron Hands's Quark Drive, boosting its Attack even further. Due to its great defensive utility, it partners well with Pokemon like Slowbro and Dragapult, as it takes advantage of Dark-types that pressure these two out, with Slowbro providing Future Sight support and Dragapult taking advantage of Iron Hands’s checks like Buzzwole and Skeledirge. Due to its lack of longevity, it is a poor singular check to threats such as Kingambit, Weavile, and Kartana, so pairing it up with Pokemon like tank Garchomp, Tapu Fini, and Rotom-W to form defensive a defensive core works wonders.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Flying)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

This new Paradox Pokemon might have some niches in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
• While not quite as powerful or versatile as its counterpart Hydreigon, Iron Jugulis fills a unique role due to its higher Speed and Flying-type STAB.

  • Hurricane vs Air Slash: Hurricane secures KOs on Pokemon like Iron Bundle that Air Slash cannot, however, Air Slash is much less likely to miss, and the flinch chance can come in handy occasionally.

  • Taunt: With Taunt, Iron Jugulis stops walls such as Clodsire from healing off its attacks, and prevents debilitating status that would otherwise cut its sweep short.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power grants Iron Jugulis valuable coverage on most Pokémon that would not mind its main attacks, like Tinkaton.

  • Flash Cannon: Flash Cannon is useful for hitting Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane for big damage.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower provides super effective coverage on Steel-types that might otherwise cause issues for Iron Jugulis.

Other Options

  • Knock Off: While not doing much damage to many does due to Iron Jugulis's thoroughly average Attack stat, Knock Off can still help Iron Jugulis and its teammates by softening up defensive cores via item removal.

  • Substitute: Substitute can be used to punish Spore attempts from the likes of Breloom and Brute Bonnet, as well as easing prediction by scouting switches.

  • Focus Blast: Though unreliable due to its accuracy, Focus Blast is Iron Jugulis's best option to hit Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Terastallizing into a Flying-type boosts Iron Jugulis's damage output with Air Slash and Hurricane, making it even more difficult to switch into while removing the weaknesses that come from its secondary Dark typing.

  • Dark: A Dark-type Tera boosts Dark Pulse's damage considerably, and when coupled with its rather high flinch rate, a Tera Dark Iron Jugulis can prove quite difficult to handle for some teams.

  • Steel: A Steel-type Tera grants Iron Jugulis a resistance to Fairy and Ice, improving its matchup with Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle and giving it STAB on Flash Cannon.

  • Ground: Tera Ground gives Iron Jugulis an Electric-type immunity, allowing it to block Volt Switch from the likes of Rotom-W and Iron Hands while also giving it STAB on Earth Power.

sets.name: NANO LOVE (Choice Item)
sets.description:
• With its good Speed and powerful STABs, Iron Jugulis lends itself nicely to use a Choice item set, setting itself apart from Hydreigon by virtue of its higher Speed at the cost of some power.

  • Hurricane vs Air Slash: Hurricane offers Iron Jugulis an extremely powerful Flying-type STAB attack, though Air Slash is far more consistent due to its higher accuracy.

  • Earth Power: Earth Power allows Iron Jugulis to hit otherwise irritating switch-ins like Magnezone and Tinkaton.

  • Flash Cannon: Flash Cannon allows Iron Jugulis to punish Fairy-type switch-ins such as Flutter Mane, as well as the numerous Tera Fairy users in the BSS metagame.

  • U-turn: U-turn allows Iron Jugulis to keep momentum for its team by scouting switches and pivoting out of disadvantageous matchups.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs elevates Iron Jugulis's power, allowing it to wallbreak much more consistently.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf's Speed boost allows Iron Jugulis to outspeed otherwise faster foes like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, potentially surprising them with early KOs.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Tera Flying boosts Air Slash to more respectable power levels, and also makes Hurricane incredibly hard to switch into safely.

  • Dark: Tera Dark pushes Dark Pulse's damage output even further, making Iron Jugulis very hard to deal with in conjunction with the move’s ever-irritating flinch rate.

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Iron Jugulis resistances to Fairy and Ice, improving its matchup against Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
High Special Attack, great Speed, and a variety of coverage moves make Iron Moth a powerful offensive presence and late-game sweeper. With Booster Energy and the listed EV spread, Iron Moth receives a one-time Speed boost to outspeed and threaten normally-faster foes such as Dragapult, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Roaring Moon. Furthermore, Fiery Dance can further boost its offense with Special Attack boosts. Energy Ball allows it to take on Water- and Ground-types such as Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Great Tusk. Dazzling Gleam gives Iron Moth an answer to Dragon-types such as Dragapult, Roaring Moon, and Baxcalibur. Finally, Psychic threatens Poison-types such as opposing Iron Moth and Toxapex, as well as Fighting-types such as Iron Valiant. With Tera Fairy, Iron Moth receives a boost to Dazzling Gleam, and it also loses its crippling weaknesses to Ground, Psychic, and Stealth Rock. Tera Fairy also gives Iron Moth a valuable resistance to Sucker Punch, meaning it no longer fears Kingambit revenge killing it mid-sweep. An alternative EV spread of maximum Special Attack and Speed with a Timid nature is a viable alternative, since Iron Moth will receive a boost to its Special Attack from Booster Energy.

Iron Moth serves best on various hyper offense teams, where it can sweep efficiently. When pairing Iron Moth with other offensive Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Baxcalibur, and Dragapult, some can punch holes early- and mid-game for others to sweep more easily late-game. Meowscarada, Great Tusk, and mixed offensive Garchomp provide hyper offense teams with entry hazards, which wear foes down into Iron Moth's KO range. Kingambit, Dragonite, and Choice Band Scizor can revenge kill boosted sweepers that Iron Moth can struggle with. Kingambit revenge kills Dragapult and Tera Flying Roaring Moon, Dragonite covers Volcarona and offensive Iron Moth, and Choice Band Scizor covers Iron Valiant and Dragonite. Iron Moth is very vulnerable to hazards, so it appreciates hazard removal from the likes of offensive Great Tusk and Booster Energy Iron Treads.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description:
• Iron Moth functions as a late-game cleaner with the combination of Agility and Booster Energy and aids hyper offense teams by absorbing Toxic Spikes.
  • Psychic lets Iron Moth break past Clodsire and Toxapex, 2HKOing both after minimal chip. Sludge Wave can be run instead to deal with the plethora of foes that wish to Terastallize into the Fairy typing.
  • Tera Fairy should be used in conjunction with Dazzling Gleam to OHKO Koraidon and Miraidon and improve the Chien-Pao matchup by making Iron Moth harder to revenge kill with priority.
  • Alternatively, Tera Grass boosts Energy Ball, allowing it to 2HKO Ting-Lu and OHKO Garganacl, and removes Iron Moth's weaknesses to Ground and Rock.
  • Iron Moth functions best on offensive teams, where it can set up on and pick off weakened foes.
  • Koraidon is a good partner, as it sets sun, can bring Iron Moth in safely with U-turn, and can help overwhelm their shared checks, such as Skeledirge, Dachsbun, and Pelipper.
  • Spikes setters such as Glimmora and Froslass are also appreciated, allowing Iron Moth to get KOs it otherwise would not be able to such as the 2HKO on Garganacl and the OHKO on Great Tusk.

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Fire)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Poison)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Excellent offensive stats, the useful ability to absorb Toxic Spikes, and good coverage make Iron Moth one of the best choices for an offensive Fire-type.

  • Energy Ball versus Discharge: One of these two moves is highly recommended to hit Dondozo hard and OHKO Iron Bundle if not using Choice Specs. Energy Ball deals massive damage to Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Hippowdon. Discharge trades hitting Ground-types hard for not getting walled by opposing Iron Moth.

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam is the best option against Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon.

  • Overheat: Even with the lack of extra coverage, Overheat is so strong that very few Pokemon can safely switch into it.

  • Acid Spray: For Assault Vest or Life Orb sets, Acid Spray can be a way to get past Skeledirge that lack Earth Power. If using Choice Specs and Tera Poison, it becomes extremely difficult to check defensively, with Skeledirge in particular being 2HKOed after Stealth Rock damage.

Other Options

  • Flame Charge: If not using a Choice Item, coverage can be sacrificed in exchange for giving Iron Moth the ability to outspeed major threats such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult.

  • U-turn: Iron Moth is fully capable of being a reasonable pivot, though U-turn is rather weak.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Tera Grass massively improves Iron Moth's matchup against common Ground-types like Great Tusk and Garchomp and the high powered Energy Ball helps against Assault Vest Dondozo. The immunity to Spore can help in a pinch against Brute Bonnet and Breloom too.

  • Fire: When paired with Overheat and Choice Specs, Tera Fire means Fire-resistant foes aren't safe; even physically defensive Skeledirge is 2HKOed!

  • Fairy: The boost given to Dazzling Gleam makes Tera Fairy far more effective against Dragon-types, now being able to OHKO Dragapult and even OHKO Garchomp if using Choice Specs.

  • Water: With Tera Blast, Tera Water improves the Skeledirge and Iron Moth matchup.

  • Poison: Tera Poison gives Sludge Wave good damage potential and removes Iron Moth's annoying Stealth Rock weakness. It also turns Acid Spray into a deadly wall-breaking move.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs turns Iron Moth into a full blown wallbreaker.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf outspeeds important threats such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, who could otherwise outpseed and KO Iron Moth.

  • Assault Vest: Iron Moth's good special bulk makes Assault Vest a fine choice, letting it survive new attacks such as an unboosted Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle and Rotom-W.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb's ability to switch moves over Choice Specs can make it desirable since it still has similar wallbreaking capabilities, though it makes Iron Moth much more vulnerable to priority and Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Speedy Booster Energy
sets.description:
• With Booster Energy in its circuits, Iron Moth can sacrifice some of its power to become a surprisingly effective late-game sweeper and emergency revenge killer.

  • Dazzling Gleam: Dazzling Gleam is Iron Moth's ticket to overloading Dragon-types like Roaring Moon and Dragapult, who can otherwise stop a sweep.

  • Energy Ball versus Discharge: Iron Moth will usually want a move to OHKO Iron Bundle. Energy Ball is the best choice since it also hits Great Tusk and Hippowdon hard, but Discharge does prevent opposing Iron Moth from walling this set.

  • Acid Spray versus Sludge Wave: Acid Spray on its own is weak without Tera Poison, but it presents Iron Moth a chance to break through Skeledirge and Assault Vest Dondozo. Sludge Wave is the more reliable STAB move for dealing big damage to Azumarill and common Tera Fairy foes such as Garchomp and Rotom-W.

  • EV Spread: The given EV Spread ensures Iron Moth gets a Speed boost upon consuming Booster Energy while also surviving a neutral 120 BP attack from Great Tusk without an offensive item thanks to Terastallization.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Tera Grass is among the best options, preventing Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp from easily stopping a late-game sweep.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Fiery Dance's somewhat underwhelming damage output can be overcome, now letting Iron Moth OHKO Iron Bundle.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy ensures that most Dragapult and Roaring Moon will now be OHKOed, in addition to being immune to deadly Dragon-type attacks.

  • Poison: Tera Poison will make Acid Spray just as powerful as Fiery Dance, making it especially effective against Assault Vest Dondozo, in addition to letting Sludge Wave OHKO defensive Tera Fairy Garchomp.

  • Water: If paired with Tera Blast, Tera Water is usually the best option against Skeledirge, though this will come at the cost of coverage or Acid Spray's wallbreaking utility.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth is a powerful special attacker that also provides good defensive utility thanks to Desolate Land and Morning Sun. Its near-unique offensive typing lets it threaten common walls like non-Well Baked Body Corviknight and Scream Tail, especially when boosted by sun. U-turn can be used to maintain momentum against predicted switch-ins like Garchomp and Garganacl, while Toxic Spikes punishes switch-ins with status. Iron Moth complements Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their vulnerability to Primordial Sea Greninja. Pokemon like Kingambit and Dragonite appreciate Iron Moth taking advantage of their Steel-type checks like Corviknight.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Specially defensive Iron Moth uses its solid bulk, good defensive typing, and sun-boosted Morning Sun to consistently check foes like Volcarona. It's not entirely passive either, as the boosts from Fiery Dance under sun allow it to eventually overwhelm passive foes like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Florges. U-turn lets it gain momentum by pivoting out safely, and Toxic Spikes punishes grounded foes like Garganacl and Ting-Lu. Due to its devastating Ground weakness, Ground-immune Pokemon like Corviknight and Dragonite make good pairings with it. Iron Moth works well with wallbreakers like Quaquaval and Chien-Pao, as they appreciate being given free entry to threaten its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Iron Moth is a great complement to special walls like Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their type weaknesses.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here id s sample set that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• Baxcalibur's bulk and the wonderful Ice Shard means it doesn't need to set-up to become a powerful threat.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear is recommended despite its inconsistent damage, as it deals damage through Mimikyu's disguise and potentially KOes Focus Sash users like Breloom and Meowscarada.

  • Glaive Rush: Glaive Rush makes Baxcalibur very vulnerable to getting KOed the next turn, but it is still the least risky Dragon-type STAB move. Remember that Ice Shard will remove Glaive Rush's negative effects as well.

Tera Types

  • Ground: A Ground Tera type gives Baxcalibur a reliable STAB move in Earthquake, resistance to Stealth Rock, and removes a ton of weaknesses, all at the cost of losing to Water-types such as Rotom-W and Iron Bundle.

  • Electric: With Tera Electric, Baxcalibur's Tera Blast deals massive damage to Corviknight that lack a set up move, Azumarill, does good chip damage to Dondozo, and gains a valuable resistance to Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

  • Ice: Boosting the power of Ice Shard gives Choice Band Baxcalibur new revenge kill chances, and makes wall breaking with Icicle Spear easier.

  • Fire: Tera Fire massively swings the Scizor matchup in Baxcalibur's favor, and makes it a good check against powerful Fire-types such as Iron Moth and Volcarona.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Baxcalibur's bulk makes it an excellent user of Assault Vest, making it particularly effective against Rotom formes and Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Band: With Choice Band, Baxcalibur becomes an immediate threat, threatening to 2HKO physical walls such as Dondozo.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This simple EV spread maximizes Baxcalibur's bulk and power.

  • 116 HP / 156 Atk / 236 Spe with Adamant: The Speed investment here outspeeds Modest Gholdengo and Adamant Dragonite.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: If using Choice Band, winning Speed ties against Great Tusk and opposing Baxcalibur makes maximum Speed much more appealing.

sets.name: Sweeper
sets.description:
• With good bulk, an immunity to burn, and just enough Speed to work, Baxcalibur is a powerful sweeper.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear KOes Breloom and Mimikyu through Focus Sash and Disguise respectively.

  • Glaive Rush: While Glaive Rush is valuable for late-game sweeping, it does make Baxcalibur very vulnerable to bulky OHKO move users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard means Baxcalibur will have a difficult time breaking past bulky Steel-types early-game, but it makes it an effective cleaner otherwise.

Other Options

  • Swords Dance: Dragon Dance is the more reliable option for sweeping due to Baxcalibur's Speed, but Swords Dance can be paired with Ice Shard and an Adamant nature to OHKO fast, frail foes such as Booster Energy Flutter Mane.

Tera Types

  • Ground: Tera Ground makes Earthquake an especially reliable sweeping tool, removes most of Baxcalibur's weaknesses, and makes it immune to Thunder Wave.

  • Electric: When paired with Tera Blast, this is Life Orb Baxcalibur's best shot at dealing damage to Dondozo switch-ins. The paralysis immunity also helps Baxcalibur set up against Chansey with less risk.

  • Ice: Tera Ice works great with Ice Shard, making Baxcalibur easier to clean teams with.

  • Fire: Besides adding a useful Bullet Punch resistance, Tera Fire severely punishes powerful Fire-types that think they can revenge kill, and gives Baxcalibur a powerful Tera Blast against Corviknight and Tera Steel Rotom-W.

  • Dragon: This makes Glaive Rush deal obscene damage and removes weaknesses to Mach Punch and Bullet Punch.

  • Steel: With a Tera type of Steel, Baxcalibur can set up on Mimikyu and Dragon-type attacks.

Items

  • Loaded Dice: With a guaranteed 4 hits from Icicle Spear, Baxcalibur is able to always OHKO offensive Mimikyu after Dragon Dance.

  • Life Orb: This helps Baxcalibur sweep reliably and ensures Icicle Spear OHKOes Breloom through Focus Sash.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash may seem like a waste with Baxcalibur's bulk, but it provides new set up opportunities and eases match-ups against other Dragon-types.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gholdengo utilizes its high Special Attack and its great offensive typing to become a fast revenge killer. Gholdengo can effectively hit offensive threats such as Dragapult and Iron Valiant with its STAB moves. Trick allows Gholdengo to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Dodonzo, Corviknight, and Clodsire. Its typing also allows it to switch into foes such as Iron Valiant and Iron Hands in a pinch, as it either resists or is immune to most of their attacks. Focus Blast is ideal for Gholdengo to hit Kingambit and other foes such as a weakened Ting-Lu, but Nasty Plot can be run instead to take advantage of stopping defensive Pokemon with Trick and having a free turn to set up and do a great amount of damage. Recover can also be run, taking a more defensive approach to give Gholdengo a free turn to heal. Gholdengo prefers Fighting as a Tera type, as it removes its prior weaknesses, meaning it is not threatened by Kingambit's Sucker Punch or Skeledirge's Torch Song. It also boosts the power of Focus Blast, reliably removing the former. To counter different foes, Gholdengo can instead opt for Tera Flying to have better ground against Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

Teammates such as Kingambit and Iron Valiant appreciate Gholdengo's offensive pressure, as it can help against shared checks such as Great Tusk and Amoonguss. With this role, Gholdengo prefers to have a clean switch after a teammate has fainted in order to pressure the opponent. Similarly, entry hazard setters such as Garchomp, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu appreciate Gholdengo for its Good as Gold ability and its Ghost typing, preventing all forms of hazard removal excluding Court Change. Gholdengo is mainly vulnerable to priority moves such as Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Dragonite also presents an issue for it with Multiscale in conjunction with Earthquake, not to mention it can set up twice in front of Gholdengo. This can be avoided with a carefully timed Trick or help from defensive Great Tusk and Skeledirge. Similarly, depending on its Choice lock, Roaring Moon and Cinderace can take advantage of Gholdengo with Crunch and Sucker Punch, respectively. As a result of this, Garchomp and Garganacl pair well with Gholdengo, acting as a defensive backbone with type advantage and great bulk. Iron Valiant can be a great revenge killer against these threats with great Speed and coverage.

sets.name: Air Balloon
sets.description:
Thanks to its great typing and Good as Gold, Gholdengo is a setup sweeper that's notably difficult to deal with. Having an additional Ground immunity with Air Balloon further improves Gholdengo's already great typing, letting it switch in on Pokemon that otherwise threaten it, such as Garchomp and Iron Treads. This is especially useful against the latter, as Air Balloon strengthens Gholdengo's ability to block entry hazard removal. Maximum Speed investment is for outspeeding Dragonite and uninvested Great Tusk. 252 Special Attack EVs and Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo's STAB moves very threatening against neutral foes. Fighting and Dark Tera types give Gholdengo the option to Terastallize defensively; notably, Tera Fighting lessens the impact of moves like Crunch from Roaring Moon. Tera Dark is useful in a pinch to resist attacks such as Shadow Ball from Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo.

Entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Glimmora are the most profitable teammates for Gholdengo, as its ability and typing ensure that their entry hazards stay around as long as Gholdengo does. Hyper offense staples such as Iron Valiant benefit greatly from the constant presence of entry hazards to break down bulkier cores; in return, Gholdengo gets teammates that synergize with its role as a wallbreaker, applying heavy pressure throughout a game to Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Rotom-W. Offensive Pokemon that outspeed and OHKO Gholdengo, such as Cinderace, Roaring Moon, and Knock Off variants of Great Tusk, threaten to completely shut down Gholdengo; defensive teammates like Garganacl, Dondozo and Skeledirge can help mitigate some of these weaknesses.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Gholdengo can utilize its natural bulk, great typing, and immunity to status moves for a more defensive role on balance and stall teams. It can switch into several key offensive threats such as Iron Valiant, Scizor and Breloom and completely shut down multiple defensive Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Corviknight. With Good as Gold, Gholdengo can act as a reliable means of spinblocking and denying Defog. Recover provides Gholdengo with a means of improving its longevity, letting it switch into the aforementioned threats multiple times throughout a match. Thunder Wave allows Gholdengo to cripple threats it can lure in, like Iron Moth and Roaring Moon. Gholdengo can capitalize on the status it spreads with Hex, letting it deal high damage once its targets have been paralyzed. Gholdengo can take advantage of switches it forces by setting up Nasty Plot, letting it exert a high offensive threat level, and enabling it to win potential stalemates against bulkier Pokemon such as Corviknight and Dondozo. Alternatively, Make It Rain can be used to immediately KO Garganacl and Iron Valiant. Tera Flying improves Gholdengo's matchups against Ground-types like Great Tusk and Iron Treads. This completely flips the matchup in Gholdengo's favor, as it can use them as a point of entry to set up Nasty Plot. Tera Fairy, on the other hand, grants Gholdengo a resistance to Dark-type attacks, allowing it to survive Crunch from Roaring Moon and paralyze it with Thunder Wave. Gholdengo's item choice is quite flexible and largely depends on its team structure. Leftovers offers passive recovery, which is quite valuable to preserve Recover PP. Covert Cloak grants Gholdengo an immunity to the secondary effects of various moves, allowing it to counter Garganacl by nullifying the chip damage from Salt Cure. It is also useful to allow Gholdengo to switch into a wider pool of moves, like Hatterene's Nuzzle, with far less risk. Heavy-Duty Boots nullifies entry hazard damage, allowing Gholdengo to switch in and out with little issue. A physically defensive EV spread allows Gholdengo to more reliably check Pokemon such as Garganacl, Corviknight, and Scizor.

Defensive Gholdengo fits on a variety of teams, but it particularly shines on balance and stall teams. Its ability to nullify most forms of hazard control is most useful to entry hazard setters such as Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Great Tusk. These Pokemon also appreciate Gholdengo's ability to check Hatterene, which can bounce back hazards with Magic Bounce. If Gholdengo is utilizing Covert Cloak, it will be a great teammate to Pokemon like Dodonzo, Toxapex, and Corviknight, which struggle against Garganacl due to Salt Cure. Gholdengo can pivot into many key status moves such as Will-O-Wisp and is therefore a great ally to Pokemon that are common targets of them, such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Meowscarada. When not running Tera Flying, Ground-types like Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire can use Gholdengo as an entry point to either deal high damage to it with Earthquake or set up entry hazards. Corviknight is thus a great partner, as it can switch into them with ease and clear entry hazards they may set up with Defog. Hatterene is another good teammate, since it can completely shut down attempts to set up entry hazards with Magic Bounce. Gholdengo is also quite vulnerable to a few other offensive threats, such as Volcarona, Cinderace, and Kingambit, so bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxpaex can switch into these Pokemon and prevent setup via Unaware and Haze, respectively, which Gholdengo will greatly appreciate. Garchomp and Great Tusk can switch into Cinderace and Kingambit and threaten them out with Earthquake, and they can also benefit from Gholdengo's Thunder Wave support, allowing them to more reliably check Cinderace and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Gholdengo is a strong revenge killer with a unique typing that gives it nearly perfect coverage. Gholdengo's ability and typing make it immune to Defog, Rapid Spin, Mortal Spin, and status moves, giving it a niche over other special attackers. Trick is useful to cripple special walls like Blissey, Iron Treads, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu by locking them into unfavorable moves, thus supporting teammates like Miraidon and Iron Bundle. Focus Blast targets Chi-Yu, Kingambit, and Iron Treads. Alternatively, Recover may be used to grant Gholdengo longevity, while Nasty Plot helps it function as a cleaner in the late-game. Tera Water gives it a better defensive typing by allowing it to deal better with Choice Scarf Koraidon. Tera Ghost gets rid of Gholdengo's Ground-type weakness while retaining immunity to Rapid Spin and strengthens Shadow Ball. Lastly, Tera Fighting weakens otherwise super effective hits from Chien-Pao and Kingambit to allow Gholdengo to revenge kill them while also boosting Focus Blast to deal more damage to Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Treads. Gholdengo works best with entry hazard setters and defensive walls such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads, as well as strong attackers like Chien-Pao, Miraidon, Koraidon, and Iron Bundle, that appreciate Gholdengo's ability to revenge kill, block hazard removal, and cripple walls. Toxapex and Alomomola are useful to check Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon and Sucker Punch Chien-Pao, as they are not revenge killed by Gholdengo.

sets.name: Nasty Plot Sweeper
sets.description: Gholdengo is a threatening setup sweeper on hazard stack teams due to its unique typing and ability. The combination of Shadow Ball and Make it Rain offers nearly perfect coverage. Recover ensures longevity, allowing it to switch into walls repeatedly, notably Corviknight and Blissey; alternatively, Focus Blast easily breaks Ting-Lu and Iron Treads. Air Balloon makes it immune to Ground-type attacks from Iron Treads and Great Tusk, allowing Gholdengo to comfortably switch into them if expecting Rapid Spin. Tera Water gives it a stronger defensive typing, notably against Koraidon and Iron Bundle. Tera Ghost is an option that removes the Ground-type weakness, while still retaining the ability to block Rapid Spin. Gholdengo requires support from entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, Glimmora, and Great Tusk. Iron Treads and Clodsire are solid entry hazard setters that also check Miraidon, which is a huge threat for Gholdengo. Physical walls like Toxapex and Alomomola are able to switch into and chip revenge killers like Koraidon and Chien-Pao via Rocky Helmet, making it easier for Gholdengo to sweep. Teammates such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle make the most out of Gholdengo's wallbreaking power and ability to block entry hazard removal.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Gholdengo outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, can use Trick to weaken defensive teams, and also blocks Defog and Rapid Spin to keep pressure on defensive Pokemon with entry hazards.
  • Focus Blast deals more damage to Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Treads, while Nasty Plot and Recover can be used after Gholdengo's Choice Scarf has been removed via Trick to turn it into a setup sweeper or give it longevity, respectively.
  • Tera Fighting powers up Focus Blast, which allows Gholdengo to potentially 2HKO Ting-Lu. Alternatively, Gholdengo can use Tera Steel on sets not using Focus Blast to boost Make It Rain and remove its weaknesses to Flutter Mane's and Chien-Pao's STAB moves.
  • Gholdengo should almost always be switched in if Corviknight is on the field and be used sparingly against Great Tusk and Iron Treads if a Rapid Spin is predicted, but this is risky due to its Earthquake weakness.
  • Spikes setters like Ting-Lu and Clodsire on balance teams as well as Froslass on hyper offense teams appreciate Gholdengo keeping up Spikes and it acting as a revenge killer for their respective archetypes.
  • Pokemon like Calm Mind Miraidon, Calm Mind Flutter Mane, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao also benefit from Gholdengo using Trick on defensive Pokemon, forcing them to either heal or be locked into an unfavorable attack while they set up. Gholdengo can also clean up weakened teams if these Pokemon are used to wallbreak first.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot + Recover Gholdengo is the best option for preventing entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Tera Steel bolsters Make It Rain's power, allowing Gholdengo to overwhelm threats such as Koraidon, defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and bulky Tera Fairy Miraidon after a Nasty Plot boost while removing its Ghost typing.
  • Tera Normal blocks incoming Ghost-type attacks from the likes of Flutter Mane, Choice Scarf Houndstone, and opposing Gholdengo.
  • Air Balloon provides a temporary measure against Ground-type attacks from Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, allowing Gholdengo to sometimes switch into them.
  • Gholdengo best fits on hyper offense and balance teams that aim to preserve their own entry hazards for as long as possible.
  • Frail leads such as Froslass and Masquerain appreciate their entry hazards staying intact against Great Tusk, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Glimmora.
  • Glimmora and Ting-Lu make for good teammates on balance teams in particular, as they provide similar entry hazard support while having sufficient power and bulk to punish threats.
  • Wallbreakers such as Miraidon, Koraidon, and Chi-Yu appreciate multiple entry hazards to further overwhelm the opposition with their tremendous attacks and power.

sets.name: Nasty Plot (Steel)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf (Ghost)
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gholdengo's ability to revenge kill threats such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao lacking Sucker Punch, and Dragapult, come into status-spreading Pokemon such as Klefki and Breloom due to Good as Gold, and inconvenience bulkier teams by preventing all forms of entry hazard removal with its ability and typing make it a prime pick for Ghost teams. Make it Rain greatly weakens Dark- and Normal-types such as Hydreigon and Indeedee, and it OHKOes Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao. Shadow Ball lets Gholdengo clean types such as Psychic and Ghost late-game. Trick neutralizes defensive pivots such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire, which typically switch into it. The last move of choice is dependent on what the Ghost team lacks; Focus Blast gives the team another way to defeat Choice Specs Greninja, Thunderbolt cleans Water- and Flying-teams, or Nasty Plot which turns Gholdengo into a massive threat against bulkier teams especially after their main specially defensive wall has been given a Choice Scarf with Trick.

As Gholdengo provides the needed revenge killing capabilities on Ghost teams, teammates such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult are free to run sets like Choice Specs and Dragon Dance, respectively. Both also break down walls such as Clodsire and Gastrodon; in return, Gholdengo deals with Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Gallade. Skeledirge walls most physical attackers and Fire-types such as Scovillain and Volcarona. Mimikyu provides a safety net against offensive types like rain Water and Ghost, checking Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Flutter Mane for the team, and it loves Gholdengo shutting down defensive walls such as Toxapex with Trick. Entry hazard setters in Brambleghast and Froslass are is also greatly appreciated, as they can set, remove, or prevent entry hazards for Gholdengo; in return, Gholdengo prevents their entry hazards from getting removed by Glimmora. Brambleghast also switches into Ground-types such as Ting-Lu and Great Tusk and deals with Water-types like Gastrodon and Dondozo, while Froslass can spread paralysis with Thunder Wave and bring down an opposing Pokemon with its Destiny Bond.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• With Trick and an immunity to status moves, Gholdengo is a dangerous Choice item attacker for offensive and stall teams alike!

  • Thunderbolt: This 2HKOes Dondozo and deals serious damage to Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Dazzling Gleam Dazzling Gleam deals massive damage to Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon.

  • Nasty Plot: This can be used to give Gholdengo more bite against defensive, slower teams after using Trick.

  • Focus Blast: Though it's accuracy can be an issue, Focus Blast is the best way around Kingambit.

  • Neutral Nature and Nature Mints: Use a neutral nature Gholdengo that has a Timid or Modest Mint used on it. This way, Gholdengo can eat any Berry without being confused after Trick.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Gholdengo gains an extremely useful immunity to Ground, which is especially useful on Choice Specs sets and against users of Fissure such as Dondozo.

  • Ghost: The extra damage from Shadow Ball can make Gholdengo a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Gholdengo a far better chance of defeating Kingambit.

  • Water: In addition to giving Gholdengo a valuable resistance to Fire, this makes Gholdengo deal much more damage to Volcarona and common Tera Fire users such as Dragapult.

  • Steel: Make It Rain becomes very powerful with a Tera boost, at the cost of making Gholdengo vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.
