  • Normal: A Normal Tera type gives Gholdengo the edge against opposing Ghost-types, at the cost of becoming very vulnerable to Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With this, Gholdengo outspeeds key threats such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Flutter Mane.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs make Gholdengo much more difficult to wall, with foes such as Dondozo getting 2HKOed.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Gholdengo mirror matches are common enough that maximizing Speed is usually a wise idea.
  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 212 SpA / 28 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: This bulkier spread for Choice Specs sets allows Gholdengo to survive an unboosted Shadow Ball from opposing Gholdengo, while outspeeding Timid Magnezone and Jolly Tyranitar.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo a terror against slower teams, especially with its good bulk, unpredictable coverage, and diverse Tera Types.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Gholdengo avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure and ease prediction in general.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock lets Gholdengo break through Chansey and Clodsire more easily.

  • Focus Blast: Despite its reliability issues, Focus Blast lets Gholdengo defeat Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Gholdengo gets the jump on dangerous Earthquake users such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is unlikely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

  • Normal: While it's a much worse defensive typing, Tera Normal does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types like Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, at the cost of being weak to Mach Punch.

  • Water: With this Tera type, Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Skeledirge are far less likely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

Items

  • Leftovers: This is the most reliable option for keeping Gholdengo healthy and pairs especially well with Substitute.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak prevents Salt Cure from chipping down Gholdengo, making it far easier for it to run Recover against Garganacl.

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon ruins Breloom's chances of winning the lead war against Gholdengo and makes Hippowdon easy setup bait.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Gholdengo's good bulk, Focus Sash is useful for giving it new opportunities to sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Speed is key to at least speedtie with opposing Gholdengo, and outspeeding several threats close to this Speed tier, such as Dragonite.

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 212 SpA / 28 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: For sets with Recover, this bulkier spread can make sense, allowing Gholdengo to survive Shadow Ball from Gholdengo that lack an offensive item, and outpacing Timid Magnezone and Jolly Tyranitar.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• While Gholdengo's defensive stats aren't remarkable, it's fantastic typing and immunity to status moves like Taunt make it a great defensive Pokemon.

  • Thunder Wave This makes switching into this Gholdengo very difficult, as it can punish its speedier offensive checks like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada.

  • Hex versus Shadow Ball: Hex gives this Gholdengo a good offensive kick against paralyzed foes, but Shadow Ball is worth considering for its consistency.

  • Make It Rain versus Focus Blast: Make It Rain is Gholdengo's most consistent way of dealing damage to Garganacl, but this set's defensive nature makes it difficult to win the one-on-one. Focus Blast isn't nearly as reliable, but it's Gholdengo's best shot at making it past Kingambit.

  • EV Spread:The given EVs outspeed paralyzed Dragapult, while maximizing physical bulk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Avoiding Earthquake against foes like Garchomp makes Tera Flying extremely useful for Gholdengo; this also gives it protection against Fissure from the likes of Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is not incredible defensively, but it does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Mimikyu.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Gholdengo a much better matchup against Dark-type attackers like Roaring Moon, Brute Bonnet, and Meowscarada.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet takes advantage of Gholdengo's excellent typing against physical moves, making it a good way to punish contact moves such as Outrage from Garchomp.

  • Covert Cloak: This is Gholdengo's best shot of outstalling Garganacl, since it grants an immunty to Salt Cure's effect.

  • Weakness Policy While this might seem strange on a defensive Pokemon, Weakness Policy lets Gholdengo beat opposing Gholdengo as long as they lack Choice Specs.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Gholdengo's good bulk and unpredictable Tera types make it a great user of Assault Vest.

  • Dazzling Gleam: This punishes Dark-type revenge killers such as Hydreigon and Meowscarada when combined with Tera.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is Gholdengo's best shot at muscling past Dondozo and also deals good damage to Corviknight and Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Focus Blast: The only chance of getting past Kingambit is the inaccurate Focus Blast.

Tera Types

  • Flying: A Flying-type makes Gholdengo much more difficult to revenge kill with common Earthquake users such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting is Gholdengo's best chance of breaking past Kingambit.

  • Normal: With a Normal Tera type, Gholdengo can defeat several faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Flutter Mane, at the cost of a worse defensive typing and losing to Breloom.

  • Water: With Assault Vest, Gholdengo can tank most Fire-type attacks against it and deal good damage to Volcarona and Iron Moth. Watch out for their Grass-type attacks, though.

sets.name: Defensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Gholdengo uses its great typing and decent bulk to switch into Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Hawlucha, most Mega Medicham, most Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta. Gholdengo's typing and unique ability in Good as Gold make it the premier stopgap to entry hazard removal and a good asset for entry hazard-stacking teams. Gholdengo can switch in on Defoggers like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T—the tier's top Defogger—and can switch in on status moves like Leech Seed from Ferrothorn and Toxic from Clodsire after Gholdengo Terastallizes. A STAB combination of Ghost / Steel hits many targets neutrally, with Shadow Ball being incredibly spammable and Make It Rain hitting Ghost-resistant Pokemon like Garganacl, Tyranitar, and Weavile; the former two are otherwise able to switch in freely. Tera Fairy lets Gholdengo switch out of otherwise crippling Pursuit, and Water lets it stay in on four attacks Kingambit and begin setting up. The removal of a Ground weakness also allows it to take advantage of Heatran, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire. 128 Special Defense EVs let Gholdengo survive two Heat Waves from offensive Tornadus-T from maximum HP, while the Special Attack allows it to OHKO bulky Tornadus-T with Make It Rain after a Nasty Plot; the remaining are put in Defense to take hits from the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar much better after Terastallizing. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Mega Diancie appreciate their hazards staying up for as long as possible. Pokemon like Mega Lopunny appreciate Gholdengo beating common revenge killers in Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zamazenta. Rotom-W is notable in that it checks Pokemon like Mega Swampert, Heatran, and Victini, and it appreciates Gholdengo providing entry hazard control. Gholdengo struggles against Kingambit, which it lets in for free and struggles to switch out of due to Pursuit. Kingambit is punished by Fighting-type teammates such as Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Gholdengo also struggles against Mega Lopunny, which can switch in on stray Shadow Balls and bypass its Fighting immunity with Scrappy. Gholdengo also struggles against Clodsire and opposing Ghost-types, such as Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo. These can be checked by Pursuit users such as Weavile, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar.

sets.name: Leech Seed + Protect
sets.description: Tera Ghost allows Wo-Chien to spinblock and effectively check would-be threats like Maushold and Slither Wing. Tera Poison makes Wo-Chien immune to being poisoned while giving it a Fighting resistance. Alternative spread: 252 HP / 240 Def / 16 SpD

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description: Tera Ghost allows Wo-Chien to spinblock and effectively check would-be threats like Maushold and Slither Wing. Tera Poison makes Wo-Chien immune to being poisoned while giving it a Fighting resistance. Alternative spread: 252 HP / 240 Def / 16 SpD

sets.name: Bulky Wall
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Wo-Chien to survive a spread Heat Wave from Beads of Ruin-boosted Choice Specs Chi-Yu, then invests the remaining EVs into Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
• Ice Spinner is an alternative to Icicle Crash because of its better accuracy, but it is slightly weaker, cannot flinch, and is a contact move.
  • Ice Shard hits Miraidon and Koraidon for super effective damage, 2HKOing the former, and 2HKOes Flutter Mane reliably. Sucker Punch may be considered over Ice Shard, as it does more damage to Iron Bundle and can KO Flutter Mane, but it misses out on revenge killing Koraidon and is often prediction-reliant.
  • Sacred Sword allows Chien-Pao to OHKO Chi-Yu, Kingambit, and opposing Chien-Pao, which otherwise resist its STAB moves.
  • Chien-Pao can use Tera Dark to make Crunch stronger and 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex if it gets lucky with a Defense drop. Chien-Pao can also use Tera Ice in order to 2HKO Corviknight more reliably and boost Ice Shard damage—notably against Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon. Lastly, Tera Electric Chien-Pao with Tera Blast can easily break through bulky checks like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo.
  • Chien-Pao fits best with other strong wallbreakers that benefit from the removal of defensive walls. These include Koraidon, Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk.
  • Defensive partners like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge are mandatory to handle fast and strong threats like Koraidon and Miraidon, as Chien-Pao cannot OHKO them if they are at full health. Additionally, Great Tusk and Ting-Lu can set up entry hazards, which is crucial for getting chip on defensive walls.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Icicle Crash 2HKOes Corviknight and avoids Rocky Helmet, while Ice Spinner is more accurate and has the bonus of removing Electric Terrain.
  • Sacred Sword hits checks such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Another option is to run a double priority combination with Ice Shard and Sucker Punch. Sucker Punch hits very crucial Pokemon that Ice Shard can't, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fire Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle.
  • An Adamant nature allows Chien-Pao to achieve ridiculous feats such as revenge killing Flutter Mane from 90% HP with Ice Shard. A Jolly nature lets Chien-Pao Speed tie with Koraidon, Miraidon, opposing Jolly Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane, giving Chien-Pao the freedom to click its strongest moves less reluctantly.
  • Tera Dark allows Chien-Pao to 2HKO the entire tier while letting it still switch into weaker moves such as Shadow Ball. Tera Ice gives Chien-Pao the ability to OHKO Flutter Mane with Ice Shard, making it a terrific late-game cleaner.
  • Choice Band Chien-Pao is a wallbreaker that is best suited for bulky offense structures that love its revenge killing and wallbreaking capabilities.
  • Pokemon like Iron Treads, Hatterene, and Koraidon, which can provide entry hazard control or pivoting, are excellent teammates for Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance makes Chien-Pao immensely threatening, letting it break through bulky foes such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Ice Spinner is a more reliable option thanks to its perfect accuracy, but Icicle Crash's power and flinch chance greatly help out against all foes that can take a hit from Chien-Pao, such as Corviknight and Great Tusk.
  • Ice Shard is a reliable priority attack mainly used to better deal with Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Sucker Punch can be used as a stronger but prediction-reliant alternative that OHKOes Flutter Mane without a boost and OHKOes the likes of Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a boost. It also provides a favorable roll to OHKO Koraidon if it has Terastallized into the Fire typing.
  • Tera Dark boosts Crunch, allowing Chien-Pao to more reliably beat physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Dark Chien-Pao holding Life Orb can OHKO both Pokemon after a Swords Dance boost.
  • Tera Ice can be used instead to boost Chien Pao's Ice-type attacks. This also makes Ice Shard a better revenge killing option.
  • Sacred Sword can be used to hit foes that resist Chien-Pao's STAB moves, like Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao.
  • Life Orb is the primary item choice because it gives Chien-Pao a lot of power while allowing it to run a Jolly nature and not lose out on potential OHKOs.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots sacrifices a lot of power but gives Chien-Pao the ability to ignore entry hazards, allowing it to come in and potentially set up multiple times throughout a game.
  • Black Glasses in conjunction with an Adamant nature can be used as an alternative to Life Orb to not have recoil while still being able to OHKO the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex after obtaining a Swords Dance boost and using Tera Dark.
  • This set can be used as both an early-game wallbreaker and a late-game sweeper thanks to Chien-Pao's strong STAB attacks and priority moves.
  • Chien-Pao has very little defensive utility, so having a defensive core for it to fall back on is recommended for balance teams. On offensive teams, it can afford to run Focus Sash to take at least one hit from foes that would usually threaten it out.
  • Great Tusk is Chien-Pao's best teammate, as Great Tusk can handle one of Chien-Pao's hardest checks in Koraidon and provide Rapid Spin support. Rapid Spin also helps keep Focus Sash intact.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Chien-Pao is one of the most threatening sweepers in Anything Goes due to its solid typing, ability, and stats. Swords Dance allows Chien-Pao to break through walls such as Toxapex, Alomomola, and Corviknight. Ice Spinner can be considered over Icicle Crash due to its perfect accuracy, but it is a slightly weaker contact move that cannot flinch. Sucker Punch is the preferred priority move option, allowing it to OHKO Flutter Mane without a boost, as well as Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a Swords Dance. Alternatively, Ice Shard OHKOes Koraidon, Miraidon, and Flutter Mane at +2 Attack after Stealth Rock. Heavy-Duty Boots is the best item on this set, but Life Orb and Focus Sash are solid picks on hyper offense builds and other teams with good entry hazard control. Life Orb lets Chien-Pao get some crucial OHKOs at +2 Attack, notably against Miraidon and Koraidon with Ice Shard and Corviknight and Toxapex with Crunch. Tera Dark makes its Dark-type moves stronger while shedding the weaknesses from its Ice typing, notably reducing Stealth Rock damage and weakening Iron Head and Body Press from Corviknight as well as Torch Song from Skeledirge. Chien-Pao fits best on offensive teams and flourishes with other wallbreakers like Miraidon, Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk. On bulkier builds, teammates like defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads set entry hazards while checking fast Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon. If forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots, it is essential to pair Chien-Pao with lead entry hazard setters like Glimmora and Froslass on offensive teams and Iron Treads and Great Tusk on bulkier teams, as they additionally prevent opposing entry hazards from going up.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker (Dark)
sets.description:
Chien-Pao is an imposing force for any Dark team with its sky high Speed, blitzing past threats like Iron Valiant and Greninja, and great Attack. Sword of Ruin lets it beat physical walls like Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Toxapex, though it doesn't have great bulk and has to watch out for super effective priority moves from Scizor, Lokix, and Slither Wing and struggles to break past walls like Dondozo and Quagsire. With Swords Dance, it can boost up to beat even the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex if it has Crunch. Fighting-type coverage picks off Dark-types like Kingambit and Greninja. Sacred Sword picks off weakened Garganacl, while Brick Break destroys opposing Dark or Fairy team's dual screens. Ice Shard stops common revenge killers like Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Flutter Mane, and Great Tusk.

As Chien-Pao focuses on breaking down foes with its sheer power and Speed, it appreciates support from its teammates. Ting-Lu can set up Stealth Rock and Spikes while Skuntank can set up Toxic Spikes and pressure Fairy-types, all of which make wallbreaking for Chien-Pao easier. Grimmsnarl provides Chien-Pao with dual screens support, making setting up easier. Sableye can burn opposing Pokemon and cripple them with Taunt and Knock Off, removing Heavy-Duty Boots and making foes susceptible to hazards, while also acting as a Fighting-type move switch-in. Choice Specs Greninja can clean up after Chien-Pao has done enough damage while also countering Fire-types that would annoy Chien-Pao such as Skeledirge and Cinderace if Chien-Pao does not have Crunch. Hydreigon can break Steel-types for Chien-Pao if it foregoes Fighting-type coverage or Swords Dance, beating Fighting-neutral Steel-types like Corviknight and Scizor. Choice Scarf Meowscarada is able to threaten Pokemon that counter Chien-Pao such as Quaquaval and Choice Scarf users such as Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, and Great Tusk, while also being able to pivot to Chien-Pao with U-Turn.

sets.name: Choice Band (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its high Speed and decent STAB coverage that hits common physically defensive walls like Ting-Lu and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster offensive threats such as Barraskewda and common Choice Scarf users; alternatively, Ice Shard is weaker but hits Roaring Moon super effectively. Sacred Sword beats Steel-types like Kingambit and bypasses Garganacl's Defense boosts. Chien-Pao's best fit is on balance teams that can provide it with safe switch-ins and take advantage of the holes it creates. Iron Moth and Sandy Shocks are recommended teammates, as both can help Chien-Pao beat the incredibly troublesome Dondozo and Toxapex. Corviknight and Iron Treads are both good teammates thanks to their ability to pivot Chien-Pao in safely, in addition to clearing Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Dazzling
sets.description: Dazzling Chien-Pao boasts high Attack and Speed, which enable it to check common priority users such as Aerilate Dragonite and Triage Hatterene as well as offensive threats like Sucker Punch Meowscarada. Sacred Sword can be used to deal with Kingambit and Garganacl, which can otherwise safely switch into Chien-Pao, while Ice Shard can be used as a priority option for faster threats like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Dragon Dance Dragonite. Heavy-Duty Boots allows for Chien-Pao to more reliably check its common targets, while Life Orb can be used to wallbreak more effectively. Frail offensive teammates like Gengar and Iron Moth appreciate Chien-Pao's ability to handle priority users that they'd otherwise be susceptible to. Chien-Pao can have a hard time breaking through physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Dondozo, so pairing it with a specially offensive threat that can handle them like Sandy Shocks or Rotom-W is advised. Chien-Pao is also quite frail, so slow pivots like Corviknight and Slowking can bring it onto the field safely.

sets.name: Defensive Hazards
sets.description:
Ting-Lu is an incredible entry hazard setter for bulky offense and balance teams alike thanks to its combination of gargantuan defensive stats, good utility movepool, and an amazing defensive ability in Vessel of Ruin. It also has a great typing that lets it answer threats such as Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge. Whirlwind is incredibly useful for thwarting setup Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Volcarona. Ruination lets Ting-Lu deal consistent damage to bulky Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Hatterene. Tera Poison lets Ting-Lu act as an answer to Iron Valiant while giving it an immunity to poison damage from Clodsire’s Toxic and letting it absorb Toxic Spikes from the likes of Glimmora and Iron Moth. Meanwhile, Tera Fairy is a generally solid defensive typing, letting it more reliably check Pokemon such as Dragapult and Great Tusk. Maximum Special Defense, in tandem with Ting-Lu's ability, makes it a more consistent check to special attackers such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Volcarona.

Ting-Lu’s premier defensive profile makes it most proficient on bulky offense and balance teams that can supply enough offensive momentum to make up for Ting-Lu’s relative passivity. Pokemon that can supplement offensive prowess to make up for Ting-Lu's passivity such as Iron Valiant and Kingambit make for excellent partners, as they can assist against threats like opposing Iron Valiant, Dondozo, and Great Tusk. Without Ruination, Ting-Lu is utterly helpless against Corviknight, so Pokemon that can threaten it such as Gholdengo and Cinderace make for excellent partners. Bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex appreciate Ting-Lu's immunity to Electric while being quite helpful against Pokemon like Kingambit and Quaquaval in return. Other defensive Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight also make for excellent partners, being helpful against Pokemon like Scizor while appreciating Ting-Lu’s ability to check Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Additional entry hazard setters such as Garganacl and Great Tusk allow Ting-Lu to fit Ruination into its moveset more capably, so it is less passive in the face of Ground-immune threats like Corviknight and Air Balloon Gholdengo.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu is a key Pokemon for many playstyles in SV Ubers, ranging from stall to bulky offense.
  • Whirlwind helps Ting-Lu against Substitute users like Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur and other threatening hyper offense Pokemon such as Agility + Calm Mind Miraidon.
  • Tera Steel lets Ting-Lu check Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle. Tera Ghost, on the other hand, lets Ting-Lu soft check physical attackers such as Great Tusk, Koraidon locked into Close Combat, Iron Hands, and Iron Valiant. Tera Fire is another option that lets Ting-Lu soft check and beat Chi-Yu one-on-one. Lasty, Tera Fairy is also an option to check Dragon-types and have an overall good defensive typing against Pokemon that would normally overwhelm Ting-Lu, such as Choice Specs Miraidon.
  • Ting-Lu works best as a defensive pivot on bulky offense teams, capitalizing on its massive natural bulk and ability Vessel of Ruin to set Spikes against Pokemon like Miraidon and Chi-Yu, tank big hits, and recover HP with Protect.
  • Pokemon that appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to wear down opposing Ground-types with Spikes, such as Miraidon and Koraidon, are excellent partners for it. Other defensive Pokemon such as Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Blissey relieve pressure of Ting-Lu by helping to check Miraidon; they also check Flutter Mane, and Corviknight additionally helps check Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• This EV spread and nature ensures that Ting Lu always OHKOs Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake, and then uses the remaining EVs to maximize its special bulk.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Ting-Lu is a reliable special wall and a premier Miraidon check. Regenerator gives Ting-Lu reliable recovery without conflicting with Assault Vest. Nuzzle discourages dangerous attackers like Zacian-C and Palkia-O from switching in. U-turn allows Ting-Lu to safely bring in teammates thanks to its low Speed. Ceaseless Edge forces chip damage on foes, letting offensive teammates wallbreak more easily. Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Covert Cloak, making Ting-Lu's own utility more effective; it also punishes Imposter users attempting to gain Regenerator. Ting-Lu fits best on balance teams, which appreciate its ability to spread paralysis and safely bring in teammates thanks to its huge bulk. Dangerous wallbreakers like Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Palkia-O help maximize the effectiveness of U-turn pivoting. Ting-Lu is unable to naturally check Palkia-O and Quiver Dance Arceus-Water, so a teammate that helps shore up this weakness, such as Arceus-Grass or Hisuian Goodra, is appreciated. Tera Fairy provides an immunity to Dragon, allowing Ting-Lu to block Dragon Energy from Palkia-O and Choice Specs Miraidon; alternatively, Tera Grass provides a Water resistance, covering for Palkia-O's Water Spout and coverage from Miraidon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Dragonite and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Focus Blast Gengar can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Gengar and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu is an outstanding wall, utilizing its immense bulk, Vessel of Ruin, and useful defensive typing to check threats such as Dragapult, Espathra, and Tapu Koko well. With access to both Stealth Rock and Spikes, Ting-Lu is a flexible entry hazard setter that supports its teammates well. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to pressure Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, which don't care about its Earthquake. Rest is an option for more longevity across the length of a game, but it renders Ting-Lu useless for a few turns. Whirlwind works exceptionally well with other hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Mega Diancie, as it lets Ting-Lu wear down Pokemon quickly for its teammates, as well as phazing setup sweepers such as Espathra and Dragonite easily. Water is the primary Tera type for Ting-Lu, being overall solid defensively and letting it switch into Barraskewda and Weavile easily. Ghost is also a solid Tera type, as it lets Ting-Lu check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant, as well as blocking Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk. Water-types such as Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Floatzel easily force Ting-Lu out, making Water-resistant teammates such as Ferrothorn, Slowbro, and Dragonite great partners. Due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to Fighting-types like Mega Medicham, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta, Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge work really well alongside it. Gholdengo in particular forms a potent defensive core with Ting-Lu, preventing its entry hazards from being Defogged. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant all pair amazingly with Ting-Lu's hazard support. Lastly, due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to hazard chip damage, entry hazard removers like Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk are invaluable partners.

sets.name: Feesh (Offensive Wallbreaker)
sets.description:
• Overheat hits extremely hard and can 2HKO even the bulkiest of Pokemon. Fire Blast and Flamethrower can be used to KO foes without Chi-Yu suffering a Special Attack drop, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy.
  • The only reason to run Timid over Modest is to outspeed Jolly Great Tusk, Jolly Annihilape, and fast Iron Treads with Special Defense investment.
  • Tera Fire allows Chi-Yu to turn 2HKOs to OHKOs, for example OHKOing opposing Chi-Yu with Overheat. Tera Fire also lets it 2HKO any prominent special wall, including Toxapex, Blissey, and Ting-Lu, OHKOing them with sun.
  • Choice Specs Chi-Yu is a wallbreaker, suited best for offensive teams. Koraidon is an excellent teammate because it sets sun and pivots Chi-Yu in with U-turn. Koraidon and Chi-Yu also threaten each other's checks, like Koraidon threatening Blissey and Garganacl and Chi-Yu threatening Skeledirge and Dondozo.
  • Helpful teammates are those that can get Chi-Yu in safely and force out its few checks. Corviknight and Koraidon are noteworthy examples, pivoting into special walls such as Ting-Lu. Lures such as Heavy Slam Koraidon and Great Tusk, which beat Dachsbun, and Psyshock Flutter Mane, which beats Toxapex and Blissey, are also appreciated teammates.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Fire Blast is Chi-Yu's strongest STAB move without any stat drops. Psychic is an alternative that 2HKOes common switch-ins such as Dachsbun and Toxapex. Overheat facilitates revenge killing, hitting even Pokemon that resist it such as Koraidon hard, and is a better midground play.
  • Memento serves as a way to facilitate sweepers like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon that Chi-Yu is usually paired with.
  • Tera Fire powers up Flamethrower and Overheat to nuclear levels, turning 2HKOs against Pokemon such as Koraidon into OHKOs. Tera Dark nullifies Chi-Yu's Stealth Rock weakness while making Dark Pulse 2HKO Dachsbun and Toxapex. Tera Grass should only be used with Tera Blast; it gives Chi-Yu nice resistances to Ground and Water and allows Chi-Yu to OHKO Great Tusk and 2HKO Ting-Lu after Spikes damage.
  • Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a revenge killer best suited for offensive teams.
  • Pokemon that can get Chi-Yu safely into the field, such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Corviknight, are excellent teammates for it. Koraidon also sets up sun, further boosting Chi-Yu's Fire-type attacks.
  • Ting-Lu and Glimmora can set entry hazards to guarantee some 2HKOs, such as against opposing Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot Chi-Yu can threaten to KO foes it couldn't otherwise, such as Ting-Lu and Blissey. Overheat hits extremely hard and threatens to OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Flamethrower is valuable for its perfect accuracy.
  • A Modest nature alongside Life Orb lets Chi-Yu OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used instead to give Chi-Yu more opportunities to switch in, but the loss of power is notable.
  • Chi-Yu fits best on offensive teams with Pokemon such as Cyclizar and Grimmsnarl that can facilitate its setup. Sticky Web support from Masquerain is also useful, as it lets Chi-Yu outrun Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon and KO them at +2.
  • Chi-Yu's best partner is Koraidon, since it sets up sun, can safely bring Chi-Yu into play with U-turn, and threatens Blissey. Other good partners are special attackers that benefit from special walls being neutered by Chi-Yu, such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo. Great Tusk is also greatly appreciated, as it can remove Stealth Rock and threatens Blissey and Ting-Lu for Chi-Yu. Chi-Yu can deal with Corviknight and Dondozo in return.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Chi-Yu is one of the metagame's most devastating wallbreakers. Beads of Ruin and a high Special Attack stat let it consistently force a KO whenever it comes in. Overheat allows Chi-Yu to OHKO or 2HKO even bulky resistant foes, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy and not dropping Chi-Yu's Special Attack. Dark Pulse allows Chi-Yu to immediately threaten Fire-resistant Pokemon like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Garganacl, 2HKOing or OHKOing them without sun. Fire Blast can reach important damage thresholds, such as 2HKOing Blissey, without the Special Attack drop that accompanies Overheat, with Psychic instead preventing Toxapex from scouting Chi-Yu's move. Tera Fire turns Chi-Yu's 2HKOs against Pokemon like Toxapex and Double Dance Miraidon into OHKOs under sun, and it guarantees 2HKOs on even the bulkiest defensive Pokemon like Blissey and Garganacl, OHKOing them in sun and with minor chip damage. A Modest nature is preferred, but a Timid nature can be considered if Jolly Great Tusk is an issue. Koraidon is an incredible partner, setting sun and bringing Chi-Yu in with U-turn; in exchange, Chi-Yu greatly threatens all of Koraidon's checks. Pivots such as Corviknight and the aforementioned Koraidon are greatly appreciated, as they can let Chi-Yu switch in without worrying about its poor bulk. Entry hazard removal from Great Tusk, Corviknight, or Iron Treads is very helpful due to Chi-Yu's weakness to Stealth Rock and its tendency to switch out after a KO. Chi-Yu is often forced out by faster Pokemon like Miraidon and Koraidon, so defensive switch-ins to them like Clodsire, Toxapex, Ting-Lu, and Corviknight are good partners.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Dragonite and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
Dragon Dance Roaring Moon is one of the tier's most threatening late-game setup sweepers due to its high offensive stats, strong coverage moves, and decent bulk. Earthquake is a strong, consistent coverage option that hits Kingambit, Garganacl, Iron Hands, and Clodsire super effectively. Roost, on the other hand, gives Roaring Moon access to reliable recovery, which gives it more setup opportunities throughout the game even if its Booster Energy is already used up. Acrobatics has fantastic coverage, as it hits Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Breloom super effectively and should always be run alongside Tera Flying to maximize its power. Iron Head is a viable alternative to Acrobatics and should always be run alongside Tera Steel, as it deals with Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Hatterene simultaneously. Tera Flying removes all of Roaring Moon's baseline weaknesses bar Ice, gives it a resistance to Fighting- and Bug-type attacks, a Ground immunity, and a STAB boost to Acrobatics. Tera Steel, though more niche, allows Roaring Moon to resist Hatterene's Dazzling Gleam, Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Tera Normal Dragonite's Extreme Speed. A Jolly nature is typically run to outspeed Booster Energy Iron Valiant after a Dragon Dance, but Adamant is a decent alternative, particularly on teams that allow Roaring Moon to obtain more than one Dragon Dance boost. After a Dragon Dance, Adamant Roaring Moon can more easily OHKO defensive variants of Gholdengo and Great Tusk.

Dragon Dance Roaring Moon best functions on offensive teams, pairing well with setup sweepers that can wear down each other's checks. Iron Valiant can opt out of running Psyshock, since Roaring Moon breaks past Clodsire for it, and Breloom can more effectively utilize its STAB moves and Spore once Roaring Moon eliminates Gholdengo. Dondozo and Tera Fairy Skeledirge are major threats to Roaring Moon due to their ability to ignore its boosts with Unaware, while strong priority users like Dragonite and Breloom can revenge kill Roaring Moon thanks to its low Defense. Ting-Lu can force Roaring Moon out with Whirlwind, and Choice Band Iron Hands survives a boosted Earthquake from full health and can OHKO Roaring Moon with Close Combat. Iron Valiant offers immediate damage against Dondozo, Iron Hands, and Ting-Lu due to its excellent mixed coverage. Offensive Great Tusk and Technician Breloom can help wear down Ting-Lu with their super effective STAB moves, and Breloom's Technician-boosted Bullet Seed can also break past Dondozo. Grimmsnarl's ability to set up dual screens allows Roaring Moon to set up multiple Dragon Dances and survive attacks from Dragonite. Orthworm is a niche option that sets entry hazards and provides a slow Shed Tail to get Roaring Moon in safely behind a Substitute, allowing for much easier setup opportunities against opposing status users like Rotom-W and protecting it from priority moves from Dragonite and Breloom.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With Dragon Dance and Acrobatics, Roaring Moon is a strong sweeper on offensive teams, with coverage to beat almost all Pokemon.
  • Tera Flying allows Roaring Moon to set up on Great Tusk and Body Press Corviknight and boosts Acrobatics's power to achieve feats such as OHKOing Toxapex and Ting-Lu after two Dragon Dances and entry hazard or slight chip damage.
  • Crunch is more reliable, having a chance to drop Defense with no potential drawback, while Jaw Lock has the potential to give Roaring Moon a free chance to set up when paired with Roost, assuming a favorable target is trapped. If an unfavorable target is trapped, however, it has a major downside, making it less consistent.
  • Roost gives Roaring Moon more opportunities to use Dragon Dance, turning weaker Pokemon like Brave Bird Corviknight and Whirpool Alomomola into setup fodder.
  • Earthquake hits Kingambit, Garganacl, and Iron Treads, which can otherwise survive hits and wear down Roaring Moon.
  • Taunt stops defensive Pokemon like Haze Toxapex, Will-O-Wisp Skeledirge, and Whirlwind Ting-Lu from dealing with Roaring Moon, making it devastating against bulkier teams if positioned right.
  • Hyper offense leads such as Glimmora, Froslass, and Grimmsnarl all give Roaring Moon good support to break through a team more easily.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk, Tera Fire Koraidon, and Tera Fairy Miraidon can all be used to bait Chien-Pao and take it out, helping Roaring Moon greatly, as it is one of the most reliable revenge killers that can be used against it.
  • On bulkier teams, Roaring Moon requires teammates that can switch into Ice-type moves from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, making Toxapex and specially defensive Corviknight great partners. The latter can also pivot with U-turn, giving Roaring Moon more chances to set up on defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Full Moon (Choice Band)
sets.description:
• Earthquake lets Roaring Moon break past Pokemon that would otherwise check it, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and especially Kingambit.
  • Iron Head lets Roaring Moon hit Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Tera Fairy Garganacl and Skeledirge super effectively.
  • U-turn lets Roaring Moon generate offensive momentum for its team and is especially useful against targets Roaring Moon scares out, like Skeledirge without Tera Fairy and Gholdengo.
  • The given EVs and a Jolly nature ensure Roaring Moon's Speed is boosted in sunlight, letting it get the jump on crucial threats like unboosted non-Choice Scarf Koraidon and Miraidon and threaten them with its STAB Dragon Claw. The remaining 36 Special Defense EVs improve Roaring Moon's chances to survive Iron Bundle's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock while giving it a chance to survive Overheat in sun from Modest Choice Specs Chi-Yu.
  • Tera Dark strengthens Roaring Moon's Crunch to the point where it always 2HKOs physically defensive Corviknight and always 3HKOs Dondozo while easing predictions with Earthquake against Garganacl.
  • Tera Steel lets Roaring Moon resist otherwise super effective Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type attacks from the likes of Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, Koraidon, and Miraidon. Tera Steel also powers up Roaring Moon's Iron Head.
  • Tera Fairy allows Roaring Moon to resist Fighting-type attacks while becoming immune to Dragon-type attacks, letting it defeat Koraidon and Iron Valiant, both of which outspeed and threaten to OHKO Roaring Moon otherwise.
  • Roaring Moon loves the support of Koraidon, as it activates Roaring Moon's Protosynthesis via Orichalcum Pulse and reliably threatens Pokemon such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Ice-types like Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle. In return, Roaring Moon threatens non-Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Koraidon and Roaring Moon both struggle with defensive Great Tusk, so they can team up with Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao, which threaten all Great Tusk sets. Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao also threaten Koraidon and Miraidon, with Iron Bundle naturally outspeeding non-Choice Scarf variants and Chien-Pao threatening them with priority Ice Shard.
  • Defensive Great Tusk and Ting-Lu also work well with Roaring Moon, as they can set up entry hazards for Roaring Moon's team and check Koraidon and Miraidon, respectively. Great Tusk in particular can use Rapid Spin, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in, while Ting-Lu can phaze threatening boosters like Espathra with Whirlwind and set up Spikes.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight can check Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, both of which outspeed and threaten Roaring Moon, and can Defog hazards away, giving Roaring Moon more opportunities to switch in.
  • Roaring Moon can easily pivot into Chi-Yu, which takes advantage of the sun set by Koraidon and threatens walls like Great Tusk, Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Terastallized Skeledirge.
  • Gholdengo also makes for a decent partner, as not only does it have perfect defensive synergy with Roaring Moon, but it can also reliably block all common forms of hazard removal. This allows Roaring Moon’s team to keep up hazards, in particular Spikes, for it to eventually break down walls.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Acrobatics
sets.description:
• With Booster Energy juicing up Tera Flying Acrobatics and one of Roaring Moon's stats, it's an excellent choice for late-game sweeping!

  • Earthquake: Earthquake is Roaring Moon's best shot at beating Kingambit.

  • Taunt: Taunt is the best way around troublesome defensive foes, such as Dondozo, Corviknight, and Tera Fairy Skeledirge.

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop is the preferred Dark-type STAB move over Crunch, since it can shut down important sound moves from Skeledirge, Volcarona, and Sylveon.

  • Roost: Recovery really allows Roaring Moon to take advantage of its good special bulk, especially if investing in it.

EV Spreads

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: This spread gives Roaring Moon a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, making it a good revenge killer.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: This simple spread makes Protosynthesis boost Attack, potentially letting Roaring Moon 2HKO Skeledirge with Acrobatics.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 28 Def / 196 SpD / 28 Spe with Careful: This spread takes a slower, bulkier approach to boosting, getting a Special Defense boost from Protosynthesis and outspeeding Dragapult after one Dragon Dance. This spread is best used with Roost, and Taunt is also highly recommended to get past Skeledirge.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• While Roaring Moon is most known for using Booster Energy and Acrobatics, other Tera Types and moves can let it defeat a different set of threats and be used earlier in the game.

  • Throat Chop: Throat Chop shutting down important sound moves such as Volcarona's Bug Buzz makes it the better option over Crunch.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is good at punishing Fairy Terastallization, especially when using Tera Steel Roaring Moon.

  • Roost: Even with the offensive nature of this set, Roost is good against Choice locked foes.

  • Scale Shot: While lowering Roaring Moon's Defense makes it even more vulnerable to priority, the Speed boost can lead to some surprising sweeps when picking off foes. It also has a shot of OHKOing offensive Dragonite through Multiscale.

Other Options

  • Outrage: This is by far Roaring Moon's strongest attack, though being locked in can easily lead to counter play via Terastallization and Fairy-types.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel's good matchup against Fairy- and Dragon-types makes it a prime candidate.

  • Fire: With Tera Fire, Roaring Moon gains a useful resistance to Bullet Punch and cooks Scizor, Tinkaton, and Corviknight with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy is an excellent answer to faster Dragon-types such Dragapult and Choice Scarf Garchomp and gives Roaring Moon a vital Fighting-type resistance against otherwise troublesome foes like Great Tusk, Iron Hands, and Annihilape.

  • Ghost: Roaring Moon gains a useful Extreme Speed and Mach Punch immunity, making Dragonite and Breloom far less problematic. This is especially useful if using Scale Shot.

Items

  • Life Orb: While making Roaring Moon more vulnerable to priority, the reliable damage output means Roaring Moon doesn't have to set up to deal massive damage.

  • Booster Energy: Beyond making Roaring Moon more suited for late-game sweeping, Booster Energy is perfect for making opponents think its the more common Acrobatics set.

  • Loaded Dice: When using Scale Shot, Loaded Dice is a strong consideration, letting +1 Roaring Moon always OHKO offensive Dragonite and almost always OHKO Breloom with Scale Shot.

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry is perfect for taking advantage of Pokemon that are likely to inflict status on Roaring Moon, such as Tinkaton, Rotom-W, and Umbreon.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: This classic spread will give Roaring Moon an Attack boost from Protosynthesis.

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe: This is the spread to use if a Speed Boost from Protosynthesis is needed.

sets.name: Jaw Lock Trapper
sets.description:
• With Jaw Lock, Roost, and Taunt, Roaring Moon is capable of severely punishing defensive answers to it, which is worth the risk of trapping itself.

  • Dragon Dance: If trapping a very passive foe such as Hippowdon, Roaring Moon can threaten to get to +6, slicing through teams like a hot knife through butter!

  • Substitute: Substitute works great with Toxic Spikes support, giving Roaring Moon a means to rack up Toxic damage.

  • Earthquake: This prevents Roaring Moon from being walled by Kingambit.

  • U-turn: U-turn gives Roaring Moon a way to switch out of bad Jaw Lock matchups, reducing its risk greatly without using up an item slot.

Other Options

  • Acrobatics: If using Booster Energy and Tera Flying, Acrobatics is far more powerful than Jaw Lock, punishing Annihilape and Great Tusk in particular.

Tera Types

  • Poison: In addition to providing a vital resistance to Fairy- and Fighting-type attacks, Tera Poison lets Roaring Moon freely switch into Toxic, which would ruin this set otherwise.

  • Fairy: Taking on Dragon- and Fighting-type attacks makes Fairy a reliable Tera type.

  • Flying: Tera Flying grants Roaring Moon safety from Garganacl and Dondozo's Fissure and pairs nicely with Acrobatics.

  • Don't Use Ghost: Tera Ghost is tempting to allow Roaring Moon to switch out of Jaw Lock, but be warned: you must Terastallize only on the turn after using Jaw Lock, because otherwise, the trapping effect will fail to activate if using Jaw Lock as a Ghost-type!

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Dragon Dance, the residual recovery makes setting up multiple Dragon Dances much easier.

  • Shed Shell: Shed Shell lets Roaring Moon switch out of Jaw Lock, massively reducing the risk.

  • Booster Energy: This turns Tera Flying Acrobatics into a powerful form of offense.

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Making Roaring Moon immune to Toxic Spikes gives it much more flexibility against stall teams with Toxic Spike setters such as Clodsire and Toxapex.

  • Protective Pads: Protective Pads will guard Roaring Moon against Volcarona's Flame Body and Rocky Helmet for otherwise good trapping targets such as Dondozo and Clodsire.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 4 Atk / 196 Def / 36 SpD / 28 Spe with Impish: This EV spread outspeeds Dragapult after one Dragon Dance, avoids a 2HKO from Iron Bundle if Roaring Moon is Terastallized, and avoids a 2HKO from an unboosted Dragonite Tera Normal Extreme Speed.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 28 Def / 196 SpD / 28 Spe with Careful: This spread gets a Special Defense boost from Protosynthesis while still outspeeding Dragapult after one Dragon Dance.

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: While much less bulky than the other spreads, maximum Speed ensures Roaring Moon outspeeds Iron Valiant, Scream Tail, and Dragon Dance Tyranitar. The former two can ruin Roaring Moon with Encore.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• With great offenses and U-turn, Roaring Moon is a good and unexpected choice for pivoting.

  • Throat Chop versus Jaw Lock: Shutting down troublesome sound moves such as Torch Song and Bug Buzz make Throat Chop the superior choice over Crunch. If using Assault Vest, Jaw Lock's trapping capabilities come in handy, especially with U-turn reducing its risk.

  • Iron Head: Iron Head is good coverage against Tera Fairy-types with Levitate such as Rotom-W and Hydreigon.

  • Outrage: Outrage is a risky move, but it excels at cleaning teams in the late game.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Tera Steel gives Roaring Moon a good matchup against Fairy types with Iron Head, and the Stealth Rock resistances lets it pivot out with less consequences.

  • Fire: Tera Fire's Stealth Rock weakness is a bit problematic with U-turn, but has great offensive and defensive synergy, letting Roaring Moon take Fairy-type attacks, and roast Scizor and Air Balloon Tinkaton with Tera Blast.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy not only absorbs Dragon-type attacks, but it also massively improves Roaring Moon's matchups against strong Fighting-types such as Iron Hands, Great Tusk, and Annihilape via Tera Blast.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: A Choice Scarf in wing will let Roaring Moon outpace some of its common revenge killers, such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Dragapult.

  • Choice Band: Choice Band gives Roaring Moon incredible wallbreaking power, now being able to 2HKO Skeledirge and Dondozo with Outrage.

  • Assault Vest: Roaring Moon makes for a great bulky using of Assault Vest, being able to easily take on Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane when Terastallized into the correct type.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: The old-school offensive spread gives Roaring Moon an Attack boost from Protosynthesis.

  • 220 Atk / 36 Def / 252 Spe: This spread gives Roaring Moon a Speed boost from Protosynthesis, which can be useful if running Choice Band on a sun team.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Roaring Moon's Dragon / Dark typing and high special bulk enable it to switch into Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and other special attackers, setting it apart from other offensive pivots like Greninja and Iron Moth. Earthquake forces out Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Moth and Kingambit. Iron Head targets bulky Fairy-types such as Florges and Scream Tail, while Stone Edge hits threats such as Dragonite and Volcarona. Roaring Moon fits best on teams in need of a pivot with both longevity and a Speed tier that exceeds the likes of Chien-Pao and Barraskewda. Roaring Moon struggles to break past physically defensive foes like Levitate Garganacl, so it appreciates having strong special attackers such as Greninja and Gengar as teammates. Steel-types like Corviknight and physical walls like Dondozo are great for patching up Roaring Moon's defensive blind spots.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Roaring Moon serves as a great specially defensive pivot, able to check various prominent special attackers like Iron Moth and Sandy Shocks with its good bulk and defensive typing. Crunch and Earthquake provide great coverage against the likes of Gengar and Iron Moth, Rock Slide consistently hits Volcarona while Stone Edge OHKOes fully defensive Volcarona after Stealth Rock, and Dragon Tail can punish setup and rack up entry hazard chip. Frail offensive attackers like Swords Dance Ceruledge and Cinderace appreciate Roaring Moon getting them onto the field safely. Roaring Moon, despite its great bulk, can fail against Fairy-types, especially Triage Hatterene, so partners like specially defensive Corviknight partner well with Roaring Moon. Corviknight can double as much appreciated hazard removal. Roaring Moon also struggles against most physical attackers and appreciates strong physical walls like Intimidate Corviknight and Fluffy Dondozo as partners.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Iron Valiant functions as a special wallbreaker thanks to its speed, power, and coverage moves. Psyshock hits Poison-types like Clodsire, Toxapex, and Amoonguss. Shadow Ball targets Gholdengo and Skeledirge, while Thunderbolt is used to hit Corviknight, as well as doing super effective damage to Toxapex, Tera Flying Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Trick is another option to cripple common switch-ins such as Clodsire, Skeledirge, Toxapex, and Volcarona. Focus Blast threatens an OHKO on Garganacl while greatly damaging Corviknight. However, Aura Sphere is another option that is more consistent thanks to its accuracy, though it misses out on the damage output of Focus Blast. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast and removes Iron Valiant's weakness to Fairy-, Psychic-, and Flying-type attacks. Alternatively, Tera Ghost makes Iron Valiant immune to Dragonite's Extreme Speed, allows it to OHKO Gholdengo, and increases its damage output against Skeledirge. Tera Electric is a final option to OHKO Toxapex and physically defensive Corviknight and turn its Steel-type weakness into a resistance.

Physically offensive Pokemon such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Cinderace benefit from Iron Valiant, as they struggle against Dondozo, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W, all of which Iron Valiant can pressure effectively. Entry hazard support from partners like Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Garchomp provides chip damage against Pokemon that try to play around Iron Valiant such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire. Pivots such as Rotom-W, Dragapult, Cinderace, and Corviknight give Iron Valiant opportunities to get on the field, reducing the risk of it taking damage. Volcarona can counter Iron Valiant, as it is only 3HKOed by all of its attacks and can set up in front of it. Therefore, Toxapex is a great partner, as is specially defensive Garganacl, which can handle Will-O-Wisp Volcarona, and Dragonite, which can handle Giga Drain variants. Iron Valiant enjoys the presence of partners that it can rely on to take hits, such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl, due to its frailty. Keeping the field free from hazards grants Iron Valiant more chances to get on the field and make progress, so teammates with access to Rapid Spin or Defog such as Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Corviknight are appreciated.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
High attacking stats and a wide array of coverage moves make Iron Valiant a devastating mixed attacker that can 2HKO common defensive walls physically and specially; Moonblast and Thunderbolt threaten physically defensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo, while Close Combat and Psyshock deal with specially defensive foes like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Its Quark Drive-boosted Speed from Booster Energy turns it into a potent late-game cleaner, letting it outspeed would-be revenge killers like Dragapult, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, which is further enforced by its unique typing that resists Sucker Punch from Kingambit. However, it can also be used to revenge kill boosted threats like Baxcalibur and Dragonite in a pinch, especially since Iron Valiant can take on the latter's +1 Tera Normal Extreme Speed from full health. Tera Fairy boosts Iron Valiant's Moonblast while still retaining its defensive profile to take on Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Tera Electric amplifies Thunderbolt's damage, notably allowing it to 2HKO would-be checks like Toxapex, specially defensive Dondozo and Tera Water Garganacl, and offensive Gholdengo after Stealth Rock, as well as preventing Iron Valiant from being revenge killed by Scizor's Bullet Punch.

Mixed Iron Valiant is commonly seen on offense and bulky offense teams. Due to the lack of a damage boosting item or setup move, it can still fall short of threatening bulky Pokemon like Amoonguss, and without Shadow Ball or Knock Off, Skeledirge and defensive Gholdengo as well; thus, Pokemon that can deal with them such as Great Tusk, and Kingambit make good teammates. Particularly, the aforementioned Pokemon can overwhelm a shared check in Corviknight and are generally effective as early-game wallbreakers that can open up Iron Valiant to clean up late-game easily. Entry hazards from teammates like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora can chip down foes like Garganacl, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Dondozo. A sturdy defensive backbone with the likes of Corviknight and Ting-Lu can help check offensive threats that threaten Iron Valiant out, such as a boosted Roaring Moon, opposing Iron Valiant, and Gholdengo. Pivots like Dragapult, Scizor, and Rotom-W can compensate for Iron Valiant's lack of bulk by bringing it in safely on foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Blissey, respectively; the latter can also cripple Amoonguss with either Trick or Will-O-Wisp. Gholdengo is a great partner, as it reliably prevents the much-needed entry hazards from being removed by Rapid Spin and Defog, threatens Skeledirge and Tera Fairy Garganacl, and appreciates Iron Valiant dealing with foes like Corviknight and Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon in return.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Iron Valiant utilizes a deadly combination of offensive power, coverage, and Speed to function as one of the best sweepers in OU. After a Quark Drive boost, Iron Valiant outspeeds and OHKOes a plethora of premier offensive threats in the tier, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon. Thunderbolt allows Iron Valiant to damage Corviknight and bulky Water-types like Dondozo, Azumarill, Toxapex, and Tera Water Garganacl, while Psyshock scores a 2HKO on any Clodsire looking to stop Iron Valiant's sweep. With Calm Mind, Iron Valiant can switch roles from an endgame sweeper to a powerful wallbreaker. After one Calm Mind, Moonblast 2HKOes defensive Garganacl, and +1 Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes specially defensive Slowking and OHKOes Corviknight. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast, which can now 2HKO Garganacl and Hatterene. Tera Electric boosts the power of Thunderbolt, which secures important 2HKOs on specially defensive Dodonzo, Corviknight, and Toxapex, lets Iron Valiant survive Scizor's Bullet Punch, and grants Iron Valiant an immunity to paralysis from Hatterene's Nuzzle.

Iron Valiant relies heavily on its super-effective coverage moves for damage output. As a result, it struggles to make progress against Pokemon like Volcarona, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo. Thus, teammates like Clodsire and Ting-Lu are good defensive partners for Iron Valiant, with the added benefit of being able to set up entry hazards. Iron Moth has strong offensive synergy with Iron Valiant, being able to threaten Amoonguss, Iron Treads, and Tera Fairy Garganacl, while also being able to chip down special walls like Clodsire. On offense teams, Iron Valiant complements powerful wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Kingambit, since they can overwhelm defensive cores and open up the path for Iron Valiant to sweep. Finally, Iron Valiant is highly reliant on Booster Energy to sweep, as it cannot normally outspeed common revenge-killers like Dragapult, Cinderace, and Meowscarada. Therefore, it is important to time when to switch in to Iron Valiant to ensure defensive counters like Skeledirge and Volcarona are either removed or heavily damaged so it can sweep or break through the opposing team effectively. Along these lines, it is important to conserve Iron Valiant's health, since it can survive key priority moves such as Extreme Speed from Tera Normal Dragonite after a Dragon Dance. Therefore, Pokemon that can remove entry hazards, such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, are great teammates for Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
• Life Orb Iron Valiant is a strong wallbreaker that can threaten common walls such as Corviknight, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Skeledirge, Blissey, and Toxapex.
  • Thunderbolt is a good coverage move to hit Corviknight and Toxapex hard and is especially powerful under Electric Terrain. Psyshock is Iron Valiant's strongest option for breaking through Clodsire.
  • Knock Off lets Iron Valiant wear down potential checks by removing Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots. Shadow Ball hits most targets neutrally and Skeledirge and Scream Tail, which would otherwise wall it, super effectively. However, this option is outclassed by Knock Off and Psyshock.
  • Tera Fairy makes Iron Valiant's Moonblast immensely strong while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams thanks to its ability to outspeed and KO common offensive foes while under Electric Terrain, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Great Tusk, while pressuring walls including Ting-Lu, Corviknight, Clodsire, and Toxapex. However, Life Orb recoil and the ever-present entry hazards make it difficult for Iron Valiant to maintain pressure in longer games, and common, faster wallbreakers, such as Scarf Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Protosynthesis-boosted Flutter Mane, force Iron Valiant out.
  • Miraidon is a fantastic partner for Iron Valiant thanks to it providing Electric Terrain support and pivoting Iron Valiant in with U-turn. In return, Iron Valiant can take on Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Blissey, and Chien-Pao for Miraidon while switching into Dragon moves from opposing Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Wallbreakers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane appreciate Iron Valiant breaking through Corviknight and Toxapex while they take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk and Skeledirge are great teammates for dealing with Koraidon, which can take on any of Iron Valiant's attacks with Tera Fire and set up sun to make it harder for Iron Valiant to revenge kill Flutter Mane.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight is a fantastic partner for soft checking Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane while removing entry hazards with Defog. Great Tusk also clears hazards, making it easier for Iron Valiant to consistently come in during a match.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
• Booster Energy Iron Valiant is a good anti-offense Pokemon, as it outspeeds and revenge kills many hyper offense staples such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Miraidon.
  • Thunderbolt hits Toxapex and Corviknight hard, while Focus Blast is Iron Valiant's strongest STAB option against Tera Steel Pokemon like Ting-Lu which would otherwise check Iron Valiant. Focus Blast also 2HKOes Blissey after a Calm Mind boost, something that Psyshock fails to do.
  • Psyshock hits Unaware Clodsire and the rare Iron Moth for super effective damage. Shadow Ball, on the other hand, hits Skeledirge, Iron Valiant's biggest roadblock, but it doesn't offer much outside of that.
  • Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast while retaining Iron Valiant's useful defensive niche against Sucker Punch from Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Kingambit. However, Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes Toxapex and Corviknight without a boost. It also makes Iron Valiant immune to Thunder Wave and removes its weakness to Steel-type attacks.
  • Booster Energy Iron Valiant is best suited for offensive teams and, as such, should be used offensively, using its perfect coverage to break enemy walls and revenge kill threats to its team.
  • Miraidon is Iron Valiant's best teammate, as it sets Electric Terrain, letting Iron Valiant conceal its item; it also powers up Thunderbolt and can get Iron Valiant safely into the field with U-turn. Iron Valiant, in return, deals with Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Blissey for Miraidon. Other hyper offense Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and Dragonite appreciate Iron Valiant for its good matchup against other offensive teams.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Iron Valiant is a potent offensive threat that is difficult to switch into thanks to its spammable STAB attacks and high Speed under Electric Terrain.
  • Thunderbolt breaks through Corviknight and Toxapex and is further boosted by Electric Terrain. Shadow Ball pressures Skeledirge and Scream Tail, but Psyshock is an option to beat Clodsire, which would wall this set otherwise.
  • Fairy is Iron Valiant's best Tera type, as it makes its Moonblast incredibly difficult to switch into, threatening to OHKO Flutter Mane, while maintaining its Dragon immunity and resistance to Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao.
  • Iron Valiant fits on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take on common Dark- and Dragon-types such as Ting-Lu, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, Miraidon, and Koraidon. Iron Valiant also helps break past walls such as Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex, which are roadblocks for its teammates such as Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Miraidon is the best partner for Iron Valiant thanks to powering up Thunderbolt, boosting its Speed because of Quark Drive, and pivoting into Iron Valiant with U-turn. Similarly, wallbreakers such as Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Chien-Pao appreciate Iron Valiant breaking Corviknight and Toxapex, and they can take on Skeledirge for Iron Valiant in return. Finally, Skeledirge uses Corviknight as setup fodder, and Great Tusk threatens Tera Fire Koraidon for Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Specs (Fighting)
sets.description:
Iron Valiant is a special attacker with an unmatched Speed tier in a sea of physical attackers, making it a solid pick for Fighting teams. It also has a spammable Fairy STAB movr in Moonblast, which allows it to ease the Dark match up by threatening Sableye while also neutering opposing Fighting-types such as Great Tusk and Breloom. Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types such as Dondozo and Corviknight. Psyshock hits Poison-types such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Clodsire, whereas Future Sight can apply pressure to opponents like Toxapex for teammates such as Breloom and Gallade. Shadow Ball hits Ghost-types such as Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Aura Sphere can be used instead as a hard-hitting STAB move, while Trick is a neat option that cripples potential switch-ins such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, Clodsire, and Skuntank.

Wallbreakers such as Breloom and Gallade appreciate Iron Valiant's ability to take out physical walls as well as its ability to pressure the opponent with Future Sight. Assault Vest Iron Hands is a fantastic partner as well thanks to its ginormous HP stat that lets it deal with Fairy-types such as Flutter Mane and Hatterene that can outspeed or wall Iron Valiant. Choice Scarf users such as Flamigo, Quaquaval, and Slither Wing pressure Pokemon faster than Iron Valiant such as Greninja, Dragapult, and Cinderace. Tauros-F is another fantastic partner thanks to its ability to shatter dual screens with Raging Bull, making Iron Valiant more effective in matchups against Dark, Fairy, and Ice, all while avoiding burns thanks to its part Fire typing, which helps against Ghost and Dark teams.

sets.name: Special Attacker (Fairy)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Physical Destiny Bond
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's blistering Speed and Destiny Bond make it a cybernetic assassin that's excellent at taking foes down with it!

  • Shadow Sneak: Shadow Sneak is Iron Valiant's best tool against Flutter Mane and is useful for picking off Focus Sash foes such as Iron Bundle.

  • Encore: Encore plugs in perfectly with Destiny Bond, punishing foes that use support moves to avoid getting taken down with Iron Valiant.

  • Spirit Break: Besides being a decent STAB move, Spirit Break's Special Attack drops give Iron Valiant a chance to help teammates set up after it gets KOed.

  • Knock Off: This is Iron Valiant's only way to 2HKO offensive Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost lets Iron Valiant safely Encore Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

  • Fighting: An extra powerful Close Combat gives Iron Valiant better late-game cleaning potential.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Getting around Iron Valiant's aluminum-thin bulk gives it the potential to take down multiple Pokemon.

  • Booster Energy: Getting a one-time Speed boost trades Iron Valiant's great early-game potential for excellent revenge killing potential.

sets.name: Special Destiny Bond
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's high Special Attack and Destiny Bond make it a highly unpredictable threat that can surprise its more physically defensive checks, such as Dondozo.

  • Encore: This will give any foe attempting to use support moves to escape Destiny Bond a nasty shock.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball 2HKOes Skeledirge and will often 2HKO defensive Gholedngo, both of whom are common issues for the physical variant of this set.

  • Shadow Sneak: While weak enough to be unable to 2HKO bulkier Flutter Mane, Shadow Sneak is still a great choice for picking off Focus Sash foes such as Great Tusk and Iron Bundle.

  • Close Combat versus Aura Sphere: Even without physical investment, Close Combat is generally the stronger move, and it ensures Blissey and Chansey will not wall Iron Valiant without Terastallization. However, Aura Sphere does hit many physically defensive foes such as Corviknight harder, and it gets around Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Iron Valiant an opening to Encore Extreme Speed Dragonite and gives Shadow Sneak a more acceptable amount of power.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy's boost to Moonblast potentially gains a 2HKO on Dondozo and Terastallized Skeledirge.

Items

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash is particularly useful for letting Iron Valiant surprise Skeledirge, who normally OHKOes with a +1 Torch Song.

  • Booster Energy: While unlikely to enable a sweep unless it's late-game, this consumable Speed boost transforms Iron Valiant into an effective revenge killer.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• While tricky to set up without support, Swords Dance Iron Valiant is a dangerous sweeper that requires dedicated defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Dondozo to easily check.

  • Encore: Encore lets Iron Valiant short-circuit support moves and have a shot of setting up Swords Dance, but this does come at the cost of one of its STAB moves.

  • Close Combat versus Spirit Break: If giving up a slot for Encore, Close Combat's high power against bulky foes such as Kingambit and Corviknight makes it the easy option. Spirit Break's low Base Power reduces Iron Valiant's general sweeping potential in exchange for dealing big damage to common Tera Fairy Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Garchomp.

  • Shadow Sneak versus Knock Off: With a boost, Shadow Sneak is capable of ruining Flutter Mane's attempt to revenge kill, but Knock Off lets Iron Valiant deal with Gholdengo, hit Volcarona and Iron Moth hard, and punish Skeledirge switch ins.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: Powering up Shadow Sneak can make cleaning easier and the Extreme Speed immunity can turn Extreme Speed Dragonite into setup bait with Encore.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has excellent defensive synergy, giving Iron Valiant an important Bullet Punch resistance and covering Flying- and Fairy-type attacks.

  • Fairy / Fighting: Terastallizing into one of Iron Valiant's STAB types can make cleaning through bulky foes easier if dropping coverage for Encore.

  • Fire: In addition to a useful Bullet Punch resistance, Tera Fire gifts Iron Valiant a burn immunity and can even be used with Tera Blast to break defensive Gholdengo and Corviknight.

  • Electric: Not only does this help Iron Valiant against Scizor, but Tera Electric can be paired with Life Orb and Tera Blast to wear down Dondozo.

Items

  • Focus Sash: If not using Encore, this is the most reliable way to get Swords Dance set up.

  • Booster Energy: Quark Drive's Speed boost makes it far more difficult to revenge kill Iron Valiant, outpacing key threats such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb makes Iron Valiant more effective at hit-and-run tactics and can let it OHKO bulky threats such as Corviknight after a boost and Stealth Rock damage.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
• Iron Valiant's excellent special movepool gives it an effective wallbreaking mode that can catch foes such as Skeledirge and Dondozo by surprise.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball is essential for 2HKOing Skeledirge before it Terastallizes, as it's normally a great Iron Valiant check.

  • Encore: Encore is perfect for punishing attempts to set up on Iron Valiant.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock deals massive damage to Iron Moth and Clodsire, who are otherwise big problems.

  • Thunderbolt: This programs Iron Valiant to 2HKO Corviknight and physically defensive Dondozo with Life Orb.

Other Options

  • Calm Mind: Calm Mind makes Iron Valiant even more difficult to wall, but it's very difficult to set up without Focus Sash or Encore.

  • Aura Sphere: Close Combat's higher power is usually preferred, but Aura Sphere does better against Corviknight and makes Iron Valiant less vulnerable to priority attacks.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: With Tera Ghost, Life Orb Shadow Ball OHKOes physically defensive Skeledirge, in addition to giving Iron Valiant an important immunity to Extreme Speed.

  • Fairy: Powering up Moonblast with Tera Fairy can 2HKO even specially defensive Dondozo.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has fantastic defensive synergy, giving useful resistances to Scizor's Bullet Punch and Flying- and Fairy-type attacks.

  • Electric: Tera Electric means Iron Valiant no longer needs Life Orb to reliably 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo without Life Orb, in addition to giving a vital resistance to Scizor's Bullet Punch.

Items

  • Life Orb: While the recoil makes Iron Valiant even more vulnerable to priority attacks, it provides immense wallbreaking power.

  • Booster Energy: Taking advantage of Quark Drive trades easy wallbreaking in exchange for incredible revenge killing power and late-game sweeping.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Valiant leverages its strong attacks, great typing, and good Speed tier to act as a potent special attacker. Fleur Cannon, its most powerful move, threatens common defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Ting-Lu; Moonblast trades power for consistent damage. Vacuum Wave picks off frail, weakened, or faster Pokemon, allowing Iron Valiant to revenge kill Kingambit and Roaring Moon, even after setup. Psyshock pressures specially defensive Pokemon, such as Clodsire, Blissey, and specially defensive Toxapex, while Thunderbolt hits Corviknight and physically defensive Toxapex. Choice Specs Iron Valiant fits best on balance or bulky offense teams that appreciate its immense wallbreaking ability. It pairs well with strong physical attackers such as Roaring Moon and Choice Band Dragonite, as they can work together to pressure each others checks. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Great Tusk also make good partners, as they chip Iron Valiant's checks enough for it to beat them. Iron Valiant isn't very bulky, so it appreciates bulky teammates such as Ting-Lu and Garganacl; Ting-Lu can also use Parting Shot to help Iron Valiant enter the field safely. Cyclizar can clear hazards and pivot Iron Valiant in with Shed Tail.

sets.name: Physical Life Orb
